{"uri": "8111749180", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:45:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:45:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:42:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo/article_60d959b3-987c-571a-84a6-309fe582d8c9.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr. celebrates in the winner's circle after riding Mystik Dan to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "beth_harris@eagletribune.com", "name": "Beth Harris", {"uri": "8111795108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:01:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:01:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/us/sports/mystik-dan-at-18-1-wins-the-150-kentucky-derby/", "title": "Mystik Dan, at 18-1, just edges out two rivals to win the 150th Kentucky Derby", "body": "The Churchill Downs crowd of nearly 157,000 had to wait as the result was reviewed by stewards\n\nAn 18-1 bet, Mystik Dan, has won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a dramatic photo finish for three horses.\n\nOn Saturday Mystik Dan, ridden by Brian J. Hernandez Jr, fought to hang on with the two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did so, but only after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless. This one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million, the Associated Press reported. Mystik Dan ran the 1\u00bc miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 people at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018. \"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favourite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said later. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nOn Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone, ridden by Tyler Gaffalione, bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it. \"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" Mystic Dan trainer Kenny McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not any more, right?\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose - the closest margin in horse racing - and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favourite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nHernandez and McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes - the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. {"uri": "8111810158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:22:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:22:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:21:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://thejewishvoice.com/2024/05/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo-finish-since-1947/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947 - The Jewish Voice", "body": "(AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nKentucky Derby to remain on NBC through 2032 in extension with Churchill Downs\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345455745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:49:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:49:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:16:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.troyrecord.com/2024/05/04/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish-at-churchill-downs-2/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said. \"His mother is a filly who raced hard, but wasn't well known. His father wasn't a big name, either.\"\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. {"uri": "8111737771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:25:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:25:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:22:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/national/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo/article_3492c321-9de1-5dde-a8a1-a9c2fb4b7e72.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nAP horse racing: {"uri": "8111824308", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:44:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:44:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:43:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/04/mystikal-finish-oaklawn-horse-has-a-nose-in-front-at-the-wire-in-kentucky-derby/", "title": "Mystikal finish: Oaklawn horse has a nose in front at the wire in Kentucky Derby", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan, who made three starts at Oaklawn Racing Casino Resort this season earlier this year. He finished third in the Arkansas Derby on March 30, won the Southwest Stakes on Feb. 3 and placed fifth in the Smarty Jones on New Year's Day.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" said trainer Kenny McPeek, who was born in Arkansas at Fort Chaffee. \"His mother is a filly who raced hard, but wasn't well-known. His father wasn't a big name, either.\"\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel, who finished second in the Arkansas Derby, led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.' \"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. {"uri": "8111731052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:10:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:10:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:09:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.twincities.com/2024/05/03/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo-finish-since-1947/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. {"uri": "8111742369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:31:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:31:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:30:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://s24526.pcdn.co/sports/1653700/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish-at-churchill-downs", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs - Times Leader", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said. \"His mother is a filly who raced hard, but wasn't well known. His father wasn't a big name, either.\"\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.", "source": {"uri": According to NBC, the last time a race was this close was in 1996 when Grindstone and jockey Jerry Bailey won.\n\nHernandez and McPeek also won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. They become the first trainer-jockey duo to win both races in the same year since 1952.\n\nThis was the fifth Derby mount for Hernandez and his first ever win. {"uri": "8112383773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:27:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:27:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:25:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1319411", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by nose in photo finish", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" trainer Kenny McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1\u00bc miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call a working-class horse,\" McPeek said. \"His mother is a filly who raced hard, but wasn't well known. His father wasn't a big name, either.\"\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. {"uri": "2024-05-345542761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:11:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:11:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:39:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo/article_7e837804-4de6-5acd-9879-da8b732e07c4.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing\n\nMore from this section\n\nChurch of Scientology Hosts Inner City Shakespeare Ensemble: Young Actors Present Blow-Away Performance of Their PG Version of 'Grease' More than 2,100 people have been arrested during pro-Palestinian protests on US college campuses Striking deals to end campus protests, some colleges invite discussion of their investments", "source": squeezed between Sierra Leone from the outside and Mystik Dan which was running on the rails.\n\nThis is trainer Kenny McPeek's first Kentucky Derby win and his second career Triple Crown win after {"uri": "8111700076", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:19:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:19:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wcpo.com/sports/horse-racing/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish-at-churchill-downs", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a three-horse photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone by a nose with Forever Young third in the tightest finish since 1996 on Saturday.\n\nSent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone wore the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and the bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952 and the fourth overall.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMore {"uri": "8111722524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:56:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:56:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:55:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.tampabay.com/sports/2024/05/04/mystik-dan-wins-kentucky-derby-by-nose-3-horse-photo-finish/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday.\n\nJockey Brian Hernandez Jr. squeezed Mystik Dan through a tight spot to reach the rail turning for home and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He took off down the stretch and built a slight lead.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8113323360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:22:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:22:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T07:21:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/06/uncertain-plans/", "title": "Uncertain plans", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, N.Y., before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that [I have] now.\"\n\nTrainer Kenneth McPeek, right, hand off the trophy to jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. as Hernandez celebrates in the winner's circle after riding Mystik Dan to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson)\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. rides Mystik Dan across the finish line to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson)\n\nCORRECTS TO REMOVE REFERENCE TO FINISH LINE TO WIN - Brian Hernandez Jr. rides Mystik Dan, right, as horses near the first turn during the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs on Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. Mystic Dan went on to win the race. {"uri": "8111749611", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:45:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:45:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:43:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo-finish-since-1947/C63CYAP3VNEMTL5MRLFQRR3W4E/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "That year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. {"uri": "8111726913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:04:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:04:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:03:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://omaha.com/ap/sports/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish/article_a0e66556-dc19-501e-bbbd-6638080b8ffe.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "By BETH HARRIS - AP Racing Writer\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday.\n\nJockey Brian Hernandez Jr. squeezed Mystik Dan through a tight spot to reach the rail turning for home and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He took off down the stretch and built a slight lead.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nAP horse racing: Sierra Leona, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone wore the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952 and the fourth ever.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.", {"uri": "8111679244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:46:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:46:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:45:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10119877-kentucky-derby-2024-final-results-standings-payouts-and-replay-highlights", "title": "Kentucky Derby 2024: Final Results, Standings, Payouts and Replay Highlights", "body": "Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby by one of the smallest margins in the event's history.\n\nMystik Dan edged out Sierra Leone by a nose at the finish line in a race that went down to those two horses and Forever Young.\n\nA key move to the inside allowed Mystik Dan to earn the slightest of advantages at the finish line and cash the pre-race odds at 18-1.\n\nThe victory gave jockey Bryan Hernandez Jr. and trainer Kenneth McPeek the rare double weekend sweep of the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby.\n\nMcPeek became the first trainer to complete the Oaks-Derby double since 1952. Hernandez is the first jockey to do the double at Churchill Downs since Calvin Borel in 2009. Thorpedo Anna won the Oaks for the Hernandez-McPeek duo on Friday afternoon.\n\nSierra Leone produced the cleanest race of the favored horses. He made a late run down the outside, but he was one nose away from catching Mystik Dan.\n\nForever Young attempted to become the first Japanese horse to win the first leg of the Triple Crown, but he finished third in the close finish behind Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone.\n\nPre-face favorite Fierceness finished 24 1/2 lengths behind the top three horses and was never in contention for first place.\n\nCatching Freedom took fourth, T O Password finished fifth to put two Japanese entries in the top five and long shot Resilience took home sixth.\n\nMystik Dan will likely participate in the Preakness Stakes in two weeks as his unlikely march to the Triple Crown continues.", "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bleacher Report"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112181029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:11:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:11:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:10:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10119879-kentucky-derby-results-2024-final-race-chart-finishing-times-and-purse", "title": "Kentucky Derby Results 2024: Final Race Chart, Finishing Times and Purse", "body": "The 150th Kentucky Derby required a photo finish to decide the winner between three horses, with Mystik Dan (at 16-1 odds) finally getting announced as the victor.\n\nWith over 156,000 in attendance, the thoroughbred held onto a narrow lead over Sierra Leone (5-1) and Forever Young (6-1) across the finish line.\n\nFierceness (7-2) entered the race as the betting favorite, jumping out to an early lead at the quarter pole before falling behind down the stretch and eventually finishing in 15th place.\n\nKenneth McPeek, Mystik Dan's trainer, became the first trainer to win both the Derby and the Kentucky Oaks on the same weekend since 1952 after Thorpedo Anna emerged victorious at the Oaks on Friday.\n\nHere's the final race chart, finishing times, and purse for the 2024 Derby.\n\n2024 Kentucky Derby Finishing Time, Race Chart and Purse\n\nThe Derby contained a record-breaking guaranteed $5 million purse, with $3.1 million going to Mystik Dan. This surpassed the previous $3 million purse, which had been in place since 2019.\n\nMcPeek gave credit to jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. after the win, calling him \"one of the most underrated riders in racing\" although he acknowledged that the underrated label would likely no longer apply after the historic win on Saturday.\n\n\"Brian just did an amazing job,\" McPeek said. \"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride. I mean, the draw helped us from the beginning. We talked about that.\"\n\nThe result went under review before it was declared official, causing some brief confusion regarding the winner. Hernandez called the wait before the official announcement \"the longest few minutes of my life,\" via the Associated Press (h/t ESPN).\n\n\"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while,\" Hernandez added.\n\nAfter the leader changed several times throughout the race, Mystik Dan surged to the front down the inner rail of the track before maintaining the lead down the stretch and just barely edging out Sierra Leone and Forever Young.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez explained, per the Associated Press. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nMcPeek was able to complete a career Triple Crown on Saturday after previously securing wins at the 2020 Preakness Stakes as well as the 2002 Belmont Stakes.\n\nCatching Freedom, a horse that entered the Derby with 8-1 odds, placed fourth while T O Password (47-1) finished at No. 5.\n\nNow, Mystik Dan will attempt to complete the second leg of a potential triple crown at the Preakness Stakes on May 18.", "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
