{"uri": "8111741864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:30:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:30:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:29:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/sports/national/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo/article_68b75f83-1a2c-5178-a302-549a8de26355.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "By BETH HARRIS - AP Racing Writer\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nPeople are also reading... Sports anchor-reporter Heather Prusak exiting WIVB After fatal shootings, members of Buffalo's Bangladeshi community are angry, afraid Tesla ending Supercharger work based at its Buffalo plant, report says Ryan O'Halloran: Bills fans, give this team time to jell and you may be rewarded Man charged with criminal possession of weapon in connection with Zenner Street double homicide Mike Harrington: For now, Sabres need to forget about titles and get their Andy Dalton moment Commission censures Judge Mark Grisanti for shoving Buffalo cop handcuffing his wife Tops acquires five Perna-owned Tops franchise stores Lack of transparency over Bills PSL pricing upsets some season ticket holders Bills sign three free agents, including WR Chase Claypool Erie County real estate transactions National analysts weigh in on Buffalo Bills' draft class 7 Sabres who can benefit from Lindy Ruff taking over as the Sabres' head coach Buffalo Bills bringing in Quintez Cephus, begin to add UDFAs to roster after NFL draft Buffalo police looking for help identifying suspect in double murder on Zenner Street\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8111975794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:50:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:50:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:49:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/horse-racing/articles/cld0x5x3lkgo", "title": "Kentucky Derby: Mystik Dan wins three-horse photo finish by a nose", "body": "Mystik Dan edged a three-horse photo finish by a nose to win the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe 18-1 shot, ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr, won the thriller in front of 156,710 fans at Churchill Downs with Sierra Leone in second place and Forever Young a nose further back.\n\nIt took several minutes for the stewards to confirm the result.\n\n\"Those were the longest few minutes of my life,\" said Hernandez. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby.\n\n\"I don't think it will sink in for a while. It's like a dream come true.\"\n\nPre-race favourite Fierceness was among the early pace setters but as they faded Mystik Dan burst through on the inside rail to take the lead on the turn for home.\n\nSierra Leone and Forever Young nearly reeled him back in but Mystik Dan just held on.\n\nIt was the 10th time the race had been decided by a nose and the first since 1996.\n\nIt was also the second win of the weekend for Hernandez Jr and trainer Kenny McPeek, who also teamed up for victory in the Kentucky Oaks on Friday on Thorpedo Anna.\n\n\"For three weeks, I've felt like we were going to win both races,\" added McPeek.\n\n\"I can't tell you why. Both horses have been easy to deal with, the team has done such a great job every day. There's been no drama.\n\n\"I just believe in mojo, in positive energy and we've had a lot of it.\"", "source": {"uri": "bbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BBC"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Churchill_Downs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Churchill Downs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epsom_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Epsom Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Oaks", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Oaks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_trainer", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Horse trainer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_racing", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Horse racing"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Adventure_Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Adventure Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Snowmobile_Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Snowmobile Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 81}], "image": "https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1024/branded_sport/1bd8/live/65046ab0-0aa3-11ef-803e-1931033d7030.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539947", "eventUri": "eng-9539947", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 193, "relevance": 1}

{"uri": "8111791093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:56:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:56:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:54:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.newson6.com/story/6636c2d1d467d10645a4db7c/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-in-stunning-photo-finish-tulsas-attorneys-horse-finishes-11th", "title": "Mystik Dan Wins 150th Kentucky Derby In Stunning Photo Finish; Tulsa's Attorney's Horse Finishes 11th", "body": "Sent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone wore the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and the bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nMystik Dan will earn $3.1 million from a total purse of $5 million, the largest purse in the race's history. The purse is split among the top five finishers in the Derby, with $1 million for the runner-up, $500,000 for third place, $250,000 for fourth place and $150,000 for fifth place.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952 and the fourth overall.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.", {"uri": "8111766252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:16:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:16:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:11:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/brian-hernandez-jr-long-underappreciated-020713304.html", "title": "Brian Hernandez Jr., long an underappreciated jockey, rides an unforgettable Kentucky Derby", "body": "As a native of Lafayette, Louisiana, who has largely spent his jockey career as a regular on the Kentucky circuit, Brian Hernandez Jr. felt an obvious connection with Calvin Borel.\n\nSo when 18-1 shot Mystik Dan, the horse Hernandez was to ride in the historic 150th Kentucky Derby, drew the third post position, Hernandez immediately thought of Borel.\n\nIn an improbable late career surge, Borel -- a native of St. Martin Parish, Louisiana, who also rode regularly in the commonwealth -- scored three Kentucky Derby victories, utilizing a rail-hugging, ground-saving style to claim the last two of those wins in the 2009 Derby aboard Mine That Bird and the 2010 Run for the Roses on Super Saver.\n\n\"With Mystik Dan being in the three hole, I watched a couple of (Borel's) rides there between Super Saver and Mine That Bird,\" Hernandez said. \"I said, 'You know what? We're going to roll the dice.'\"\n\nDelivering a \"Calvin Bo-Rail\" special, Hernandez made a bold move along the rail in the final turn that, ultimately, allowed Mystik Dan to get through to the lead and save just enough ground to prevail at the wire in a scintillating three-horse charge to the finish with Sierra Leone and Forever Young.\n\nWith a Churchill Downs crowed of 156,710 roaring, the three horses crossed the finish line almost locked in stride.\n\nUltimately, a photo finish showed Mystik Dan a nose ahead of Sierra Leone, who was a nose ahead of third-place Forever Young, the previously unbeaten Japanese horse. The winning time was 2:03.34.\n\nThe three-way photo to determine the victor was the first in a Kentucky Derby since 1947. It was a finish worthy of the 150th renewal of North America's marquee horse race -- and the ride by Hernandez proved every bit worthy of such a historic moment.\n\nOnce Mystik Dan claimed the lead entering the stretch, Hernandez said he had his head down, riding, and did not realize until the final jumps of the race that there were closers to his horse's outside charging hard to take the Kentucky Derby away.\n\nOnce the finish line had been crossed, Hernandez said he asked an outrider if Mystik Dan had won. The reply was probably, but it was not certain pending the photo.\n\nThe wait for Derby certainty \"was the longest two minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said.\n\nThe victory by trainer Kenny McPeek's Mystik Dan made Hernandez a Kentucky Derby champion in his fifth try at the race. In four previous Derbys, Hernandez had not finished better than eighth.\n\n\"It's unbelievable,\" Hernandez said. \"It still hasn't sunk in yet.\"\n\nEleven years ago, the 38-year-old Hernandez had another signature moment on one of horse racing's grandest stages. On the jockey's 27th birthday, he guided Fort Larned to victory in the 2012 Breeders' Cup Classic at Santa Anita.\n\nYet, for whatever reason, that victory did not elevate Hernandez's career to the elite level of racing.\n\nToiling mostly on the Kentucky racing circuit, Hernandez's great patron became McPeek. The trainer, a Tates Creek High School and University of Kentucky graduate, has long given Hernandez chances on his best horses. In 2021, Hernandez won four stakes races at Keeneland -- all on horses trained by McPeek.\n\n\"Well, the older you get, I don't get enamored with all the, I guess you could say, big-namers,\" McPeek said of more famous jockeys. \"With Brian and his agent (Frank Bernis), there's nothing complicated about either one of them. It's all business, business, business -- and there's no drama. And I like 'no drama.'\"\n\nOn Saturday, Hernandez repaid McPeek's faith.\n\nThe key point in the race came in the final turn. A tiring Track Phantom drifted out slightly. Hernandez asked Mystik Dan to push through a small hole along the rail.\n\n\"When I called upon him to hit that spot that I needed right before we straightened, to kind of get a little separation on the deep, deep closers, he did it,\" Hernandez said of Mystik Dan. \"He jumped off quickly and we were able to get that separation, and that made the difference of them not getting to him (at) the wire.\"\n\nAs the winning jockey in Kentucky Derby 150, Hernandez etched his name in race lore.\n\nHe joins Oliver Lewis (first Derby in 1875), J.D. Mooney (50th Derby in 1924) and Angel Cordero Jr. (100th Run for the Roses in 1974) as the winning jockeys in numerically significant Kentucky Derbys.\n\nIt was the weekend of a lifetime for the McPeek-Hernandez duo. The jockey and trainer also combined to win Friday's Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nThat makes Hernandez the eighth jockey all-time to win the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks in the same year. He is the first to do so since -- you guessed it -- Borel (Rachel Alexandra in the Oaks, Mine That Bird in the Derby) in 2009.\n\nAll it took for Hernandez to win the Kentucky Derby and put his name on several historic lists was a daring move along the rail that would have done Borel proud.\n\nSaid McPeek: \"Brian, his ride, was the difference today in winning.\"\n\nMystik Dan wins historic 2024 Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish at Churchill Downs\n\nSee the best photos, videos from 2024 Kentucky Derby: Mystik Dan's win, fashion, celebrities\n\nKentucky Derby 2024 complete order of finish and payoffs at Churchill Downs\n\n'I believe in mojo.' Lexington trainer earns rare double in thrilling Derby photo finish.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345280129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:38:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:38:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:21:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish/article_ff047e61-70f7-53a6-b388-c09d860b6756.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "A race fan walks through the grounds Saturday at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a photo finish, edging out Forever Young and Sierra Leone for the upset victory.\n\nSent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Forever Young from Japan and Sierra Leone gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22 to win.\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. {"uri": "8111808118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:19:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:19:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:19:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/mystik-dan-won-kentucky-derby-030630621.html", "title": "Mystik Dan won the Kentucky Derby by a whisker. The key? One great ride.", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- There would have been a fleeting moment nearly three decades ago, participating in his first Kentucky Derby, when Kenny McPeek thought he might just win it. He was just 32 years old back then, barely starting to crack the top echelon of the sport, and a horse named Tejano Run -- the first big horse he had in his barn -- was flying through the stretch.\n\nUltimately, Tejano Run came up just short to Thunder Gulch. McPeek, a young and confident trainer, figured it was just the beginning.\n\n\"If I thought it would take me this long to knock it down...\" he said, his voice trailing off Saturday night. \"I thought I'd do it before today.\"\n\nBut in the 29 years since, McPeek has won a ton of races and learned a lot of lessons. One of them, of course, is that winning the Derby is really, really hard: None of his next eight Derby runners even hit the board.\n\nHe learned another lesson, too: It doesn't take a superstar jockey to give a horse a great ride.\n\nAnd on Saturday, in the 150th Kentucky Derby, 38-year-old journeyman Brian Hernandez delivered one of the great human performances in the history of the race.\n\nAnd the horse he rode wasn't too bad, either.\n\nWith a rail-skimming ride that was practically perfect in its boldness and timing, Hernandez got 18-1 shot Mystik Dan home by a whisker over the surging Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a three-horse photo finish that left the Churchill Downs crowd of 156,710 initially wondering who had won America's most famous horse race.\n\n\"(Hernandez) was the difference in winning and losing today, for sure,\" McPeek said.\n\nThough McPeek's career has progressed from his first Derby in 1995 to the point where he was operating one of the top 20 stables in the country on a regular basis -- including a Preakness and Belmont victory -- he's never had a weekend like this one.\n\nOn Friday, he and Hernandez dominated the Kentucky Oaks with front-running Thorpedo Anna. A mere 24 hours later, they pulled a Derby shocker with a humbly bred colt who shot to the lead coming off the final turn and needed every inch of ground Hernandez was able to save to get his nose on the wire first.\n\n\"Three jumps before the wire I didn't see (the other horses) at all,\" Hernandez said. \"And right at the wire they surged late and I was like, 'Did we win the Kentucky Derby?' That was the longest two minutes waiting. From the fastest two minutes to the longest.\"\n\nThe end result is that Hernandez is the first jockey to win the Oaks-Derby double since Calvin Borel in 2009, and McPeek is the first trainer to do it since 1952, making him a cinch to one day enter the horse racing Hall of Fame.\n\n\"For three weeks I felt like we were going to win both races,\" McPeek said. \"I can't tell you why. Both horses have been so easy to deal with, the team has done such a great job every day. I believe in mojo and positive energy, and we had a lot of that.\"\n\nThough Hernandez has spent a couple of decades riding the Kentucky circuit, Mystik Dan was just his fifth mount in the Derby -- a number that suggests he's never been considered among the top tier of riders.\n\nBut about seven or eight years ago, he started riding a lot of horses for McPeek, who appreciated his professionalism and the solid work he would put in day after day. He didn't have to beg Hernandez or his agent to get on his horses, scheduling conflicts were resolved easily and he rarely found himself second-guessing a ride.\n\n\"It's business, business, business with no drama,\" McPeek said. \"I like no drama, especially the older I get. But more than anything, I put Brian on horses on a daily basis -- good horses and average horses -- and he does a good job on every one of them. Then I'll get outside the box and go to Saratoga and ride some other riders and go, 'Boy, I miss Brian because he doesn't make many mistakes.'\n\n\"I don't want anybody to know how good Brian is, but I guess the cat's out of the bag.\"\n\nIn February, Mystik Dan stamped himself as a possible Derby horse with an eight-length victory in the Southwest Stakes at Oaklawn Park, the home track of Arkansas-based owners Lance and Sherilyn Gasaway.\n\nBut after a bit of a disappointing third-place finish in the Arkansas Derby, Mystik Dan was slightly forgotten in the Derby lead-up while most of the attention went to horses like Fierceness and Sierra Leone.\n\nWhen Mystik Dan drew the No. 3 post position, assuring a rail trip would be his likely way through the field, Hernandez went to the film room to watch Calvin Borel, a fellow south Louisiana native he got to know when he first arrived in Kentucky with big hopes and dreams.\n\nBorel -- nicknamed Bo-rail due to his affinity for hugging the inside lane -- won the Derby three times with Street Sense (2007), Mine That Bird (2009) and Super Saver (2010). All three times, he came through on the rail with a burst of speed that proved decisive in victory.\n\n\"I was like, 'I'm going to roll the dice,' \" Hernandez said. \"Kenny trusts me to do things like that. We thought we had the right kind of horse to give him that kind of trip.\"\n\nAs the race unfolded, Hernandez was able to establish position just behind the leaders -- including 3-1 favorite Fierceness -- who were setting a pretty fast pace with a 46.63-second half-mile.\n\nAs the field approached the quarter-pole, Hernandez guided Mystik Dan right on the heels of long-shot Track Phantom, waiting for an opening to develop. Then, as the horses came off the turn, Track Phantom drifted out and Hernandez immediately signaled to Mystik Dan that it was time to go.\n\nIn the blink of an eye, he cut the corner and opened up a couple-length lead on the field as Track Phantom, Fierceness and the rest of that leading pack began to tire.\n\n\"We might have took out a little of the inside fence, but that's OK,\" Hernandez said. \"I was just smiling the whole time. It's an amazing feeling when you are on the horse under you and you know they're going to go forward.\"\n\nMeanwhile, another battle was happening behind Mystik Dan. Sierra Leone and the Japanese entrant, Forever Young, began to move in tandem. Through the stretch, they appeared to make contact several times -- though it wasn't entirely clear which horse was at fault -- but were still gaining on Mystik Dan with every stride.\n\nIn retrospect, that probably made the difference given the razor-thin margin.\n\n\"I had a hard time keeping him straight,\" said Sierra Leone's jockey, Tyler Gaffalione. \"That definitely cost us.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the crowd gasped as the horses hit the wire, unsure who had actually won the race. Chad Brown, the trainer of Sierra Leone, thought it might have been a dead-heat. McPeek felt like he had won the race in real time and was even more confident when he saw a slow-motion replay on a monitor in his box.\n\nAfter the trophy ceremony, he finally had a chance to watch the whole race, having finally captured the Derby he had been chasing since 1995. The analysis was shockingly simple.\n\n\"Great ride,\" he said. \"Great ride.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8111733621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:16:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:16:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:14:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/horseracing/s-3231734", "title": "Mystik Dan wins the 150th Kentucky Derby by less than a nose", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The margin was a nose but the smiles were a mile wide. In one of the closest finishes in almost 30 years, Mystik Dan won the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe horse was generally overlooked by most but he ran a smart race on the rail and poked his head in front in the final strides to hold off Sierra Leone and Forever Young in the blanket finish.\n\nIt also completed a rare double for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez, who also won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. It was only the fourth time that has been done.\n\n\"That was the longest few minutes in my life I've spent waiting for them to hang the dang number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\nMcPeek was effusive with his praise for Hernandez.\n\n\"Brian did an amazing job,\" McPeek said. \"He's just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey. He's probably one of the most underrated riders in the business. But not anymore.\"\n\nMystik Dan paid $39.22 to win.\n\nThe 3-year-old colt found his way to Churchill Downs with a third-place finish in the Arkansas Derby and a win in the Southwest Stakes, both at Oaklawn.\n\nMystik Dan likely will have a rematch with the Arkansas Derby winner, Muth, in two weeks at the Preakness.\n\nFierceness, the favorite, finished 15th, proving he may well be a \"bounce\" horse, running well every other race.\n\n...continued", "source": {"uri": "arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ArcaMax"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111675314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:39:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:39:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:38:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/sports/other/racing-tradition-hats-fashion/article_5fd9512c-ab7a-560d-9482-d2e12c162fac.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby in 3-horse photo finish", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Mystik Dan won a dramatic 150th Kentucky Derby Saturday at Churchill Downs, edging out second-place Sierra Leone by a nose in a photo finish.\n\nSierra Leone was the second favorite at 9-2 entering the race, with Forever Young, at 7-1, finishing third.\n\nMystik Dan went out of the third stall and went off at 18-1. With Brian Hernandez Jr. at the controls, Mystik Dan got against the rail as he tried to squeeze past the lead pack entering the final stretch.\n\nOnce he got past the lead group, Hernandez was able to hold off the rest of the field and win his first Kentucky Derby.\n\nMystik Dan won in a little more than 2 minutes, 3 seconds. He became the 10th horse to win the Derby by a nose in the race's history.\n\nThe 3-1 favorite, Fierceness, finished 15th.\n\nThe next Triple Crown race comes in two weeks when the Preakness Stakes is held at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.\n\nTags Wire Dcc Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use {"uri": "8113315556", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:17:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:17:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T07:15:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/mystik-dan-wins-kentucky-derby-thriller-by-a-nose/article_93c2a2a8-48d2-5edc-98f8-70d8d7786132.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins Kentucky Derby thriller by a nose", "body": "BETH HARRIS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Suspect in Heartland college carjacking granted pretrial release Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Normal man arrested in home invasion, sexual assault investigation Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Former Fairbury officer sentenced to 4 years in prison in sexual assault case Man waiting murder trial accused of contacting witness from McLean County Jail Pitching talents of Pontiac's Henry Brummel attracting professional scouts Protesters camp on ISU quad in Normal, call for cease-fire in Israel-Hamas war\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said. \"His mother is a filly who raced hard, but wasn't well known. His father wasn't a big name, either.\"\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 {"uri": "8112931990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:12:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:12:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:11:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-other-top-finishers-uncertain-for-preakness-5644180", "title": "Kentucky Derby Winner Mystik Dan, Other Top Finishers Uncertain for Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and Mystik Dan's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" Mr. McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those [situations] where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds, and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid-back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Mr. Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Kentucky Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Mr. Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs Mr. McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. Mr. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' Sierra Leona, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled.\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMore than 156,000 fans were in attendance to watch \"The Greatest Two Minutes in Sports\" at Churchill Downs.\n\nGloomy skies and occasional rain drops gave way to blue skies and sunshine. {"uri": "8112742660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:43:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:43:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T19:43:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/05/mystik-dan-and-several-other-top-horses-might-be-held-out-of-preakness/", "title": "Mystik Dan and several other top horses might be held out of Preakness", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr. celebrates in the winner's circle after riding Mystik Dan to victory in the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. Jeff Roberson/Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nUP NEXT\n\nWHAT: The Preakness Stakes\n\nWHEN: May 18\n\nWHERE: Pimlico Race Course, Baltimore\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Belmont Stakes - the Triple Crown's final jewel - for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap between the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds, and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse, but when we brought him out, (he) was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines, with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nJockey Brian Hernandez Jr. and Mystik Dan, right, head toward the finish alongside Forever Young, center, and Sierra Leone, left, in the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. Brynn Anderson/Associated Press\n\nAs McPeek and the owners of Mystik Dan ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that, and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat, and the first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed while a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point, he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. {"uri": "8111711404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:37:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:37:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:36:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://ksltv.com/641791/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby/", "title": "Mystik Dan Wins 150th Kentucky Derby By Nose In 3-Horse Photo Finish", "body": "Sent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone wore the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and the bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952 and the fourth overall.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. {"uri": "2024-05-345295831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:27:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:27:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:20:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/article288276295.html", "title": "Who is Mystik Dan? What to know about the long-shot champion of Kentucky Derby 2024", "body": "Mystik Dan has won the 150th Kentucky Derby, a surprise to many given he was largely overlooked leading up to the race.\n\nAlong with offering an exhilarating by-a-nose photo finish, the horse also has a local tie in that he's Kentucky bred and his trainer is a University of Kentucky graduate.\n\nHere's what you need to know about one dandy horse that claimed the blanket of red roses:\n\nWhat were Mystik Dan's odds?\n\nMystik Dan went off at 18-1 odds at post time, edging forward to win by a nose in an electrifying photo finish.\n\nThe bay colt was bred in Kentucky and earned little attention going into Saturday's race. Most of the buzz centered on favorite Fierceness (3-1) and such top contenders as Sierra Leone (9/2), Forever Young (6-1), Catching Freedom (8-1) and others.\n\nStill, Mystik Dan was not to be dismissed, previously excelling on a sloppy track when he won the Southwest Stakes in February. He earned his first career win at Churchill Downs last November.\n\nPrior to his Kentucky Derby win Saturday, 38-year-old Brian Hernandez was winless on four Derby starts. The Louisiana native's best Derby finish was eighth on McCracken in 2017.\n\nMoments after Mystik Dan nudged his nose across the finish line Saturday, a breathless Hernandez talked about the \"rush\" of his exhilarating win. Winning the Kentucky Derby has been his dream since childhood, the Eclipse Award-winning jockey said.\n\n\"When I was a 6-year-old kid riding my bike around my grandparents' farm, telling them all I was going to win the Kentucky Derby one day, and here we are,\" Hernandez said.\n\nWho is Mystik Dan's trainer?\n\nKenny McPeek, 61, is an Arkansas native with strong local ties: He's a graduate of both Tates Creek High School and the University of Kentucky.\n\nAn accomplished trainer, McPeek won the Preakness Stakes in 2020 with Swiss Skydiver and the Belmont Stakes in 2002 with Sarava. He previously had nine Kentucky Derby starts, but finally captured his first Derby win Saturday.\n\nLance and Brent Gasaway are cousins and Daniel Hamby III is an Arkansas native owner.", "source": With the win, Mystik Dan has earned a winning share of $3.1 million from the Kentucky Derby purse.\n\nREQUIRED READING: Kentucky Derby payout, purse: How much money will winning horse make at Churchill Downs in 2024?\n\nMystik Dan's trainer, Kenny McPeek, became the first trainer since 1952 -- and the fourth ever -- to win both the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby in the same year: Thorpedo Anna won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday.\n\nFor Mystik Dan himself, it is the second time -- the other being the 2024 Southwest Stakes (Grade 3) on Feb. 3 at Oaklawn Park -- this year that he has won a race. Entering the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, Mystik Dan had a career earnings of $550,050.\n\nHere's what you need to know from how much Mystik Dan won in cash prizes by winning the 2024 Kentucky Derby:\n\nBy winning the 2024 Kentucky Derby, Mystik Dan -- with Brian Hernandez Jr. as his jockey -- won the winner's share: $3.1 million.\n\nMystik Dan won $3.1 million of the record-breaking $5 million winner chest after winning the 2024 Kentucky Derby.\n\nWith the win at Churchill Downs, Mystik Dan will now have the chance to become the 14th horse -- and first since Justify in 2018 -- to be a Triple Crown winner. The Preakness Stakes will take place on Saturday, May 18 at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore while the Belmont Stakes will take place on Saturday, June 8 at Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga Springs, New York. The Belmont Stakes is taking place at Saratoga Race Course this year as Belmont Park is currently undergoing renovations.\n\nUsing calculations from previous Kentucky Derby runnings by CNBC, Hernandez Jr. will take home 10% of the winning $3.1 million winning payout -- or $500,000.\n\nNote: The 10% percentage payout for the winning jockey of the Kentucky Derby is when the purse was $3 million. It remains unclear if that percentage will increase under the new purse number for 2024.\n\nThe Run for Roses purse for this year is a record-breaking $5 million, which is an increase of $2 million from what it was from 2019-2023.\n\n\"These record purse increases are a symbol of the health of horse racing in Kentucky,\" CEO of Churchill Downs Incorporated Bill Carstanjen said in a statement.\n\nHere's the full prize breakdown of the top five finishers at the Kentucky Derby:\n\nMystik Dan had a 20/1 odd per CBS Sports to win the Kentucky Derby, which tied for sixth best among {"uri": "8111773032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:26:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:26:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:23:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/happened-fierceness-west-saratoga-other-021950024.html", "title": "What happened to Fierceness, West Saratoga and all the other 2024 Kentucky Derby also-rans?", "body": "The finish of the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby was worthy of the Run for the Roses historic milestone.\n\nMystik Dan held off a late charge from Sierra Leone and Forever Young to win in a photo finish after going off at 18-1 odds. Mystik Dan gave Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek his first Kentucky Derby victory and gave McPeek the first Derby-Kentucky Oaks double for a trainer since 1952.\n\nWhat happened to everybody else in the field? Here's a look.\n\nWith Mystik Dan leading at the final turn, Blue Grass Stakes winner Sierra Leone, who was 17th at the first turn, and Forever Young, who was in the middle of the pack early, made a late charge from the outside. That charge came just short with a photo finish confirming Mystik Dan had just edged out Sierra Leone.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" Sierra Leone's trainer, Chad Brown, said. \"But he's a tremendous horse, nearly undefeated. I'm just so lucky to have him, so proud of his effort today.\n\n\"He did what we asked him to do, just came up a little bit short. (I didn't think I won) watching it live, but then when they started showing the slo-mo, I thought maybe this could be a dead heat because I got a great bob. I just wasn't in front.\"\n\nForever Young finished third, just missing becoming the first Japan-bred horse to win the Derby.\n\nBrad Cox-trained Catching Freedom took a similar path to Mystik Dan, emerging from the pack along the rail in the final turn but was passed down the stretch by Sierra Leone and Forever Young.\n\n\"Overall I was very happy with Catching Freedom's effort,\" Cox said. \"I really was and the ride Flavien (Prat) gave him. We'll regroup, not sure where we'll land.\"\n\nT O Password, the other Japan-bred horse in the field, was never in contention for the win but made a late charge to finish fifth.\n\n\"He didn't break well,\" jockey Kazushi Kimura said. \"This was his third time running and he was in a new country. He probably wasn't 100% mature. Today he finished up strong. I hope the horse can stay for the Preakness.\"\n\nFlorida Derby winner Fierceness, the 3-1 race favorite, jumped out of the gate but recovered to be among a four-wide pack leading at the first turn. Fierceness was still in third with four furlongs to go.\n\nAfter Mystik Dan made his charge to the lead along the inside rail in the final turn, Fierceness faded, finishing 15th.\n\n\"He had the hop at the start, and we kind of had to hustle a little more than we wanted to,\" trainer Todd Pletcher said. \"Got some pressure on both sides coming by the eighth pole. ... Finally got to the position we wanted, but (jockey) Johnny (Velazquez) said he was a little bit too geared up at that point.\"\n\nJust Steel, Epic Ride and Track Phantom helped set the early pace alongside Fierceness but all finished out of contention. Track Phantom was 11th, Epic Ride was 14th and Just Steel, who is trained by D. Wayne Lukas, was 17th.\n\n\"I was on the lead for a while,\" Track Phantom's jockey, Joel Rosario, said. \"He ran his race but we couldn't hang in there. He did his best.\"\n\nJockey Keith Asmussen said Just Steel was squeezed leaving the gate, and Lukas said the early pace was too fast.\n\n\"It was probably a little too fast for the opening quarter-mile,\" Epic Ride's jockey, Adam Beschizza, said. \"I was a little too aggressive going past the wire. It was a rough, busy race. I was able to keep it uninterrupted for the most for him. It's just probably a bit too far.\"\n\nSanta Anita Derby-winner Stronghold was fourth heading into the final turn but finished seventh, just behind Wood Memorial winner Resilience. Honor Marie, who was last at the first turn, finished eighth.\n\n\"My race was over coming out of the gate,\" Honor Marie's jockey, Ben Curtis, said. \"I got speared from both sides, I lost an iron and had to put it back in. He was nearly down on his head but I gave him time to pick himself up. He didn't get the smoothest first quarter of a mile and I just let him float around a bit after that. Then I took to the inside because I didn't want to give away any more ground. He paid for the early exertion but he ran a credible race.\"\n\nEndlessly and Dornoch rounded out the top 10.\n\n\"He had a very bad trip,\" Dornoch's trainer, Danny Gargan, said. \"He was eliminated early. He got very tired. I'm disappointed in the way he ran today.\"\n\nWest Saratoga, whose trainer Larry Demeritte became the first Black trainer to saddle a horse in the Derby since 1989, finished 11th.\n\nDomestic Product (12th), Society Man (16th), Grand Mo the First (18th), Catalytic (19th) and Just a Touch (20th) were never really in the mix.\n\nMystik Dan wins historic 2024 Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish at Churchill Downs\n\nKentucky Derby 2024 complete order of finish and payoffs at Churchill Downs\n\nSee the best photos, videos from 2024 Kentucky Derby: Mystik Dan's win, fashion, celebrities\n\nOwner of Kentucky Derby 2024 winner Mystik Dan dedicates victory to his late father\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr., long an underappreciated jockey, rides an unforgettable Kentucky Derby", {"uri": "8112677881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "18:29:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T18:29:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:26:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.si.com/fannation/rodeo/news/longshot-wins-historic-kentucky-derby-thrilling-photo-finish-laura9", "title": "Longshot Wins Historic 150th Kentucky Derby in Thrilling Photo Finish", "body": "The unpredictable nature of horse racing showed up at the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby where a longshot took the win.\n\nThe 150th running of the Kentucky Derby came down to the wire. Literally. In one of the most dramatic finishes in the race's history, Mystic Dan crossed the line just a nose in front of his competition.\n\nIn what will, no doubt, be a Derby to be remembered and talked about for years, the 16-1 longshot, Mystic Dan, emerged the victor in a field of very qualified thoroughbreds. In what seemed like a very long time to determine, officials had to go to the photo finish to announce the winner.\n\nChurchill Downs held a record breaking crowd of over 156,000 spectators all holding their breath for the final determination of the winner.\n\nMystic Dan had to hold off Sierra Leone (5-1) and Forever Young (6-1) who were having a battle of their own coming down to the wire.\n\nTrained by Kenneth McPeek, Mystik Dan's victory was particularly special as McPeek became the first trainer since 1952 to win both the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks in the same weekend, with Thorpedo Anna winning the Oaks on Friday. Jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. piloted Mystik Dan to victory, delivering a masterful ride that showcased his horse's abilities.\n\nFierceness (7-2) who was the clear favorite and had shown the ability to win finished in a disappointing position 15 when the race was over. The beautiful bay colt came out strong and led the field in the turn for home but faded.\n\nMystic Dan did exaclty the opposite. When the crowd came around the final turn, Hernandez found an opening along the rail and took it. From that point on, the horse surged and found new gears.\n\nSierra Leone and Forever Young mounted a fierce challenge on the outside, but Mystik Dan held on gamely to win by a nose in one of the closest finishes in Kentucky Derby history.\n\nThe result was not without controversy, as the stewards reviewed the finish before declaring Mystik Dan the official winner. The delay only added to the drama, with Hernandez describing the wait as \"the longest few minutes of my life.\" When the result was finally announced, Hernandez was overcome with emotion, saying, \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nLooking ahead, Mystik Dan will now aim to capture the second leg of the Triple Crown at the Preakness Stakes on May 18. If he can continue his winning ways, he will be well on his way to etching his name in the annals of horse racing history alongside legends like Secretariat, Seattle Slew, and American Pharoah.", {"uri": "8112712345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:06:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:06:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T19:05:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others-leave-questions-for-preakness/article_6d23ef4d-d04a-5dde-87bb-ea7643b8f825.html", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "Trainer Kenneth McPeek celebrates with his family after riding Mystik, with jockey Dan Brian Hernandez Jr. won the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "gary_b_graves@eagletribune.com", "name": "Gary B. {"uri": "2024-05-345293825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:20:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:20:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:19:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://gephardtdaily.com/sports/mystik-dan-wins-kentucky-derby-in-wild-three-way-photo-finish/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins Kentucky Derby in wild, three-way photo finish", "body": "May 4 (UPI) -- Mystik Dan held on through the final yards to win a wild, three-way battle to the wire in Saturday's 150th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs, with Blue Grass Stakes winner Sierra Leone second and Japan's Forever Young third.\n\nThird in the Arkansas Derby in his last start, Mystik Dan got the jump on the field with an inside move at the top of the stretch and opened up a daylight lead with a furlong to run.\n\nBut the two main rivals, bumping and grinding, kept coming, and it took the photo finish camera to separate them at the finish.\n\nLouisiana Derby winner Catching Freedom finished fourth and Japan's international racing image was burnished as its second entry, T O Password, reported fifth.\n\nMystik Dan, a Goldencents colt, is trained by Kenny McPeek and was ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nThe trainer-jockey combination also won the Grade I Kentucky Oaks a day earlier with Thorpedo Anna. It was only the fourth time in the 150-year history of the races that a trainer has saddled the winners of both the Derby and Oaks in the same year.\n\n\"I'm really proud of that,\" McPeek said. \"But what are you gonna do? You only pick one horse at a time.\"\n\nThe finish was so tight that Hernandez thought, but didn't know, that Mystik Dan had won.\n\n\"The longest two minutes I've spent in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up,\" he said. \"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won, so it was quite a rush to sit there and wait for it.\n\n\"I always told myself I was never going to step into the Derby winner's circle until I could do it on the back of a horse. Now, to be able to live that dream ... I was a 6-year-old kid, riding my bike around my grandparents' farm, telling them all that I was going to win the Kentucky Derby some day -- and here we are.\"\n\nStarting from the No. 3 gate in a field of 20 enabled Mystik Dan to take a forward position in the race, avoiding the traffic issues that often prevent the best horses from reaching competition.\n\nWhen the field swung out of the stretch turn, Hernandez cut things so close, he said, that his left boot actually scraped the rail.\n\n\"When we cut the corner, I thought, 'Man, we have a chance to win the Kentucky Derby,'\" he said.\n\nHis chances were helped during the stretch battle as Sierra Leone lugged in, bumping repeatedly with Forever Young. Whether the contact cost either of them the noses by which they lost, racing will never know.\n\nSierra Leone came into the race with three wins from four starts, and finished second by a nose in the Grade II Remsen Stakes in December in the other. Trainer Chad Brown bemoaned his missed chance but praised the Gun Runner colt.\n\n\"He's a tremendous horse. We're so proud to have him. He just came up a little short,\" Brown said. \"The Derby gods can be cruel sometimes. Some trainers never win one.\"\n\nForever Young's performance was, if anything, even more impressive. He won his first two starts in Japan, and then traveled to Saudi Arabia, where he was fully extended through the stretch to win the Group III Saudi Derby.\n\nHe followed that with a victory a month later in the Group II Saudi Derby in Dubai, again using a relentless stretch run to catch the leader, South American-bred Auto Bahn.\n\nCatching Freedom's fourth-place finish followed the Louisiana Derby victory and a third, behind Sierra Leone, in the Grade II Risen Star, also at Fair Grounds in New Orleans.\n\nThe surprise of the day was T O Password. The Copano Rickey colt had only two previous starts, both in Japan. The second of those was by a head in the Fukuryu Stakes at Nakayama Racecourse, the final and deciding leg of the \"Japan Road to the Kentucky Derby.\"\n\nHe, too, might have fared even better at Churchill Downs but for a slow start and traffic issues.\n\nThe Triple Crown series now shifts focus to Pimlico Racecourse in Baltimore, where the Preakness Stakes awaits May 18.\n\nMystik Dan's part-owner, Lance Gasaway, clutching the gold Derby trophy, said, \"We'll discuss it.\"\n\nThe Preakness most likely will include some talented \"new shooters,\" including horses trained by Bob Baffert, who is banned from Churchill Downs and unable to contest the Derby for a third straight year.", "source": {"uri": "gephardtdaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gephardt Daily"}, "authors": [{"uri": "united_press_international@gephardtdaily.com", "name": "United Press International", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345344207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:36:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:36:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:39:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/mark-story/article288285875.html", "title": "Brian Hernandez Jr., long an underappreciated jockey, rides an unforgettable Kentucky Derby", "body": "Click below to view more coverage from the Lexington Herald-Leader and Kentucky.com at the 150th Kentucky Derby on May 4 at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nAs a native of Lafayette, Louisiana, who has largely spent his jockey career as a regular on the Kentucky circuit, Brian Hernandez Jr. felt an obvious connection with Calvin Borel.\n\nSo when 18-1 shot Mystik Dan, the horse Hernandez was to ride in the historic 150th Kentucky Derby, drew the third post position, Hernandez immediately thought of Borel.\n\nIn an improbable late career surge, Borel -- a native of St. Martin Parish, Louisiana, who also rode regularly in the commonwealth -- scored three Kentucky Derby victories, utilizing a rail-hugging, ground-saving style to claim the last two of those wins in the 2009 Derby aboard Mine That Bird and the 2010 Run for the Roses on Super Saver.\n\n\"With Mystik Dan being in the three hole, I watched a couple of (Borel's) rides there between Super Saver and Mine That Bird,\" Hernandez said. \"I said, 'You know what? We're going to roll the dice.'\"\n\nDelivering a \"Calvin Bo-Rail\" special, Hernandez made a bold move along the rail in the final turn that, ultimately, allowed Mystik Dan to get through to the lead and save just enough ground to prevail at the wire in a scintillating three-horse charge to the finish with Sierra Leone and Forever Young.\n\nWith a Churchill Downs crowed of 156,710 roaring, the three horses crossed the finish line almost locked in stride.\n\nUltimately, a photo finish showed Mystik Dan a nose ahead of Sierra Leone, who was a nose ahead of third-place Forever Young, the previously unbeaten Japanese horse. The winning time was 2:03.34.\n\nThe three-way photo to determine the victor was the first in a Kentucky Derby since 1947. It was a finish worthy of the 150th renewal of North America's marquee horse race -- and the ride by Hernandez proved every bit worthy of such a historic moment.\n\nOnce Mystik Dan claimed the lead entering the stretch, Hernandez said he had his head down, riding, and did not realize until the final jumps of the race that there were closers to his horse's outside charging hard to take the Kentucky Derby away.\n\nOnce the finish line had been crossed, Hernandez said he asked an outrider if Mystik Dan had won. The reply was probably, but it was not certain pending the photo.\n\nThe wait for Derby certainty \"was the longest two minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said.\n\nThe victory by trainer Kenny McPeek's Mystik Dan made Hernandez a Kentucky Derby champion in his fifth try at the race. In four previous Derbys, Hernandez had not finished better than eighth.\n\n\"It's unbelievable,\" Hernandez said. \"It still hasn't sunk in yet.\"\n\nEleven years ago, the 38-year-old Hernandez had another signature moment on one of horse racing's grandest stages. On the jockey's 27th birthday, he guided Fort Larned to victory in the 2012 Breeders' Cup Classic at Santa Anita.\n\nYet, for whatever reason, that victory did not elevate Hernandez's career to the elite level of racing.\n\nToiling mostly on the Kentucky racing circuit, Hernandez's great patron became McPeek. The trainer, a Tates Creek High School and University of Kentucky graduate, has long given Hernandez chances on his best horses. In 2021, Hernandez won four stakes races at Keeneland -- all on horses trained by McPeek.\n\n\"Well, the older you get, I don't get enamored with all the, I guess you could say, big-namers,\" McPeek said of more famous jockeys. \"With Brian and his agent (Frank Bernis), there's nothing complicated about either one of them. It's all business, business, business -- and there's no drama. And I like 'no drama.'\"\n\nOn Saturday, Hernandez repaid McPeek's faith.\n\nThe key point in the race came in the final turn. A tiring Track Phantom drifted out slightly. Hernandez asked Mystik Dan to push through a small hole along the rail.\n\n\"When I called upon him to hit that spot that I needed right before we straightened, to kind of get a little separation on the deep, deep closers, he did it,\" Hernandez said of Mystik Dan. \"He jumped off quickly and we were able to get that separation, and that made the difference of them not getting to him (at) the wire.\"\n\nAs the winning jockey in Kentucky Derby 150, Hernandez etched his name in race lore.\n\nHe joins Oliver Lewis (first Derby in 1875), J.D. Mooney (50th Derby in 1924) and Angel Cordero Jr. (100th Run for the Roses in 1974) as the winning jockeys in numerically significant Kentucky Derbys.\n\nIt was the weekend of a lifetime for the McPeek-Hernandez duo. The jockey and trainer also combined to win Friday's Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nThat makes Hernandez the eighth jockey all-time to win the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks in the same year. He is the first to do so since -- you guessed it -- Borel (Rachel Alexandra in the Oaks, Mine That Bird in the Derby) in 2009.\n\nAll it took for Hernandez to win the Kentucky Derby and put his name on several historic lists was a daring move along the rail that would have done Borel proud.\n\nSaid McPeek: \"Brian, his ride, was the difference today in winning.\"", "source": {"uri":
