(AP) -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a three-horse photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone by a nose with Forever Young third in the tightest finish since 1996 on Saturday.\n\nSent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nAdvertisementAdvertisement\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone wore the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nSports Roundup\n\nGet the latest D-FW sports news, analysis, scores and more.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and the bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952 and the fourth overall.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim {"uri": "8112039448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:55:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:55:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:54:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/horse-racing/kentucky-derby-drama-mystik-dan-32738469", "title": "Kentucky Derby drama as Mystik Dan wins 150th edition in three-way photo finish", "body": "Mystik Dan held on by a nose in a dramatic three-way photo finish to grab Kentucky Derby glory for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nSierra Leone finished strongly but could not quite give his Coolmore owners compensation for City Of Troy's disappointing display in the 2,000 Guineas, while Japanese raider Forever Young was another nose back in third.\n\nBen Curtis, champion apprentice in Ireland back in 2010, finished eighth on Honor Marie, while Frankie Dettori was 16th of the 20 runners on Society Man.\n\nThe 150th 'Run for the Roses' took place on a 10-furlong dirt track described as running fast after a glorious day in Louisville had dried up Friday night's rain.\n\nA crowd of 156,710 packed into Churchill Downs let out an almighty roar, as Track Phantom took an early lead, flanked by Just Steel and the favourite Fierceness.\n\nThat trio held sway until the turn for home, when Mystik Dan burst through on the inside rail and quickly stormed into a three-length lead.\n\nSierra Leone and Forever Young fought hard to claw back the deficit and were closing in on the leader with every stride, but the finishing line came just in time for Mystik Dan.\n\nIt completed a memorable double for the successful trainer and jockey, who had won the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna 24 hours earlier, and McPeek told NBC Sports: \"Brian just did an amazing job - just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride.\n\n\"The draw (stall three) helped us from the beginning but Brian is amazing, probably one of the most underrated riders in racing, but not anymore, right!\"\n\nMystik Dan's jockey Brian Hernandez Jr celebrates with the trophy\n\nHernandez admitted the long wait for the result to be confirmed was agonising, stating: \"This is just unbelievable, that was the longest few minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to put that number up.\n\n\"It was exciting when we hit the front but I wasn't sure we had won, so it was quite a rush to stay there and wait for it.\n\n\"This is a lifetime achievement. This goes to our whole family, we've all worked all our lives for this and it's hard to describe what kind of feeling this is.\n\n\"I always told myself I was never going to step into the Derby winner's circle until I can do it on the back of a horse, so to be able to live that dream from when I was a six-year-old kid on my grandparents' farm, telling them all I was going to the Kentucky Derby one day - and here we are.\n\n\"It surely makes the last 20 years of getting up at five in the morning and finding horses to ride and finding people to give us opportunities all come to fruition on days like yesterday and today.\n\nHernandez Jr was understandably delighted following the result\n\n\"It's hard to put into words and it's probably going to take about a week to sink in before we say hey, we won the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks in the same year.\"\n\nTrainer Chad Brown said of runner-up Sierra Leone: \"To get beaten a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one, but that's professional sports and at this level you're going to win some and lose some, and often times it's going to come down to a matter of inches.\n\n\"He's a tremendous horse, he's nearly undefeated and hasn't lost by much in both of his defeats and I'm just so lucky to have him and so proud of his effort today.\n\n\"He did everything we asked him to do and it came up just a little bit short, but hats off to the winner, and Ken McPeek having the Derby and Oaks winners, to him and his team, they really did a fabulous job.\n\n\"The Derby gods can be cruel sometimes, making you wait, and some trainers never have one, so if I'm lucky enough to be back in the same position, I'll be grateful for that.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": It's also a first victory for jockey, Brian Hernandez Jr., according to The Courier Journal.\n\nWho owns Mystik Dan?\n\nMystik Dan is owned by Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing (Brent Gasaway), Daniel Hamby.\n\nWho is Mystik Dan's trainer?\n\n2024 Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan is trained by Kenny McPeek.\n\nWhat jockey won Derby 150?\n\nMystik Dan's jockey is Brian Hernandez Jr. His best Derby finish prior to this year's victory was eighth place with McCraken in 2017.\n\nHow much is Mystik Dan worth?\n\nPrior to his Derby appearance, Mystik Dan's career earnings were just below $650,000.\n\nWho was favored to win the 2024 Kentucky Derby?\n\nHeaded into the big race, the favored horses were Sierra Leone and Fierceness, as previously reported by The Courier Journal. {"uri": "8113598695", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:28:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:28:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:27:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.whas11.com/article/sports/horses/triple/derby/plans-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-preakness/417-00e0da52-89e9-4f9c-8a6b-7edd98c9e347", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn at Churchill Downs. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nTrainer Bob Baffert has told Pimlico officials that he is sending Muth and Imagination to Baltimore for the Preakness.\n\nRELATED: 'It's unbelievable': Kentucky Derby shares adorable photo of then 6-year-old Brian Hernandez Jr. who became winning jockey\n\nRELATED: Kentucky Derby 150 | Record-breaking number of bets placed\n\nMuth won the Arkansas Derby on March 30, when Mystik Dan finished third. Imagination was second behind Stronghold in the Santa Anita Derby on April 6.\n\nBaffert has won the Preakness eight times, including last year with National Treasure.\n\nSaratoga in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final race for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1 1/4 miles, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many horses and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run in the Belmont.\n\n\"He's a real laidback horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nTrainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"", "source": {"uri": "whas11.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "whas11.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", {"uri": "2024-05-345726104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "15:40:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T15:40:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T15:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/john-clay/article288324840.html", "title": "Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan continuing on to the Preakness far from a sure thing", "body": "When the officials from Pimlico Race Course called Kenny McPeek on Sunday morning to offer an official invitation to the Preakness Stakes, the trainer had but one question.\n\n\"Can I bring my dog?\" McPeek asked with a grin.\n\nWhile McPeek got the go-ahead to bring his yellow Labrador Sonny to Baltimore, the trainer was noncommittal on whether Kentucky Derby 150 winner Mystik Dan will be running the second jewel of the Triple Crown on May 18.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness. Not yet,\" McPeek said after the phone call. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. We skipped the Rebel (Stakes) because it was back too quick, as well. ... It'll be one of those (decisions) where we take it up to the last minute.\"\n\nMystik Dan did leave some feed in his tub Saturday night after winning a three-horse photo finish with runner-up Sierra Leone and third-place finisher Forever Young.\n\nCoupled with Thorpedo Anna's win in Friday's Kentucky Oaks, McPeek became the first trainer to execute the Oaks/Derby double since the legendary Ben Jones accomplished the feat for Calumet Farm in 1952.\n\n\"An overnight sensation, 40 years later,\" McPeek joked Sunday.\n\nSaturday was a win for the good guys. The 61-year-old McPeek is a Tates Creek High School and University of Kentucky graduate who admits he spent a good portion of his time in the library at the UK agricultural school pouring over the bloodline histories in the BloodHorse and the old Thoroughbred Record.\n\nHis first Kentucky Derby horse, Tejano Run, finished second in 1995. He won the 2002 Belmont with Sarava and the 2022 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver. He was 0-for-9 in the Derby, however, including 2002 when he saddled the favorite, Harlan's Holiday. After a seventh-place finish, the owners moved the colt to a different trainer.\n\nMystik Dan was a different colt, however. Outside of the post-time favorite Fierceness, Mystik Dan had run the only triple-digit Beyer Speed Figure -- 101 for his 8-length win in the Grade 3 Southwest Stakes -- in the Derby field. Even a third-place finish in the Arkansas Derby didn't dampen McPeek's enthusiasm about his Derby chances.\n\n\"I've thought for three weeks he was going to win the race,\" he said Sunday. \"I had a calm about it. I just did.\"\n\nHe again credited the terrific ride from jockey Brian Hernandez, a regular on McPeek's horses. Out of the No. 3 post position, Hernandez guided Mystik Dan to victory along the Churchill rail. In fact, Hernandez's boots even sported rail paint to prove it.\n\n\"We don't win the race without the job that Brian did,\" McPeek said.\n\nThe Preakness is also a different deal. These days, connections rarely run their horses in races two weeks apart. After Mystik Dan broke his maiden with a win at Churchill Downs on Nov. 12, McPeek ran the colt back in an optional claiming race at Churchill on Nov. 25, where Mystik Dan finished fifth.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us,\" McPeek said. \"If he's not in the feed tub, he won't run. And he ran hard yesterday. So we'll see.\"\n\nForever Young and Sierra Leone won't be in Baltimore. Forever Young must return to his home country of Japan before May 15 or be quarantined for three months. Trainer Chad Brown said Sunday that Sierra Leone will be pointed toward the Belmont Stakes at Saratoga, where the race will be run at a mile-and-a-quarter while Belmont Park is under renovation.\n\nMcPeek is headed to Saratoga, as well. He said he will leave for New York on Monday to set up his barn at the historic track.\n\nAfter finally winning the Kentucky Derby, how hard would it be to not run Mystik Dan back in the Preakness?\n\n\"I don't think it would be hard,\" McPeek said. \"I'll talk to (the owners) and the team here and like I said, we're going to let the horse tell us. If I don't think he's right and ready, we'll just wait for the Belmont.\"", "source": {"uri": "kentucky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lexington Herald Leader"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112139827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:33:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:33:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:32:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.capitalgazette.com/2024/05/05/kentucky-derby-takeaways-mystik-dan/", "title": "Kentucky Derby 2024: Three takeaways from Mystik Dan's thrilling victory", "body": "Mystik Dan's nose reached the wire first in a heart-stoppingly close Kentucky Derby, giving Kentucky-based trainer Kenny McPeek his first win in the first leg of the Triple Crown. Here are three takeaways from a thrilling race.\n\nHe was a difficult horse to read, because his one indisputably great performance came on a muddy track in the Southwest Stakes. When he finished third after a tough trip in the Arkansas Derby, he became a bit of an afterthought.\n\nBut his Beyer speed figure from the Southwest, which accounted for the track conditions and competition, told us he was potentially one of the fastest horses in this 3-year-old class and a tasty betting choice at 18-1 odds for the Derby.\n\nWhat a way to earn a defining victory, in the closest three-horse photo finish at a Derby since 1947.\n\n\"Ooh, that's tight. Look at that,\" McPeek said when the final margins hit the board at Churchill Downs.\n\nHe thought Mystik Dan had nosed ahead of Sierra Leone and Forever Young with a final bob of his head, but until he saw the result up there, he wasn't taking anything for granted.\n\nDerby favorite Fierceness seemed to get the setup he needed, breaking cleanly and stalking just off the lead as the race proceeded at a quick pace. When it was time to empty his tank, however, Fierceness flashed none of the speed that carried him to dominant victories in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile and Florida Derby. He fell back to 15th by the end.\n\nInto that vacuum surged Mystik Dan, holding a strong, ground-saving position along the rail under jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. Then came the twin charge from mighty Sierra Leone and undefeated Japanese contender Forever Young.\n\nPerhaps no one expected Mystik Dan to hold off those more highly touted horses, but that he did, making good on the promise he'd shown three months earlier in the Arkansas slop.\n\nTraffic was always going to be Sierra Leone's greatest enemy.\n\nThe huge-striding colt had never run a bad race, but he's a late charger, and that's a tough style for the Derby, with 19 other horses clogging the path to victory.\n\nSure enough, when jockey Tyler Gaffalione went to make his move, he had to hold Sierra Leone up and swing him wide around a wall of horses. Once he got going, he locked into a rugged duel with Forever Young as they both bore down on Mystik Dan. After all that extra running and bumping, Sierra Leone, the 9-2 second choice, still came just a nose short.\n\n\"It's a tough one, but it's professional sports. Sometimes it's a game of inches,\" said the runner-up's trainer Chad Brown, who's still looking for the first Derby win of his wildly successful career.\n\n\"The Derby gods can be cruel at times, making you wait,\" he said.\n\nThere's no question, however, about the quality of Brown's horse. Whether confronted by traffic, mud or his own reluctance to go in the starting gate, Sierra Leone always finishes with a mighty kick. He's the one star in this class you can set your watch to, and it's hard to imagine he won't send Brown to the winner's circle in some big race later this year.\n\nOwner Lance Gasaway did not immediately commit Mystik Dan to the second leg of the Triple Crown, saying, \"We'll discuss it.\"\n\nWe can no longer count that trip as a given after 2022 Derby winner Rich Strike skipped the Preakness, sending another strong signal that the Triple Crown calendar -- three races in five weeks -- is out of step with modern training practices.\n\nAssuming the Gasaways and McPeek take the traditional path, however, they'll likely see a familiar foe.\n\nMuth beat Mystik Dan in the Arkansas Derby, and he would have been in the Kentucky Derby if Baffert was not still suspended from Churchill Downs because of Medina Spirit's 2021 medication violation. Owner Amr Zedan sued unsuccessfully to get his horse, and Baffert, into the first leg of the Triple Crown.\n\nInstead, Baffert will seemingly try to repeat his formula from last year, when he beat Derby champion Mage with a fresher horse, National Treasure, to win his eighth Preakness. Baffert also has Imagination, runner-up in the Santa Anita Derby, pointed toward the Preakness.\n\nWe'll have plenty of time to dissect the successes and controversies that have made Baffert the dominant figure in recent Triple Crown history. But from a pure competitive standpoint, the potential showdown between his horses and Mystik Dan gives the Preakness an intriguing hook.\n\nMuth could well be favored in a race that has favored fresher contenders in recent years. The story would be richer still if Sierra Leone, Forever Young or both show up in Baltimore.\n\nMcPeek won the pandemic-delayed 2020 Preakness with the great filly Swiss Skydiver, out-dueling Baffert's Derby winner, Authentic, but he ruled out Kentucky Oaks winning filly Thorpedo Anna as a possible Preakness entrant.", "source": {"uri": "capitalgazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8111704430", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:26:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:26:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:25:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/horseracing/s-3231699", "title": "Mystik Dan wins historic 2024 Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Mystik Dan won a three-way photo finish over Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a historic 150th edition of the Grade 1, $5 million Kentucky Derby from a full field of 20 horses on Saturday night beneath the Twin Spires at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nMystik Dan, saddled by Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek and ridden by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., provided the first combination Oaks-Derby double since 1952 with their narrow win.\n\nThe McPeek-Hernandez duo teamed up to win the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna on Friday evening at Churchill. The last jockey to do the Oaks-Derby double was Calvin Borel in 2009 with Rachel Alexandra and Mine That Bird. The last trainer to do the double was Ben Jones in 1952 with Real Delight and Hill Gail.\n\nMcPeek is only the fourth-ever trainer to do the Oaks-Derby double in the same year.\n\nAfter Friday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track and rain threatened throughout Saturday, the Derby was run over a fast main track at Churchill.\n\nIt didn't matter. McPeek and Hernandez won in both conditions at Churchill Downs this weekend.\n\nCatching Freedom finished in fourth. T O Password (JPN) finished in fifth. Both of the Japenese horses in this year's race placed in the top five.\n\nA $2 exacta in the Derby with Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone paid $258.56. A $1 trifecta with Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young (JPN) paid $1,113.84.\n\nMcPeek was previously 0 for 9 in the Derby, with his best finish being second with Tejano Run in 1995.\n\nHernandez had been 0 for 4 in the Derby, with his best finish being eighth with McCraken in 2017.\n\n...continued", "source": {"uri": "arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ArcaMax"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Louisville, Kentucky"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"uri": "8111829129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:51:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:51:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:50:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1751861-20240505.htm", "title": "Photo finish determines winner of Kentucky Derby - RTHK", "body": "It was a three-way thriller to the wire in the 150th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.\n\nMystik Dan, ridden by Brian Hernandez, held on late to win a three-way photo finish by just a nose over Sierra Leone and Forever Young to capture the first leg of the Triple Crown on Saturday night in front of 156,710 fans.\n\n\"It's like a dream come true,\" Hernandez said.\n\nSent off at odds of 18-1, Mystik Dan made the turn for home in front and stayed on the rail with Forever Young just to his outside and Sierra Leone on the far outside.\n\nThere was a gasp from the crowd as the three colts hit the finish line. It took several minutes for the racing stewards to look at the finish line photo and declare Mystik Dan the winner.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- which is the closest margin you can have in horse racing -- and it was the first nose decision since Grindstone edged out Cavonnier in the 1996 Derby. (Reuters)", "source": {"uri": "news.rthk.hk", "dataType": "news", "title": "news.rthk.hk"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": {"uri": "8114198165", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:17:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:17:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:16:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/down-unforgettable-2024-kentucky-derby-171213239.html", "title": "Who is up and who is down after an unforgettable 2024 Kentucky Derby", "body": "Who is up and who is down after an unforgettable 150th running of the Kentucky Derby:\n\n\u25aa Up: Kenny McPeek. For the veteran trainer from Lexington, last weekend permanently altered how his career will be viewed.\n\nWhen McPeek's Thorpedo Anna won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday, followed by the trainer's Mystik Dan claiming the Derby in a three-horse photo finish Saturday with Sierra Leone (second) and Forever Young (third), it pushed the Tates Creek High School graduate and University of Kentucky alum into newly rarefied air for a trainer.\n\nMcPeek became the first trainer to claim the Oaks/Derby double in the same year since Ben Jones, the iconic Calumet Farm conditioner, did it in 1952 with Real Delight (Oaks) and Hill Gail (Derby).\n\nWith Mystik Dan's Derby win following victories by the McPeek-trained Sarava in the 2002 Belmont Stakes and Swiss Skydiver in the 2020 Preakness, the trainer has now achieved the \"career Triple Crown.\"\n\n\"Goosebumps,\" McPeek said Saturday, when asked to reflect on the magnitude of his latest achievements.\n\n\u25aa Down: Chad Brown. The Kentucky Derby gods continue to torment Brown.\n\nWith the hard-closing Sierra Leone edged out of victory by Mystik Dan's nose, the trainer is now 0-for-8 in the Derby with two second-place finishes, a third, a fourth and a fifth.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one\" to take, Brown said Saturday.\n\n\u25aa Up: Brian Hernandez Jr. Long more accomplished at his craft than celebrated in his profession, the Kentucky-based jockey rewarded the faith of his longtime patron, Kenny McPeek, by riding Thorpedo Anna and Mystik Dan to their victories.\n\nThe gutty, ground-saving ride along the rail by the 38-year-old Hernandez on Mystik Dan was all but universally seen as the difference between winning and losing the Kentucky Derby. Afterward McPeek jokingly implored the media not to write about how impressive a ride it had been so other trainers won't hire Hernandez away.\n\n\"But I guess that cat is out of the bag, isn't it?\" McPeek said.\n\n\u25aa Down: John Velzaquez. When the veteran jockey booted the gritty Medina Spirit to victory in the 2021 Kentucky Derby, it moved Velazquez to an elite level in Derby history.\n\nThat victory made \"Johnny V.,\" only the fourth jockey with at least four Kentucky Derby wins, joining legends Eddie Arcaro and Bill Hartack (five each) and Bill Shoemaker (four).\n\nSubsequently, through no fault of Velazquez, the jockey lost his fourth Derby win when a postrace test showed a banned substance in the system of the Bob Baffert-trained Medina Spirit and the horse was disqualified.\n\nAt age 52, the clock is ticking on opportunities for Velazquez to \"get back\" the fourth Kentucky Derby win that he had taken away.\n\nThat had to make this year's Derby an acute disappointment for Velazquez. Riding race-time favorite Fierceness, Velazquez came home a disappointing 15th after sitting third at the mile pole in the 1 1/4-mile race.\n\n\"When I let (Fierceness) go, he just didn't have it,\" Velazquez said.\n\n\u25aa Up: Churchill Downs management. The 150th Kentucky Derby was apparently a smash hit on multiple fronts.\n\nNBC Sports announced Sunday that the 2024 Derby drew an average audience of 16.7 million viewers. According to NBC, it is the most-watched Kentucky Derby since the 1989 race averaged 18.5 million viewers.\n\nMeanwhile, Churchill Downs announced that $210.7 million was wagered on the Derby, the first time in history that figure went above $200 million.\n\nGiven those metrics, the controversial decision made by Churchill Downs Inc. to extend the original two-year suspension of trainer Bob Baffert related to the Medina Spirit disqualification to a third Kentucky Derby does not appear to have harmed the popularity of the event.\n\n\u25aa Down: Bob Baffert. Given the above figures, the two-time Triple Crown-winning trainer does not have much leverage in his interactions with Churchill Downs.\n\n\u25aa Up: Japan. Though the two Japanese horses who contested the 150th Kentucky Derby did not produce the breakthrough Triple Crown victory that race fans in Japan yearn for, they came close.\n\nThe previously unbeaten Forever Young fought gamely but was squeezed in the middle in the three-horse battle for the race win. Meanwhile, the less highly regarded Japanese horse in the Derby, T O Password, finished a respectable fifth.\n\nWith the recent success of Japanese horses in other major international races, it seems just a matter of time before the Triple Crown win barrier is breached.\n\n\u25aa Down: Martha Stewart. Given the honor of performing the \"Rider's Up\" call for the historically significant 150th Derby, the lifestyle guru and businesswoman nearly committed the verbal faux pas of referring to \"Kentucky\" as \"Connecticut.\"\n\n\"Racing fans from around the world, the city of Louisville and the Commonwealth of Conn -- Kentucky,\" Stewart said in her remarks.\n\nThe subsequent roasting Stewart took on the social media platform X was, I thought, out of proportion to her \"offense.\"\n\nNevertheless, given the magnitude of Derby 150, I think those who were asking why Churchill Downs did not have a celebrity of national import with direct ties to the state of Kentucky perform the \"Rider's Up\" call have a point.\n\nKentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan continuing on to the Preakness far from a sure thing\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr., long an underappreciated jockey, rides an unforgettable Kentucky Derby\n\nOwner of Kentucky Derby 2024 winner Mystik Dan dedicates victory to his late father\n\n'I believe in mojo.' Lexington trainer earns rare double in thrilling Derby photo finish.\n\nWhat happened to Fierceness, West Saratoga and all the other 2024 Kentucky Derby also-rans?\n\nMedia mogul Martha Stewart almost forgets home of Kentucky Derby ... it's not Connecticut!", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jockey", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jockey"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_trainer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Horse trainer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derby", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Derby"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Derby"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medina_Spirit", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Medina Spirit"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_(horse)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Bay (horse)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Belmont_Stakes", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "2002 Belmont Stakes"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swiss_Skydiver", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Swiss Skydiver"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_A._Jones", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ben A. {"uri": "2024-05-345344204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:37:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:37:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:40:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/john-clay/article288282370.html", "title": "'I believe in mojo.' Lexington trainer earns rare double in thrilling Derby photo finish.", "body": "Click below to view more coverage from the Lexington Herald-Leader and Kentucky.com at the 150th Kentucky Derby on May 4 at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nFor the 150th renewal, you could not have asked for a more thrilling Kentucky Derby.\n\nTrained by Lexingtonian Kenny McPeek, Mystik Dan edged hard-charging $2.3 million colt Sierra Leone and Japanese intruder Forever Young in a three-way photo finish by a nose (if that) to win a breathtaking Derby before 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nNot only did McPeek earn his first Kentucky Derby victory, in combination with Thorpedo Anna's win in the Kentucky Oaks on Friday, McPeek became the first trainer since the legendary Ben Jones in 1952 to pull off the Oaks/Derby double. Jones did it with Oaks winner Real Delight and Derby winner Hill Gail.\n\n\"Wow,\" said McPeek on Saturday when asked about the feat.\n\n\"For three weeks, I felt like we were going to win both races, I can't tell you why,\" said the trainer. \"I believe in mojo. I believe in positive energy and we had a lot of that.\"\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. became the first jockey to win both the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby since Calvin Borel in 2009 on Rachel Alexandra in the Oaks and Mine That Bird in the Derby.\n\nA homebred owned by Arkansas' Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing, Daniel Hamby III and Valley View Farm, Mystik Dan won in a time of 2:03 3/5. At odds of 18-1, he paid $39.22 to win, $16.32 to place and $10 to show. The son of Goldencents had won the Southwest Stakes by 8 lengths on a muddy track at Oaklawn on Feb. 3, but had finished third behind Muth and Just Steel in the Arkansas Derby at Oaklawn on May 30.\n\n\"I'm pinching myself, wondering if this is real,\" said Gasaway. \"You just won the biggest horse race in America. Who would have dreamed it.\"\n\nThe 61-year-old McPeek won the 2002 Belmont Stakes with Sarava and the 2020 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver, but was 0-for-9 in his home state's famous race. His best finish was second with Tejano Run all the way back in 1995.\n\nIt was a heartbreaking loss for the connections of Sierra Leone, who had won the Toyota Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland on April 6. With a deep closing running style, Sierra Leone made a strong move to the finish but came up a nose short.\n\n\"It's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"It's professional sport, when you're at this level you're going to win some and lose some and often times it's a game of inches.\"\n\nThe previously unbeaten Forever Young was attempting to be the first Japanese-bred to win the Kentucky Derby. In the middle between Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone, Forever Young finished third.\n\nSierra Leone paid $6.54 to place and $4.64 to show. Forever Young paid $5.58 to show. The $1 exacta of 3-2 paid $129.28.\n\nMorning-line and post-time favorite Fierceness, the 13 1/2-length winner of the Florida Derby, challenged for the lead for most of the race, but faded badly in the stretch. Owned by Mike Repole and trained by Todd Pletcher, Fierceness finished 15th.\n\nThe finish was a terrific ending to a terrific day that included Churchill showing off its new $200 million paddock for a group of celebrities including Kansas City Chiefs Super Bowl champion tight end and Taylor Swift boyfriend Travis Kelce, Martha Stewart (who nearly misspoke during the traditional \"Riders Up\" command by saying the \"Commonwealth of Connecticut\"), \"Tonight Show\" host Jimmy Fallon, new Kentucky basketball coach Mark Pope and now former UK basketball star Reed Sheppard, among others.\n\nFriday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track. The Churchill surface was listed as muddy for the opening races on Saturday, but had dried to a fast track with a temperature of 80 degrees by the 6:57 p.m. post time for the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThis was the third consecutive Kentucky Derby without trainer Bob Baffert, who has a record-tying six Derby victories to his credit, including a pair of Triple Crown winners (American Pharoah in 2015, Justify in 2018).\n\nThe California-based Baffert was initially suspended for two years after his trainee Medina Spirit hit the finish line first in the 2021 Kentucky Derby only to be disqualified after testing positive for Betamethasone, banned on race day. Last July, Churchill Downs, Inc. extended Baffert's suspension through 2024 for what it said was the trainer continuing \"to peddle a false narrative concerning the failed drug test of Medina Spirit.\"\n\nOwner Amr Zedan opted to stick with Baffert instead of transferring his star 3-year-old Muth to an eligible trainer. After winning the Arkansas Derby, Muth is being pointed to the May 18 Preakness Stakes in Baltimore. Zedan also owned Medina Spirit.\n\nBut this Kentucky Derby Day belonged to Mystik Dan and McPeek, the trainer who had earned his 2,000th victory as a trainer back in February. What to know about the long-shot champion of Kentucky Derby 2024", "body": "Mystik Dan has won the 150th Kentucky Derby, a surprise to many given he was largely overlooked leading up to the race.\n\nAlong with offering an exhilarating by-a-nose photo finish, the horse also has a local tie in that he's Kentucky bred and his trainer is a University of Kentucky graduate.\n\nHere's what you need to know about one dandy horse that claimed the blanket of red roses:\n\nMystik Dan went off at 18-1 odds at post time, edging forward to win by a nose in an electrifying photo finish.\n\nThe bay colt was bred in Kentucky and earned little attention going into Saturday's race. Most of the buzz centered on favorite Fierceness (3-1) and such top contenders as Sierra Leone (9/2), Forever Young (6-1), Catching Freedom (8-1) and others.\n\nStill, Mystik Dan was not to be dismissed, previously excelling on a sloppy track when he won the Southwest Stakes in February. He earned his first career win at Churchill Downs last November.\n\nMystik Dan was sired by Goldenscents, the dual Breeders' Cup Dirt Mile winner. His dam is Ma'am by Colonel John.\n\nPrior to his Kentucky Derby win Saturday, 38-year-old Brian Hernandez was winless on four Derby starts. The Louisiana native's best Derby finish was eighth on McCracken in 2017.\n\nMoments after Mystik Dan nudged his nose across the finish line Saturday, a breathless Hernandez talked about the \"rush\" of his exhilarating win. Winning the Kentucky Derby has been his dream since childhood, the Eclipse Award-winning jockey said.\n\n\"When I was a 6-year-old kid riding my bike around my grandparents' farm, telling them all I was going to win the Kentucky Derby one day, and here we are,\" Hernandez said.\n\nKenny McPeek, 61, is an Arkansas native with strong local ties: He's a graduate of both Tates Creek High School and the University of Kentucky.\n\nAn accomplished trainer, McPeek won the Preakness Stakes in 2020 with Swiss Skydiver and the Belmont Stakes in 2002 with Sarava. He previously had nine Kentucky Derby starts, but finally captured his first Derby win Saturday.\n\nMystik Dan is owned by Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing (Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby.\n\nLance and Brent {"uri": "8113120563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:23:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:23:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:22:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/article-uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others/", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, N.Y., before they decide whether to enter him in the Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those [situations] where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1\u00bc mile (about two kilometres), matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", {"uri": "8111760982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:05:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:05:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:04:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/john-clay-i-believe-in-mojo-trainer-kenny-mcpeek-earns-rare-double-in-thrilling-derby/article_6453bda0-ff7d-5812-b695-31dd0cd5080a.html", "title": "John Clay: 'I believe in mojo.' Trainer Kenny McPeek earns rare double in thrilling Derby photo finish.", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- For the 150th renewal, you could not have asked for a more thrilling Kentucky Derby.\n\nTrained by Lexingtonian Kenny McPeek, Mystik Dan edged hard-charging $2.3 million colt Sierra Leone and Japanese intruder Forever Young in a three-way photo finish by a nose (if that) to win a breathtaking Derby before 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nNot only did McPeek earn his first Kentucky Derby victory, in combination with Thorpedo Anna's win in the Kentucky Oaks on Friday, McPeek became the first trainer since the legendary Ben Jones in 1952 to pull off the Oaks/Derby double. Jones did it with Oaks winner Real Delight and Derby winner Hill Gail.\n\n\"Wow,\" said McPeek on Saturday when asked about the feat.\n\n\"For three weeks, I felt like we were going to win both races, I can't tell you why,\" said the trainer. \"I believe in mojo. I believe in positive energy and we had a lot of that.\"\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. became the first jockey to win both the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby since Calvin Borel in 2009 on Rachel Alexandra in the Oaks and Mine That Bird in the Derby.\n\nA homebred owned by Arkansas' Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing, Daniel Hamby III and Valley View Farm, Mystik Dan won in a time of 2:03 3/5. At odds of 18-1, he paid $39.22 to win, $16.32 to place and $10 to show. The son of Goldencents had won the Southwest Stakes by 8 lengths on a muddy track at Oaklawn on Feb. 3, but had finished third behind Muth and Just Steel in the Arkansas Derby at Oaklawn on May 30.\n\n\"I'm pinching myself, wondering if this is real,\" Gasaway said. \"You just won the biggest horse race in America. Who would have dreamed it.\"\n\nThe 61-year-old McPeek won the 2002 Belmont Stakes with Sarava and the 2020 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver, but was 0 for 9 in his home state's famous race. His best finish was second with Tejano Run all the way back in 1995.\n\nIt was a heartbreaking loss for the connections of Sierra Leone, who had won the Toyota Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland on April 6. With a deep closing running style, Sierra Leone made a strong move to the finish but came up a nose short.\n\n\"It's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"It's professional sport, when you're at this level you're going to win some and lose some and often times it's a game of inches.\"\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe previously unbeaten Forever Young was attempting to be the first Japanese-bred to win the Kentucky Derby. In the middle between Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone, Forever Young finished third.\n\nSierra Leone paid $6.54 to place and $4.64 to show. Forever Young paid $5.58 to show. The $1 exacta of 3-2 paid $129.28.\n\nMorning-line and post-time favorite Fierceness, the 13 1/2-length winner of the Florida Derby, challenged for the lead for most of the race, but faded badly in the stretch. Owned by Mike Repole and trained by Todd Pletcher, Fierceness finished 15th.\n\nThe finish was a terrific ending to a terrific day that included Churchill showing off its new $200 million paddock for a group of celebrities including Kansas City Chiefs Super Bowl champion tight end and Taylor Swift boyfriend Travis Kelce, Martha Stewart (who nearly misspoke during the traditional \"Riders Up\" command by saying the \"Commonwealth of Connecticut\"), \"Tonight Show\" host Jimmy Fallon, new Kentucky basketball coach Mark Pope and now former UK basketball star Reed Sheppard, among others.\n\nFriday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track. The Churchill surface was listed as muddy for the opening races on Saturday, but had dried to a fast track with a temperature of 80 degrees by the 6:57 p.m. post time for the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThis was the third consecutive Kentucky Derby without trainer Bob Baffert, who has a record-tying six Derby victories to his credit, including a pair of Triple Crown winners (American Pharoah in 2015, Justify in 2018).\n\nThe California-based Baffert was initially suspended for two years after his trainee Medina Spirit hit the finish line first in the 2021 Kentucky Derby only to be disqualified after testing positive for Betamethasone, banned on race day. Last July, Churchill Downs, Inc. extended Baffert's suspension through 2024 for what it said was the trainer continuing \"to peddle a false narrative concerning the failed drug test of Medina Spirit.\"\n\nOwner Amr Zedan opted to stick with Baffert instead of transferring his star 3-year-old Muth to an eligible trainer. After winning the Arkansas Derby, Muth is being pointed to the May 18 Preakness Stakes in Baltimore. Zedan also owned Medina Spirit.\n\nBut this Kentucky Derby Day belonged to Mystik Dan and McPeek, the trainer who had earned his 2,000th victory as a trainer back in February. But for the Tates Creek High School and University of Kentucky graduate to finally win the Kentucky Derby was a dream come true.\n\n\"It means everything,\" McPeek said. \"It's been an amazing journey.\"\n\n\u00a92024 Lexington Herald-Leader. {"uri": "8112818126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:22:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:22:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:22:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://thesportsdaily.com/news/what-should-we-know-about-2024-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan/", "title": "What should we know about Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan?", "body": "The first triple crown race of 2024 took place on Saturday with the Kentucky Derby. Here are some fascinating points you may not have known about champion Mystik Dan.\n\nMystik Dan's Kentucky Derby title was extremely close. He won a three-way photo finish over second place finisher Sierra Leone and a third place finisher Forever Young. Mystik Dan's victory actually came by a nose. Forever Young is a Japanese thoroughbred race horse.\n\nThis was the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby. Aristides won the first Kentucky Derby in 1875. Black Gold won the 50th Kentucky Derby in 1924, and Cannonade won the 100th Kentucky Derby in 1974.\n\nThe native of Lafayette, Louisiana won his first Triple Crown race. The most notable win he had prior to Saturday came in 2012 when Hernandez Jr. won the 2012 Breeders' Cup Classic on the horse Fort Larned.\n\nThe 2024 Kentucky Derby was the third Triple Crown win for trainer Kenneth McPeek of Fort Chaffee, Arkansas. It was also the first Kentucky Derby win for McPeek. He previously trained Sarava to a Belmont Stakes victory in 2002, and filly Swiss Skydiver to a win at the Preakness in 2020.\n\nMcPeek was the first trainer since 1952 to win the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby in the same year. On May 3, a day before the Kentucky Derby, McPeek trained Thorpedo Anna to victory. Interestingly, Hernandez Jr. was also the winning jockey. In 1952, Ben Jones of Parnell, Missouri trained Real Delight to a win at the Kentucky Oaks and Hill Gail to a win at the Kentucky Derby.\n\nMystik Dan's only other win came at the Southwest Stakes in Hot Springs, Arkansas this past January. {"uri": "2024-05-346148333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:44:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:44:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/sports/other/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_84d15792-de8f-5ef8-be2d-122b9b347598.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "GARY B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn at Churchill Downs. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nWentzville superintendent's departure came after threats and police patrols Washington University faculty placed on leave, students 'houseless' after Gaza protest Cardinals games dropped by Comcast after Bally Sports deal falls through Busch Stadium needs renovations. Should St. Louis taxpayers kick in? Pro-Palestinian protests block traffic outside Washington University Teen charged with breaking into more than 35 cars in St. Louis County St. Louis County man charged with 1966 Chicago killing, stabbing woman 125 times Target to open this summer in Midtown St. Louis neighborhood Governor torpedoes appointment of former mayor in squabble with St. Louis senator Condemnation mounts for Washington University's 'appalling' response to protest Hochman: For Cardinals fans, 'patience' has become a 'trigger word' on social media BenFred: Here's why it just got harder to recruit against Eli Drinkwitz and Mizzou Hundreds gather at SLU to protest war in Gaza. 'It's my university's turn.' Media Views: Battlehawks dominate spring football in attendance, but no longer in TV ratings St. Louis Aldermanic President Megan Green says WashU lying about reason for her suspension\n\nTrainer Bob Baffert has told Pimlico officials that he is sending Muth and Imagination to Baltimore for the Preakness.\n\nMuth won the Arkansas Derby on March 30, when Mystik Dan finished third. Imagination was second behind Stronghold in the Santa Anita Derby on April 6.\n\nBaffert has won the Preakness eight times, including last year with National Treasure.\n\nSaratoga in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final race for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1 1/4 miles, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nTV RATINGS: Mystik Dan's nose victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby drew 16.7 million viewers, the biggest audience for the race since 1989.\n\nViewership peaked at 20.1 million from 7 to 7:15 p.m. EDT on Saturday, when 18-1 shot Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young hit the wire together in the Derby's first three-horse photo finish since 1947. That marked the biggest peak audience ever for the Derby on NBC.\n\nThe 16.7 million viewers was up 13% from last year's 14.8 million.\n\nNBC Sports said Sunday it was the biggest Derby audience since 18.5 million watched Sunday Silence win in 1989, when the race was shown on ABC.\n\nClose\n\nA race fan sits in the stands Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby {"uri": "8111670177", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:31:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:31:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:29:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/mystik-dan-wins-historic-2024-232158221.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins historic 2024 Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "Mystik Dan won a three-way photo finish over Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a historic 150th edition of the Grade 1, $5 million Kentucky Derby from a full field of 20 horses on Saturday night beneath the Twin Spires at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nMystik Dan, saddled by Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek and ridden by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., provided the first combination Oaks-Derby double since 1952 with their narrow win.\n\nThe McPeek-Hernandez duo teamed up to win the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna on Friday evening at Churchill. The last jockey to do the Oaks-Derby double was Calvin Borel in 2009 with Rachel Alexandra and Mine That Bird. The last trainer to do the double was Ben Jones in 1952 with Real Delight and Hill Gail.\n\nMcPeek is only the fourth-ever trainer to do the Oaks-Derby double in the same year.\n\nAfter Friday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track and rain threatened throughout Saturday, the Derby was run over a fast main track at Churchill.\n\nIt didn't matter. McPeek and Hernandez won in both conditions at Churchill Downs this weekend.\n\nCatching Freedom finished in fourth. T O Password (JPN) finished in fifth. Both of the Japenese horses in this year's race placed in the top five.\n\nA $2 exacta in the Derby with Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone paid $258.56. A $1 trifecta with Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young (JPN) paid $1,113.84.\n\nMcPeek was previously 0-for-9 in the Derby, with his best finish being second with Tejano Run in 1995.\n\nHernandez had been 0-for-4 in the Derby, with his best finish being eighth with McCraken in 2017.\n\n\"Brian just did an amazing job,\" McPeek said post-race on NBC, praising the jockey, Hernandez, multiple times.\n\nMystik Dan (who broke from post position 3) is owned by Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing (Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby. This was the first Kentucky Derby for all of Mystik Dan's owners.\n\nThe horse went off at 18-1 odds in the Derby.\n\nMystik Dan had accrued 46 Derby qualifying points, which included a third-place finish in the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby on March 30 at Oaklawn Park and a win in the Grade 3 Southwest Stakes in early February at Oaklawn Park.\n\nMystik Dan had 20-1 morning-line odds following last week's post position draw, before he was bet down to the 18-1 odds he went off at.\n\nThe horse is now 3-1-1 in seven career starts. He entered the Derby with career earnings of $641,360, a total that will significantly increase after Saturday's result.\n\nThe bay-colored horse was bred in Kentucky and was sired by Goldencents. Mystik Dan's dam was Ma'am, by Colonel John.\n\nA homebred, Mystik Dan earned his first career win at Churchill Downs last November.\n\nFierceness, the morning-line favorite and the 3-1 post-time favortie, finished in 15th.\n\nThe 2024 Derby Day attendance was 156,710 spectators at Churchill Downs, an increase of more than 6,000 fans from the crowd of 150,335 people that gathered for last year's race.\n\nAs always, several high-quality stakes races took place on the Derby undercard Saturday at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe early undercard races were dominated by jockey Irad Ortiz Jr., who won each of the Grade 2, $600,000 Twin Spires Turf Sprint Stakes, Grade 1, $1 million Derby City Distaff Stakes and Grade 2, $665,000 Longines Churchill Distaff Turf Mile Stakes.\n\nOrtiz won each of those races for a different trainer: Ortiz was aboard Cogburn for Steve Asmussen in a 2 1/4-length victory in the Turf Sprint, Vahva for Cherie DeVaux in a 2-length victory in the Derby City Distaff and Chili Flag (FR) for Chad Brown in a win that came by a neck in the Churchill Distaff Turf Mile.\n\nThe 88-year-old trainer D. Wayne Lukas teamed up with jockey Jaime Torres to win the Grade 2, $600,000 Pat Day Mile Stakes by 1 1/4 lengths with Seize the Grey, and trainer H. Graham Motion paired with jockey Umberto Rispoli to win the Grade 2, $600,000 American Turf Stakes with 47-1 long shot Trikari.\n\nAsmussen also won the Grade 1, $1 million Churchill Downs by 2 1/2 lengths with Gun Pilot, who was ridden by Cristian Torres.\n\nNew UK men's basketball coach Mark Pope attends 2024 Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs\n\nFormer UK basketball star Reed Sheppard attends {"uri": "8112148250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:43:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:43:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:41:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/three-headed-thriller/article_6411b566-1462-55aa-a2b8-9983900795b8.html", "title": "THREE-HEADED THRILLER", "body": "Sierra Leone (2), with jockey Tyler Gaffalione, Forever young, with jockey Ryusei Sakai, and Mystik dan, with jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., cross the finish line at Churchill downs during the 150th running of the Kentucky derby on Saturday in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBETH HARRIS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nPeople are also reading... Former McDowell man serving life sentence for murder killed in prison McDowell shortstop Eli Elliott signs to play with Ferrum College City of Marion announces new city clerk McDowell family grateful for help during girl's medical crisis Former McDowell High School counselor charged with sex acts on a student makes court appearance Man charged with driving vehicle of dead man Work begins to renovate McDowell County's Rec Center Man sentenced to prison for second-degree murder in Marion A heckler tried to derail Trevor Noah's speech at Wake Forest University. He answered her question Marion couple charged with child abuse appear in court Alumni Spotlight: Ceara Carmack Couple charged by McDowell Sheriff's Office with theft Leading the way: McDowell softball seniors come through one more time as championship nears Appalachian State football player Jack Murphy dies Victim, suspect in Monday shooting in Marion still hospitalized\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1\u00bc miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nTags Sports {"uri": "8113800687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:41:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:41:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:40:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/05/06/kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-uncertain-for-preakness-stakes/", "title": "Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan uncertain for Preakness Stakes | BusinessMirror", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Kentucky -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn at Churchill Downs. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me.... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those [situations] where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nTrainer Bob Baffert has told Pimlico officials that he is sending Muth and Imagination to Baltimore for the Preakness.\n\nMuth won the Arkansas Derby on March 30, when Mystik Dan finished third. Imagination was second behind Stronghold in the Santa Anita Derby on April 6.\n\nBaffert has won the Preakness eight times, including last year with National Treasure.\n\nSaratoga in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final race for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1 1/4 miles, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many horses and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run in the Belmont.\n\n\"He's a real laidback horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nTrainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention. AP\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"", "source": {"uri": "businessmirror.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessMirror"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", {"uri": "8112141852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:36:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:36:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:34:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/three-headed-thriller/article_13fec8af-08ed-552a-b326-da4c0feec41d.html", "title": "THREE-HEADED THRILLER", "body": "Sierra Leone (2), with jockey Tyler Gaffalione, Forever young, with jockey Ryusei Sakai, and Mystik dan, with jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., cross the finish line at Churchill downs during the 150th running of the Kentucky derby on Saturday in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBETH HARRIS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nPeople are also reading... UPDATE WITH PHOTO: Police arrest naked man for blocking road in Waterloo Iowa homeowners age 65 and up are eligible for state tax exemption UPDATE: Motorcyclist injured in Wednesday Cedar Falls crash has died UPDATE: Second person charged in 2021 Traer homicide Drake Relays: Nissen sisters relish chance to compete at same meet for first time, excel early in careers at UNI, Don Bosco Summer hours, fees set at The Falls Aquatic Center in Cedar Falls Interchange to be constructed at Greenhill, Highway 58 intersection in Cedar Falls Nebraska fugitive stopped on US Highway 20 near Grundy County line Medo's takes the place of Restoran Bosna in Waterloo with grand opening Friday College Volleyball: Cedar Falls middle blocker commits to UNI College Softball: Hogan learned to 'Go for it' in dual-sport career at UNI NFL: Ben Sinnott says whole NFL draft experience has been surreal College Men's Basketball: Coe College guard commits to UNI as grad transfer Robert \"Bob\" J. Brown New Iowa law regulates traffic cameras, which generated $1.16 million for Waterloo in 2023\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1\u00bc miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\n0 Comments
