{"uri": "8112609226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:12:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:12:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:11:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501483249/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-thriller/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby thriller - Khmer Times", "body": "LOUISVILLE, United States - Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby on Saturday, snatching victory over Sierra Leone at the wire in a scintillating first leg of US flat racing's Triple Crown at Churchill Downs.\n\nTrained by Kenny McPeek and ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr, Mystik Dan squeezed through on the inside going into the final straight and held off - by less than a nose - the late charges by second-favorite Sierra Leone and Japanese raider Forever Young with a photo needed to sort out the order.\n\nAfter the fury of the race, McPeek and Hernandez had to wait several minutes to see their horse, who went off at 18-1, confirmed as the winner.\n\n\"That was the longest two minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\n\"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won.\"\n\nFierceness, the pre-race favourite trained by Todd Pletcher and ridden by John Velazquez, challenged around the final turn but faded late to finish 15th in the field of 20.\n\nThe exciting finish capped a celebratory week at Churchill Downs, where last year's Kentucky Derby was overshadowed by a string of horse deaths that reached 12 before racing was shut down last June.\n\nThis year, the storied venue not only unveiled a sparkling new paddock enclosure but added 2,200 tonnes of new dirt to the track as part of wide-ranging safety changes made after an investigation by the Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority (HISA) found no one cause for the deaths.\n\nAll appeared to go smoothly and safely on Saturday, the crowd of nearly 157,000 treated to a classic racing spectacle.\n\nHernandez credited his win to his move through a tight gap on the inside rail as they turned for home.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it. He shot off and I thought, 'Oh man, we have a chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nBut while Mystik Dan briefly put some daylight between himself and his pursuers, the race was far from over.\n\nSierra Leone, trained by Chad Brown and ridden by Tyler Gaffalione, was forced wide on the final turn but hooked onto Forever Young and they thundered up on the leader only to be denied at the end.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said.\n\nOn Friday, McPeek and Hernandez had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMcPeek became just the fourth trainer to complete the Oaks-Derby double in the same year and the first since Ben Jones in 1952.", "source": {"uri": "khmertimeskh.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khmer At the wire Mystik Dan had just enough to hold off Sierra Leone by a nose, while Forever Young settled for third about a neck back.\n\nCampaigned by his breeders 4 G Racing, Lance Gasaway, and Daniel Hamby III, as well as Valley View Farm, Mystik Dan, a son of Goldencents -- Ma'am, by Colonel John, completed the 1 1/4-mile classic in 2:03.34 on a fast track.\n\nThe victory completes a Kentucky Oaks (G1)-Kentucky Derby double for winning trainer Kenny McPeek and winning jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. They teamed to win the May 3 Oaks with Thorpedo Anna .\n\nThis story will be updated.\n\nSign up {"uri": "2024-05-345855758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:15:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:15:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:39:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.valleycentral.com/sports/ap-uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others-leave-questions-for-preakness/", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\n___\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing", "source": {"uri": "valleycentral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KVEO-TV"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111683801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:54:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:54:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:54:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-232320286.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby in epic three-horse photo finish", "body": "Mystik Dan has won the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby in a heart-pounding three-horse photo finish.\n\nThe bay colt trained by Kenny McPeek and ridden by Brian Hernandez, who went off at 18-1 odds, held off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in the $5m race at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe crowd of more than 150,000 spectators waited nearly 10 minutes before the result was declared official. Catching Freedom placed fourth.\n\nThe 38-year-old Hernandez said he thought the race was won on the far turn of the one-and-a-quarter-mile course.\n\n\"My horse was so game being up on the inside,\" Hernandez said. \"I came through a really tight spot. We kind of climbed up on top of the rail a little bit. When he shot through that spot and he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it, he shot off and I thought, 'Oh man, we've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\n\n\"To see you number flash up to win the Derby like this, I don't think it's going to sink in for a while.\"\n\nHernandez and McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. {"uri": "8111762653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:07:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:07:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:06:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/05/04/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-brian-hernandez/", "title": "Mystik Dan Wins 150th Kentucky Derby", "body": "Underdog Mystik Dan edged out favorites Sierra Leone and Forever Young to clinch an unexpected victory Saturday at the Kentucky Derby, NBC News reported.\n\nIn a surprising outcome at the Kentucky Derby, underdog Mystik Dan clinched a historic victory in a thrilling photo-finish. The 20-1 longshot, ridden by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., narrowly defeated favorites Sierra Leone and Forever Young by just a nose at Churchill Downs, according to NBC News.\n\nBefore winning the Kentucky Derby, Mystik Dan had only managed a third-place finish at the Arkansas Derby and a victory at the Grade III Southwest Stakes, NBC News reported. Trained by Kenny McPeek, this Derby win represents McPeek's first, adding to his resume, which includes training Swiss Skydiver, the 2020 Preakness Stakes champion, and Sarava, the 2002 Belmont Stakes winner.\n\nThe victory was especially gratifying for Hernandez. This Derby win is his first, capping a remarkable 24 hours for the McPeek-Hernandez team, which also celebrated a win at the Kentucky Oaks last Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if we had won,\" jockey Hernandez told NBC Sports. \"So it was quite a rush to sit here and wait for it.\"\n\nThe race itself was tense, with favorites Sierra Leone and Forever Young jostling for the lead, a skirmish that may have cost them the race as Mystik Dan surged ahead to claim victory. Despite the disappointment, Sierra Leone's trainer, Chad Brown, expressed pride in his horse's performance, acknowledging the tight finish and praising the horse for living up to expectations.(RELATED: Dozens Of Horses Fall Seriously Ill, Several Die. Doctor Blames Toxic Weed)\n\n\"I'm so proud of his effort today. The horse did everything we asked him to do,\" Brown said, NBC News stated. \"It just came up just a little bit short.\"\n\nThe excitement of the Derby was reflected in the star-studded attendance, with celebrities like Wynonna Judd, Martha Stewart, and sports figures such as Aaron Rodgers and Travis Kelce enjoying the festivities under the iconic twin spires of Louisville, according to NBC News {"uri": "8111702124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:22:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:22:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:22:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-000203844.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins the 150th Kentucky Derby by less than a nose", "body": "The margin was a nose, but the smiles were a mile wide. In one of the closest finishes in almost 30 years, Mystik Dan won the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe horse was generally overlooked by most, but he ran a smart race on the rail and poked his head in front in the final strides and held off Sierra Leone and Forever Young in the blanket finish.\n\nIt also completed a rare double for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez, who also won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. It was only the fourth time that has been done.\n\n\"That was the longest few minutes in my life I've spent waiting for them to hang the dang number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\nMcPeek was effusive of his praise for Hernandez.\n\n\"Brian did an amazing job,\" McPeek said. \"He's just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey. He's probably one of the most underrated riders in the business. But not anymore.\"\n\nMystik Dan paid $39.22 to win. The 3-year-old colt found his way into the Derby with a third-place finish in the Arkansas Derby and a win in the Southwest Stakes, both at Oaklawn.\n\nMystik Dan probably will have a rematch with the Arkansas Derby winner, Muth, in two weeks at the Preakness.\n\nFierceness, the favorite, finished 15th, proving he might well be a \"bounce\" horse, meaning he runs well every other race.\n\nThe race was also a coming-of-age party for Japanese horses. Forever Young finished third and T O Password was fifth.\n\nThe final order of finish was Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone, Forever Young, Catching Freedom, T O Password, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie, Endlessly, Dornach, Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nTrack officials were hoping to avoid the distractions that came with the last few Derbies and for the most part were successful. Last year there was a severe spike in fatalities including two horses on Derby Day. The track eventually had to stop racing and move the meet to Ellis Park, which is also owned by Churchill Downs. No singular cause for the fatalities was ever discovered.\n\nThere is also the ongoing saga of Churchill Downs vs. Bob Baffert. The Hall of Fame trainer was suspended for two years after provisional 2021 winner Medina Spirit tested positive for legal medication, but not legal on race day. Baffert was thought to be coming back this year, but Churchill unexpectedly added at least one more year to his suspension. Churchill said Baffert did not show enough contrition and didn't take responsibility for the positive.\n\nOn the eve of this year's entry deadline, Amr Zedan, one of Baffert's owners, sued Churchill Downs to try to get his horse, Muth, into the Derby. The litigation failed on both the district and appellate level.\n\nIt would have been a circus like none other if Baffert had won the case and showed up at Churchill Downs sucking up all the oxygen from what the track was hoping would be the celebration surrounding its 150th running of the race.\n\nAnd for insiders, there was the looming potential change of the television landscape. Since 2001 the Kentucky Derby has been on NBC but the contract was set to expire after next year. Fox has made a big push to get into the racing scene and outbid NBC for the Belmont, which it did for the first time last year. It also purchased 25% of NYRA Bets, the advance deposit wagering arm of the New York Racing Assn. But, on Saturday afternoon, it was announced that a deal had been reached to keep the Derby at NBC until 2032.\n\nAll in all, a pretty good week for Churchill and an even better one for McPeek and Hernandez.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", {"uri": "8112245575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:13:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:13:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T11:12:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/05/for-a-kentucky-derby-winning-jockey-2-wins-at-a-historic-place-in-an-amazing-weekend-show.html", "title": "For a Kentucky Derby winning jockey: 2 wins at a historic place in an amazing weekend show", "body": "They call the Kentucky Derby the race where dreams come true. But that depends on who is doing the calling and where he is sitting.\n\nOn Saturday, Brian Hernandez Jr., a 38-year-old jockey out of Lafayette, La., wasn't riding a horse. He was locked in a dream path to victory that only could have been mapped out by whatever mythological jockey had been given a free pass to ride Pegasus.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek, who had put Hernandez aboard horses in Friday's Kentucky Oaks -- the premier race for 3-year-old fillies -- and Saturday's Kentucky Derby, had said, \"Why not win both?\"\n\nAnd after capturing the Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna in a wire-to-wire victory by 4 3/4 lengths, Hernandez had a revelation as he rode 18-1 Mystik Dan down the stretch at historic Churchill Downs a few minutes after 7 p.m. on Saturday: \"I have a chance to win the Kentucky Derby!\"\n\nMcPeek is a believer in the near-impossible. After all, in 2002, he ran Sarava in the Belmont Stakes at odds of 70-1 and cashed a record Belmont payout.\n\nAs he rode Mystik Dan toward the finish, all the luck in this race was stuffed in Hernandez's back pocket. He cleared the treacherous 20-horse gate safely at the start. He saved ground and earned position.\n\nHe slid past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and held off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it, \"but I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said. Sure, have a pair custom-made: The winner's share of the record $5 million purse is $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\nBut after he crossed the finish line, Hernandez still wasn't sure he had won until he saw the replay of the finish. He kept his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop, waiting for the official decision.\n\n\"I'm like, 'Woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,'\" Hernandez, 38, said. \"But then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn't really see them. And then they surged so quickly.\n\n\"I was like, 'Oh, man, I hope we won. I hope we won.' And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nHernandez is the first jockey to complete the Derby-Oaks double since Hall of Fame jockey Calvin Borel did it aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra, respectively, in 2009. McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez said. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn. I don't know how long it's going to take to sink in. It's definitely a surreal moment.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby (of 150) decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone wore the garland of red roses in 1996. But before the stewards could make it official, they had to review the entire race.\n\nHad a foul been committed when the second and third contenders slammed each on the outside before they got back in the race?\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and bay colt walked in circles while the result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nWhen Donna Barton, the former jockey now doing live interviews aboard a horse for NBC, rode next to his horse and listened in as one of the outriders told him, \"Close, much too close, but I think you won.\"\n\nShe asked Hernandez: \"So, what do you think?\" He was silent for an instant and then looked at the toteboard, which confirmed it. \"I just won the Kentucky Derby,\" he said.\n\nAdded McPeek later: \"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride. Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"", "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NJ.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jockey", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jockey"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_trainer", {"uri": "8111698570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:17:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:17:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:16:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/mystik-dan-wins-historic-2024-kentucky-derby-in-three-way-photo-finish-at-churchill-downs/article_4eb4083d-7e8d-53ed-ac3e-2cec7b367be6.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins historic 2024 Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Mystik Dan won a three-way photo finish over Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a historic 150th edition of the Grade 1, $5 million Kentucky Derby from a full field of 20 horses on Saturday night beneath the Twin Spires at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nMystik Dan, saddled by Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek and ridden by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., provided the first combination Oaks-Derby double since 1952 with their narrow win.\n\nThe McPeek-Hernandez duo teamed up to win the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna on Friday evening at Churchill. The last jockey to do the Oaks-Derby double was Calvin Borel in 2009 with Rachel Alexandra and Mine That Bird. The last trainer to do the double was Ben Jones in 1952 with Real Delight and Hill Gail.\n\nMcPeek is only the fourth-ever trainer to do the Oaks-Derby double in the same year.\n\nAfter Friday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track and rain threatened throughout Saturday, the Derby was run over a fast main track at Churchill.\n\nIt didn't matter. McPeek and Hernandez won in both conditions at Churchill Downs this weekend.\n\nCatching Freedom finished in fourth. T O Password (JPN) finished in fifth. Both of the Japenese horses in this year's race placed in the top five.\n\nA $2 exacta in the Derby with Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone paid $258.56. A $1 trifecta with Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young (JPN) paid $1,113.84.\n\nMcPeek was previously 0 for 9 in the Derby, with his best finish being second with Tejano Run in 1995.\n\nHernandez had been 0 for 4 in the Derby, with his best finish being eighth with McCraken in 2017.\n\n\"Brian just did an amazing job,\" McPeek said post-race on NBC, praising the jockey, Hernandez, multiple times.\n\nMystik Dan (who broke from post position 3) is owned by Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing (Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby. This was the first Kentucky Derby for all of Mystik Dan's owners.\n\nThe horse went off at 18-1 odds in the Derby.\n\nMystik Dan had accrued 46 Derby qualifying points, which included a third-place finish in the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby on March 30 at Oaklawn Park and a win in the Grade 3 Southwest Stakes in early February at Oaklawn Park.\n\nMystik Dan had 20-1 morning-line odds following last week's post position draw, before he was bet down to the 18-1 odds he went off at.\n\nThe horse is now 3-1-1 in seven career starts. He entered the Derby with career earnings of $641,360, a total that will significantly increase after Saturday's result.\n\nThe bay-colored horse was bred in Kentucky and was sired by Goldencents. Mystik Dan's dam was Ma'am, by Colonel John.\n\nA homebred, Mystik Dan earned his first career win at Churchill Downs last November.\n\nFierceness, the morning-line favorite and the 3-1 post-time favorite, finished in 15th.\n\nThe 2024 Derby Day attendance was 156,710 spectators at Churchill Downs, an increase of more than 6,000 fans from the crowd of 150,335 people that gathered for last year's race.\n\nIrad Ortiz Jr. dominates Derby undercard races\n\nAs always, several high-quality stakes races took place on the Derby undercard Saturday at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe early undercard races were dominated by jockey Irad Ortiz Jr., who won each of the Grade 2, $600,000 Twin Spires Turf Sprint Stakes, Grade 1, $1 million Derby City Distaff Stakes and Grade 2, $665,000 Longines Churchill Distaff Turf Mile Stakes.\n\nOrtiz won each of those races for a different trainer: Ortiz was aboard Cogburn for Steve Asmussen in a 2 1/4-length victory in the Turf Sprint, Vahva for Cherie DeVaux in a 2-length victory in the Derby City Distaff and Chili Flag (FR) for Chad Brown in a win that came by a neck in the Churchill Distaff Turf Mile.\n\nThe 88-year-old trainer D. Wayne Lukas teamed up with jockey Jaime Torres to win the Grade 2, $600,000 Pat Day Mile Stakes by 1 1/4 lengths with Seize the Grey, and trainer H. Graham Motion paired with jockey Umberto Rispoli to win the Grade 2, $600,000 American Turf Stakes with 47-1 long shot Trikari.\n\nAsmussen also won the Grade 1, $1 million Churchill Downs by 2 1/2 lengths with Gun Pilot, who was ridden by Cristian Torres.\n\n\u00a92024 Lexington Herald-Leader. Visit at kentucky.com. {"uri": "2024-05-346140009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:38:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:38:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T01:51:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.wtaj.com/sports/ap-sports/ap-uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others-leave-questions-for-preakness/", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn at Churchill Downs. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nTrainer Bob Baffert has told Pimlico officials that he is sending Muth and Imagination to Baltimore for the Preakness.\n\nMuth won the Arkansas Derby on March 30, when Mystik Dan finished third. Imagination was second behind Stronghold in the Santa Anita Derby on April 6.\n\nBaffert has won the Preakness eight times, including last year with National Treasure.\n\nSaratoga in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final race for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1 1/4 miles, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many horses and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run in the Belmont.\n\n\"He's a real laidback horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nTrainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\n___\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing", "source": {"uri": "wtaj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTAJ - www.wtaj.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111694900", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:13:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:13:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:11:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.whas11.com/article/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/watch-how-mystik-dan-held-off-sierra-leone-forever-young-kentucky-derby-finish-2024/417-1c46ed34-0602-42ed-8289-d495e73c6ccf", "title": "WATCH: How Mystik Dan held off Sierra Leone, Forever Young in dramatic Kentucky Derby finish", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th running of the Kentucky Derby was historic in plenty of ways, including the finish of Saturday's milestone race.\n\nMystik Dan held off Sierra Leone and Forever Young in one of the closest Triple Crown races in history. The race took several minutes to become official as the 150,000-plus people at the track awaited official word on the photo finish.\n\nMystik Dan held a solid lead as the horses made the turn for the final stretch, but Sierra Leone and Forever Young made a furious rally in the final furlongs to make it photo finish. You can watch the dramatic finish below.\n\nMystik Dan and his team go home with $3.1 million of the record $5 million purse.\n\nRELATED: Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346779980", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:18:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:18:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:12:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/mark-story/article288343265.html", "title": "Who is up and who is down after an unforgettable 2024 Kentucky Derby", "body": "Who is up and who is down after an unforgettable 150th running of the Kentucky Derby:\n\n\u25aa Up: Kenny McPeek. For the veteran trainer from Lexington, last weekend permanently altered how his career will be viewed.\n\nWhen McPeek's Thorpedo Anna won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday, followed by the trainer's Mystik Dan claiming the Derby in a three-horse photo finish Saturday with Sierra Leone (second) and Forever Young (third), it pushed the Tates Creek High School graduate and University of Kentucky alum into newly rarefied air for a trainer.\n\nMcPeek became the first trainer to claim the Oaks/Derby double in the same year since Ben Jones, the iconic Calumet Farm conditioner, did it in 1952 with Real Delight (Oaks) and Hill Gail (Derby).\n\nWith Mystik Dan's Derby win following victories by the McPeek-trained Sarava in the 2002 Belmont Stakes and Swiss Skydiver in the 2020 Preakness, the trainer has now achieved the \"career Triple Crown.\"\n\n\"Goosebumps,\" McPeek said Saturday, when asked to reflect on the magnitude of his latest achievements.\n\n\u25aa Down: Chad Brown. The Kentucky Derby gods continue to torment Brown.\n\nWith the hard-closing Sierra Leone edged out of victory by Mystik Dan's nose, the trainer is now 0-for-8 in the Derby with two second-place finishes, a third, a fourth and a fifth.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one\" to take, Brown said Saturday.\n\n\u25aa Up: Brian Hernandez Jr. Long more accomplished at his craft than celebrated in his profession, the Kentucky-based jockey rewarded the faith of his longtime patron, Kenny McPeek, by riding Thorpedo Anna and Mystik Dan to their victories.\n\nThe gutty, ground-saving ride along the rail by the 38-year-old Hernandez on Mystik Dan was all but universally seen as the difference between winning and losing the Kentucky Derby. Afterward McPeek jokingly implored the media not to write about how impressive a ride it had been so other trainers won't hire Hernandez away.\n\n\"But I guess that cat is out of the bag, isn't it?\" McPeek said.\n\n\u25aa Down: John Velzaquez. When the veteran jockey booted the gritty Medina Spirit to victory in the 2021 Kentucky Derby, it moved Velazquez to an elite level in Derby history.\n\nThat victory made \"Johnny V.,\" only the fourth jockey with at least four Kentucky Derby wins, joining legends Eddie Arcaro and Bill Hartack (five each) and Bill Shoemaker (four).\n\nSubsequently, through no fault of Velazquez, the jockey lost his fourth Derby win when a postrace test showed a banned substance in the system of the Bob Baffert-trained Medina Spirit and the horse was disqualified.\n\nAt age 52, the clock is ticking on opportunities for Velazquez to \"get back\" the fourth Kentucky Derby win that he had taken away.\n\nThat had to make this year's Derby an acute disappointment for Velazquez. Riding race-time favorite Fierceness, Velazquez came home a disappointing 15th after sitting third at the mile pole in the 1 1/4-mile race.\n\n\"When I let (Fierceness) go, he just didn't have it,\" Velazquez said.\n\n\u25aa Up: Churchill Downs management. The 150th Kentucky Derby was apparently a smash hit on multiple fronts.\n\nNBC Sports announced Sunday that the 2024 Derby drew an average audience of 16.7 million viewers. According to NBC, it is the most-watched Kentucky Derby since the 1989 race averaged 18.5 million viewers.\n\nMeanwhile, Churchill Downs announced that $210.7 million was wagered on the Derby, the first time in history that figure went above $200 million.\n\nGiven those metrics, the controversial decision made by Churchill Downs Inc. to extend the original two-year suspension of trainer Bob Baffert related to the Medina Spirit disqualification to a third Kentucky Derby does not appear to have harmed the popularity of the event.\n\n\u25aa Down: Bob Baffert. Given the above figures, the two-time Triple Crown-winning trainer does not have much leverage in his interactions with Churchill Downs.\n\n\u25aa Up: Japan. Though the two Japanese horses who contested the 150th Kentucky Derby did not produce the breakthrough Triple Crown victory that race fans in Japan yearn for, they came close.\n\nThe previously unbeaten Forever Young fought gamely but was squeezed in the middle in the three-horse battle for the race win. Meanwhile, the less highly regarded Japanese horse in the Derby, T O Password, finished a respectable fifth.\n\nWith the recent success of Japanese horses in other major international races, it seems just a matter of time before the Triple Crown win barrier is breached.\n\n\u25aa Down: Martha Stewart. Given the honor of performing the \"Rider's Up\" call for the historically significant 150th Derby, the lifestyle guru and businesswoman nearly committed the verbal faux pas of referring to \"Kentucky\" as \"Connecticut.\"\n\n\"Racing fans from around the world, the city of Louisville and the Commonwealth of Conn -- Kentucky,\" Stewart said in her remarks.\n\nThe subsequent roasting Stewart took on the social media platform X was, I thought, out of proportion to her \"offense.\"\n\nNevertheless, given the magnitude of Derby 150, I think those who were asking why Churchill Downs did not have a celebrity of national import with direct ties to the state of Kentucky perform the \"Rider's Up\" call have a point.", "source": {"uri": "kentucky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-345845782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "18:59:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T18:59:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-05-05/uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others-leave-questions-for-preakness", "title": "Uncertain Plans for 150th Kentucky Derby Winner Mystik Dan, Others Leave Questions for Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-05-345926728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:57:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:57:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:52:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.wthr.com/article/sports/kentucky-derby-mystik-dan-jockey-brian-hernandez-jr-louisville-kentucky/417-40ea920a-92f2-48a2-a840-5f0431e64651", "title": "Kentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Brian Hernandez Jr. will need a minute to digest his signature victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nMaybe even more time since the milestone derby capped the best weekend of a jockey career spent mostly under the radar.\n\nThe Louisiana native rode Mystik Dan to an epic win Saturday at Churchill Downs, sliding past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and holding off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish. Hernandez wasn't even sure he had won until seeing the replay and keeping his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop.\n\n\"I'm like, woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,\" the 38-year-old said. \"But then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn't really see them. And then they surged so quickly.\n\n\"I was like, 'Oh man, I hope we won. I hope we won.' And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nRELATED: Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby\n\nHernandez's derby victory aboard Mystik Dan at 18-1 odds came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire rout by 4 3/4 lengths in the 150th Kentucky Oaks. That made him the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel achieved the feat aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra, respectively, in 2009. Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez added. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn.\n\n\"I don't know how long it's going to take to sink in. It's definitely a surreal moment.\"\n\nHernandez's victory was fitting since he studied Borel's derby wins aboard Mine That Bird and Super Saver (2010), along with being around him during 20 years of racing in Kentucky. Those lessons paid off as he broke through after four derby finishes ranging from eighth to 12th, including 11th last May on Sun Thunder.\n\nRELATED: WATCH: How Mystik Dan held off Sierra Leone, Forever Young in dramatic Kentucky Derby finish\n\nHis seminal moment shouldn't have been shocking considering Hernandez already had an Eclipse Award to his name as top apprentice rider in 2004 along with a Breeders' Cup Classic win in 2012 with Fort Larned. He also was third in the Preakness two years ago with Creative Minister and has a slew of graded stakes wins.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby brings a whole different type of recognition, along with a sparkling title that will precede Hernandez for the rest of his life. McPeek asserted immediately afterward that the rider can no longer be considered underrated after a \"brilliant\" ride and called the gutsy inside path taken to victory typical for the jockey.\n\n\"He knows what to do there,\" McPeek said. \"I always had a world of confidence in him. Rarely second-guess anything he does.\"\n\nHowever, the victory created a travel issue for Hernandez, who had planned on head to Louisiana on Sunday morning for a jazz festival. It's a switch he was more than willing to make after two remarkable days that demonstrated what the right mounts can yield.\n\n\"You know, it's horse racing, it's not jockey racing,\" said Hernandez, who planned to celebrate with his wife on Saturday night. \"Just about any jockey out there, if they have the right horse, they can get them to the winner's circle. You just you have to be willing to put in the time and the effort to find the right horses.\"", "source": {"uri": "wthr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTHR-TV 13 NBC Indianapolis"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wthr.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Hernandez_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Brian Hernandez Jr."}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jockey", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jockey"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mine_That_Bird", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Mine That Bird"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filly", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Filly"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_racing", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Horse racing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Churchill_Downs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Churchill Downs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisiana", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Louisiana"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Louisiana"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_A._Jones", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Ben A. {"uri": "8113153758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:00:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:00:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:58:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/05/uncertain-preakness-plans-for-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan/", "title": "Uncertain Preakness plans for Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race May 18 in the Preakness in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, N.Y., before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16-mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn at Churchill Downs. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nTrainer Bob Baffert has told Pimlico officials that he is sending Muth and Imagination to Baltimore for the Preakness.\n\nMuth won the Arkansas Derby on March 30, when Mystik Dan finished third. Imagination was second behind Stronghold in the Santa Anita Derby on April 6.\n\nBaffert has won the Preakness eight times, including last year with National Treasure.\n\nSaratoga in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final race for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1\u00bc miles, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose ahead of Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many horses and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave today to train at Saratoga and run in the Belmont.\n\n\"He's a real laidback horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nTrainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall.\n\nOaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests.\n\nAt some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"", "source": {"uri": "newstribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jefferson City News Tribune"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111770499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:19:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:19:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:18:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://triblive.com/sports/trainer-kenny-mcpeek-earns-rare-double-in-kentucky-derby-photo-finish/", "title": "Trainer Kenny McPeek earns rare double in Kentucky Derby photo finish", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- For the 150th renewal, you could not have asked for a more thrilling Kentucky Derby.\n\nTrained by Lexingtonian Kenny McPeek, Mystik Dan edged hard-charging $2.3 million colt Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a three-way photo finish by a nose (if that) to win a breathtaking Derby before 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nNot only did McPeek earn his first Kentucky Derby victory, in combination with Thorpedo Anna's win in the Kentucky Oaks on Friday, McPeek became the first trainer since the legendary Ben Jones in 1952 to pull off the Oaks/Derby double. Jones did it with Oaks winner Real Delight and Derby winner Hill Gail.\n\n\"Wow,\" McPeek said Saturday when asked about the feat.\n\n\"For three weeks, I felt like we were going to win both races, I can't tell you why,\" he said. \"I believe in mojo. I believe in positive energy, and we had a lot of that.\"\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. became the first jockey to win both the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby since Calvin Borel in 2009 on Rachel Alexandra in the Oaks and Mine That Bird in the Derby.\n\nThe son of Goldencents had won the Southwest Stakes by 8 lengths on a muddy track Feb. 3 at Oaklawn but had finished third behind Muth and Just Steel in the Arkansas Derby on May 30 at Oaklawn.\n\n\"I'm pinching myself, wondering if this is real,\" part-owner Lance Gasaway said. \"You just won the biggest horse race in America. Who would have dreamed it.\"\n\nThe 61-year-old McPeek won the 2002 Belmont Stakes with Sarava and the 2020 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver, but he was 0 for 9 in his home state's famous race. His best finish was second with Tejano Run all the way back in 1995.\n\nIt was a heartbreaking loss for the connections of Sierra Leone, who had won the Toyota Blue Grass Stakes on April 6 at Keeneland. With a deep closing running style, Sierra Leone made a strong move to the finish but came up a nose short.\n\n\"It's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"It's professional sport. When you're at this level you're going to win some and lose some, and often times it's a game of inches.\"\n\nThe previously unbeaten Forever Young was attempting to be the first Japanese-bred horse to win the Kentucky Derby. In the middle between Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone, Forever Young finished third.\n\nThe finish was a terrific ending to a terrific day that included Churchill showing off its new $200 million paddock for a group of celebrities including Kansas City Chiefs Super Bowl champion tight end and Taylor Swift boyfriend Travis Kelce, Martha Stewart (who nearly misspoke during the traditional \"Riders Up\" command by saying the \"Commonwealth of Connecticut\"), \"Tonight Show\" host Jimmy Fallon, new Kentucky basketball coach Mark Pope and now former UK basketball star Reed Sheppard, among others.\n\nFriday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track. The Churchill surface was listed as muddy for the opening races Saturday but had dried to a fast track with a temperature of 80 degrees by the 6:57 p.m. post time for the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThis was the third consecutive Kentucky Derby without trainer Bob Baffert, who has a record-tying six Derby victories to his credit, including a pair of Triple Crown winners (American Pharoah in 2015, Justify in 2018).\n\nThe California-based Baffert initially was suspended for two years after his trainee Medina Spirit hit the finish line first in the 2021 Kentucky Derby only to be disqualified after testing positive for Betamethasone, banned on race day. Last July, Churchill Downs, Inc. extended Baffert's suspension through 2024 for what it said was the trainer continuing \"to peddle a false narrative concerning the failed drug test of Medina Spirit.\"\n\nOwner Amr Zedan opted to stick with Baffert instead of transferring his star 3-year-old Muth to an eligible trainer. After winning the Arkansas Derby, Muth is being pointed to the May 18 Preakness Stakes in Baltimore. Zedan also owned Medina Spirit.\n\nBut this Kentucky Derby Day belonged to Mystik Dan and McPeek, the trainer who had earned his 2,000th victory as a trainer back in February. But for the Tates Creek High School and University of Kentucky graduate to finally win the Kentucky Derby was a dream come true.\n\n\"It means everything,\" McPeek said. \"It's been an amazing journey.\"", "source": {"uri": "triblive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TribLIVE"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@triblive.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Oaks", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Oaks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epsom_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Epsom Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_A._Jones", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Ben A. {"uri": "2024-05-345297111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:31:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:31:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:29:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.thestate.com/sports/article288318520.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins the 150th Kentucky Derby by less than a nose", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. - The margin was a nose but the smiles were a mile wide. In one of the closest finishes in almost 30 years, Mystik Dan won the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe horse was generally overlooked by most but he ran a smart race on the rail and poked his head in front in the final strides to hold off Sierra Leone and Forever Young in the blanket finish.\n\nIt also completed a rare double for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez, who also won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. It was only the fourth time that has been done.\n\n\"That was the longest few minutes in my life I've spent waiting for them to hang the dang number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\nMcPeek was effusive with his praise for Hernandez.\n\n\"Brian did an amazing job,\" McPeek said. \"He's just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey. He's probably one of the most underrated riders in the business. But not anymore.\"\n\nMystik Dan paid $39.22 to win.\n\nThe 3-year-old colt found his way to Churchill Downs with a third-place finish in the Arkansas Derby and a win in the Southwest Stakes, both at Oaklawn.\n\nMystik Dan likely will have a rematch with the Arkansas Derby winner, Muth, in two weeks at the Preakness.\n\nFierceness, the favorite, finished 15th, proving he may well be a \"bounce\" horse, running well every other race.\n\nThe race was also a coming-of-age party for Japanese horses. Forever Young finished third and T O Password was fifth.\n\nThe final order of finish was Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone, Forever Young, Catching Freedom, T O Password, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie, Endlessly, Dornach, Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nTrack officials were hoping to avoid the distractions that came with the last few Derbies and for the most part were successful. Last year there was a severe spike in fatalities, including two horses on Derby Day. The track eventually had to stop racing and move the meet to Ellis Park, which is also owned by Churchill Downs. No singular cause for the fatalities was discovered.\n\nThere is also the ongoing saga of Churchill Downs versus Bob Baffert. The Hall of Fame trainer was suspended for two years after provisional 2021 winner Medina Spirit tested positive for legal medication that is not allowed on race day. Baffert was thought to be coming back this year but Churchill Downs unexpectedly added at least one more year to his suspension. Churchill Downs officials said that Baffert did not show enough contrition and didn't take responsibility for the positive test.\n\nOn the eve of this year's entry deadline, Amr Zedan, an owner of horses Baffert trains, sued Churchill Downs to try and get his horse Muth into the Derby. The litigation failed on both the district and appellate level.\n\nIt would have been a circus like none other if Baffert had won the case and showed up at Churchill Downs, sucking up all the oxygen from what the track was hoping would be the celebration surrounding its 150th running of the race.\n\nAnd for insiders, there was the looming potential change of the television landscape. Since 2001 the Kentucky Derby has been on NBC but the contract was set to expire after next year. Fox has made a big push to get into the racing scene and outbid NBC for the Belmont Stakes, which it did for the first time last year. It also purchased 25% of NYRA Bets, the advance deposit wagering arm of the New York Racing Association.\n\nBut, on Saturday afternoon, it was announced that a deal had been reached to keep the Kentucky Derby on NBC until 2032.\n\nAll in all, a pretty good week for Churchill and an even better one for McPeek and Hernandez.", "source": {"uri": "thestate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8112740831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:41:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:41:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T19:40:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.espn.com/horse-racing/story/_/id/40089490/kentucky-derby-champ-mystik-dan-uncertain-triple-crown-try", "title": "Derby champ Mystik Dan may skip Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16-mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks, and it completely backfired on me. ... So we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those [situations] where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nSaratoga Race Course, the picturesque track in upstate New York, will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to 1\u00bc miles, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds, and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nTrainer Chad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid-back horse but, when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and the first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and the first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMystik Dan stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt lying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey,\" he said. \"And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", {"uri": "8111668525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:27:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:27:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:26:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/04/kentucky-derby-mystik-dan-by-a-nose-in-three-way-photo-finish/", "title": "Kentucky Derby: Mystik Dan by a nose in three-way photo finish", "body": "Mystik Dan, along the rail, crosses the finish line just ahead of Sierra Leone, outside, and Forever Young, middle, to win the Kentucky Derby on Saturday at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. Kiichiro Sato/Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone and Forever Young for the upset victory.\n\nSent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Forever Young, from Japan, and Sierra Leone gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official. Sierra Leone was second and Forever Young third.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22 to win.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. {"uri": "8112705085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "18:59:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T18:59:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:57:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://wtop.com/sports/2024/05/uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others-leave-questions-for-preakness/", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness - WTOP News", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "https://wtop.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/APTOPIX_Kentucky_Derby_Horse_Racing_85663-scaled.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539947", "eventUri": "eng-9539947", "location": {"type": {"uri": "2024-05-345733693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "15:51:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T15:51:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T15:48:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://eu.courier-journal.com/story/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/2024/05/05/mystik-dan-preakness-stakes-kenny-mcpeek-kentucky-derby-2024-winner/73108790007/", "title": "Will Mystik Dan run in Preakness? Kenny McPeek on what's next for Kentucky Derby winner", "body": "Seconds later, McPeek was explaining to reporters at Churchill Downs why a trip to Baltimore might not be on the agenda.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness. No, not yet,\" McPeek said the morning after his Mystik Dan won the 150 running of the Kentucky Derby by a nose over Sierra Leone. \"We'll just watch him over the next week. It will be one of those where we'll probably take (the decision) up to the last minute. ... We'll let him tell us. If he's not in the feed tub, he won't run.\"\n\nA sleep-deprived McPeek spent Sunday morning soaking in the significance of Saturday's accomplishment -- his first Kentucky Derby victory in 40 years as a trainer.\n\nHe'd won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna and became the first trainer since Ben Jones in 1952 to get an Oaks-Derby sweep.\n\nHis children and grandchildren made congratulatory signs and placed them in the front yard of his Louisville home. Mystik Dan got extra peppermints from co-owner Sharilyn Gasaway.\n\n\"We got in late, but worthwhile,\" McPeek said of the Saturday night celebration. \"Kinda sinking in a little bit.\"\n\nBut as McPeek pointed out, \"there's more work to do,\" and the attention now turns toward the possible Triple Crown pursuit.\n\nThe $2 million Preakness is set for May 18 at Pimlico, and Mystik Dan's presence -- or lack thereof -- will have a big impact on the race's significance.\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan likely will rest Monday and Tuesday before returning to the track Wednesday. One crucial sign of Mystik Dan's condition will be his food intake, which was not off to a good start after Saturday night.\n\n\"He left three quarts feed,\" McPeek said. \"We couldn't hardly get everybody out of the barn until midnight, so he really didn't get a great night's rest.\"\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan likely will ship to Saratoga later this week. With Belmont Park being renovated, Saratoga will host the Belmont Stakes -- the final leg of the Triple Crown -- on June 8.\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan could skip the Preakness and return to action in the Belmont.\n\n\"No. 1, if we go into the (Preakness) we want to win,\" co-owner Lance Gasaway said. \"I'm pretty sure (Bob Baffert) is going to have (Arkansas Derby winner) Muth in there. You take those horses in there at full speed that have been off a month or a month and a half, and we're coming in there in two weeks. That's a big ask of this horse.\"\n\nMcPeek noted Mystik Dan raced twice in a 13-day span as a 2-year-old, breaking his maiden Nov. 12 at Churchill Downs and then finishing fifth in an optional claimer on Nov. 25.\n\n\"It completely backfired on me,\" he said of the decision to race back so quickly.\n\nA son of Goldencents, Mystik Dan won the Kentucky Derby at 18-1 odds behind a rail-skimming ride from jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nMystik Dan pulled away down the stretch before Sierra Leone and third-place Forever Young made a late charge.\n\nGasaway said he got about five hours of sleep after the race but was losing his voice.\n\n\"Has it sunk in yet? No,\" Gasaway said Sunday morning. \"This is the pinnacle of the sport. Unbelievable.\"\n\nJason Frakes: 502-582-4046; jfrakes@courier-journal.com. Catching Freedom finished fourth.\n\nAt 18-1, Hernandez was able to capture his first Kentucky Derby after a short wait for the result to become official. Sierra Leone, the second favorite at 9-2, was ridden by Tyler Gaffalione, while Forever Young, the third favorite at 6-1, had Ryusei Sakai aboard.\n\nDerby favorite Fierceness, at 3-1, finished 15th in the 20-horse field.\n\nThe second leg of the Triple Crown takes place May 18 with the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.
