{"uri": "8112554437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:15:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:15:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:14:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mystik-dan-run-preakness-kenny-154751253.html", "title": "Will Mystik Dan run in Preakness? Kenny McPeek on what's next for Kentucky Derby winner", "body": "Kenny McPeek got the phone call at 7:40 a.m. Sunday, the traditional invite from Preakness Stakes officials wanting the Kentucky Derby winner to compete in the second leg of the Triple Crown.\n\nSeconds later, McPeek was explaining to reporters at Churchill Downs why a trip to Baltimore might not be on the agenda.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness. No, not yet,\" McPeek said the morning after his Mystik Dan won the 150 running of the Kentucky Derby by a nose over Sierra Leone. \"We'll just watch him over the next week. It will be one of those where we'll probably take (the decision) up to the last minute. ... We'll let him tell us. If he's not in the feed tub, he won't run.\"\n\nA sleep-deprived McPeek spent Sunday morning soaking in the significance of Saturday's accomplishment -- his first Kentucky Derby victory in 40 years as a trainer.\n\nHe'd won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna and became the first trainer since Ben Jones in 1952 to get an Oaks-Derby sweep.\n\nHis children and grandchildren made congratulatory signs and placed them in the front yard of his Louisville home. Mystik Dan got extra peppermints from co-owner Sharilyn Gasaway.\n\n\"We got in late, but worthwhile,\" McPeek said of the Saturday night celebration. \"Kinda sinking in a little bit.\"\n\nBut as McPeek pointed out, \"there's more work to do,\" and the attention now turns toward the possible Triple Crown pursuit.\n\nThe $2 million Preakness is set for May 18 at Pimlico, and Mystik Dan's presence -- or lack thereof -- will have a big impact on the race's significance.\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan likely will rest Monday and Tuesday before returning to the track Wednesday. One crucial sign of Mystik Dan's condition will be his food intake, which was not off to a good start after Saturday night.\n\n\"He left three quarts feed,\" McPeek said. \"We couldn't hardly get everybody out of the barn until midnight, so he really didn't get a great night's rest.\"\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan likely will ship to Saratoga later this week. With Belmont Park being renovated, Saratoga will host the Belmont Stakes -- the final leg of the Triple Crown -- on June 8.\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan could skip the Preakness and return to action in the Belmont.\n\n\"No. 1, if we go into the (Preakness) we want to win,\" co-owner Lance Gasaway said. \"I'm pretty sure (Bob Baffert) is going to have (Arkansas Derby winner) Muth in there. You take those horses in there at full speed that have been off a month or a month and a half, and we're coming in there in two weeks. That's a big ask of this horse.\"\n\nMcPeek noted Mystik Dan raced twice in a 13-day span as a 2-year-old, breaking his maiden Nov. 12 at Churchill Downs and then finishing fifth in an optional claimer on Nov. 25.\n\n\"It completely backfired on me,\" he said of the decision to race back so quickly.\n\nA son of Goldencents, Mystik Dan won the Kentucky Derby at 18-1 odds behind a rail-skimming ride from jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nMystik Dan pulled away down the stretch before Sierra Leone and third-place Forever Young made a late charge.\n\nGasaway said he got about five hours of sleep after the race but was losing his voice.\n\n\"Has it sunk in yet? {"uri": "8111727887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:05:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:05:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:05:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/sport/horse-racing/mystik-dan-clings-on-to-win-kentucky-derby-thriller-c-14552266", "title": "Mystik Dan clings on to win Kentucky Derby thriller", "body": "Mystik Dan has held on by a nose in a three-way photo-finish to claim Kentucky Derby glory for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nSierra Leone came home strongly but couldn't quite give his Coolmore owners compensation for City Of Troy's disappointing display in the 2000 Guineas, while Japanese raider Forever Young was another nose back in third.\n\nThe 150th 'Run for the Roses' took place on a 10-furlong dirt track described as running fast after a glorious day in Louisville had dried up the Friday night rain.\n\nA crowd of 156,710 packed into Churchill Downs let out an almighty roar, as Track Phantom took an early lead, flanked by Just Steel and the favourite Fierceness.\n\nThat trio held sway until the turn for home, when Mystik Dan burst through on the inside rail and quickly stormed into a three-length lead.\n\nSierra Leone and Forever Young fought hard to claw back the deficit and were closing in on the leader with every stride, but the finishing line came just in time for Mystik Dan.\n\nIt completed a memorable double for the successful trainer and jockey, who had won the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna 24 hours earlier, and McPeek told NBC Sports: \"Brian just did an amazing job - just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride\".\n\nHernandez admitted the long wait for the result to be confirmed was agonising.\n\n\"This is just unbelievable, that was the longest few minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to put that number up,\" he said.\n\n\"It was exciting when we hit the front but I wasn't sure we had won, so it was quite a rush to stay there and wait for it.\n\n\"This is a lifetime achievement. To be able to live that dream from when I was a six-year-old kid on my grandparents' farm, telling them all I was going to the Kentucky Derby one day - and here we are.\n\n\"It's hard to put into words and it's probably going to take about a week to sink in before we say hey, we won the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks in the same year.\"", "source": {"uri": "perthnow.com.au", "dataType": {"uri": "8111691586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:07:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:07:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:07:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/sports/story/2024-05-04/kentucky-derby-recap-mystik-dan-wins-by-less-than-nose", "title": "Mystik Dan wins the 150th Kentucky Derby by less than a nose", "body": "The margin was a nose but the smiles were a mile wide. In one of the closest finishes in almost 30 years, Mystik Dan won the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe horse was generally overlooked by most but he ran a smart race on the rail and poked his head in front in the final strides to hold off Sierra Leone and Forever Young in the blanket finish.\n\nIt also completed a rare double for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez, who also won the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. It was only the fourth time that has been done.\n\n\"That was the longest few minutes in my life I've spent waiting for them to hang the dang number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\nMcPeek was effusive with his praise for Hernandez.\n\n\"Brian did an amazing job,\" McPeek said. \"He's just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey. He's probably one of the most underrated riders in the business. But not anymore.\"\n\nMystik Dan paid $39.22 to win.\n\nThe 3-year-old colt found his way to Churchill Downs with a third-place finish in the Arkansas Derby and a win in the Southwest Stakes, both at Oaklawn.\n\nMystik Dan likely will have a rematch with the Arkansas Derby winner, Muth, in two weeks at the Preakness.\n\nFierceness, the favorite, finished 15th, proving he may well be a \"bounce\" horse, running well every other race.\n\nThe race was also a coming-of-age party for Japanese horses. Forever Young finished third and T O Password was fifth.\n\nThe final order of finish was Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone, Forever Young, Catching Freedom, T O Password, Resilience, Stronghold, Jonor Marie, Endlessly, Dornach, Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nTrack officials were hoping to avoid the distractions that came with the last few Derbies and for the most part were successful. Last year there was a severe spike in fatalities, including two horses on Derby Day. The track eventually had to stop racing and move the meet to Ellis Park, which is also owned by Churchill Downs. No singular cause for the fatalities was discovered.\n\nThere is also the ongoing saga of Churchill Downs vs. Bob Baffert. The Hall of Fame trainer was suspended for two years after provisional 2021 winner Medina Spirit tested positive for legal medication that is not allowed on race day. Baffert was thought to be coming back this year but Churchill Downs unexpectedly added at least one more year to his suspension. Churchill Downs officials said that Baffert did not show enough contrition and didn't take responsibility for the positive test.\n\nOn the eve of this year's entry deadline, Amr Zedan, an owner of horses Baffert trains, sued Churchill Downs to try and get his horse Muth into the Derby. The litigation failed on both the district and appellate level.\n\nIt would have been a circus like none other if Baffert had won the case and showed up at Churchill Downs, sucking up all the oxygen from what the track was hoping would be the celebration surrounding its 150th running of the race.\n\nAnd for insiders, there was the looming potential change of the television landscape. Since 2001 the Kentucky Derby has been on NBC but the contract was set to expire after next year. Fox has made a big push to get into the racing scene and outbid NBC for the Belmont Stakes, which it did for the first time last year. It also purchased 25% of NYRA Bets, the advance deposit wagering arm of the New York Racing Assn.\n\nBut, on Saturday afternoon, it was announced that a deal had been reached to keep the Kentucky Derby on NBC until 2032.\n\nAll in all, a pretty good week for Churchill and an even better one for McPeek and Hernandez.", "source": {"uri": "latimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Los Angeles {"uri": "2024-05-345313219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:30:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:30:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.wlky.com/article/louisville-trainer-kenny-mcpeek-won-oaks-derby/60692501", "title": "Trainer Kenny McPeek called his shot  --  won both the Oaks and Derby", "body": "Kenny McPeek is typically one of the more confident trainers in the backside at Churchill Downs.But nothing like he has been the past two weeks.McPeek, who had been second in the Kentucky Derby with Tejano Run in 1995 and second three times in the Kentucky Oaks, pulled off the Oaks-Derby double this year after calling his shot.Two weeks prior to the Derby, McPeek stood just outside his barn after Mystik Dan and Thorpedo Anna worked and told several members of the media that he was going to make history in the 150th running of the Derby.\"Look, I wouldn't be surprised if I won them both,\" McPeek said. \"I feel that confident.\"Excuse me?\"They are two really good horses,\" McPeek said. \"Look we have been around the bulls eye on this and we have had some good runs but all of it has to come together. It's not easy.\"You have to have a lot to go right. If it's our turn it's our turn, if it isn't it isn't.\"Well, it was his turn.After guiding Thorpedo Anna to a victory in the Oaks on Friday, jockey Brian Hernandez rode closest to the rail down the stretch in the Derby to get Mystik Dan home first in a thrilling finish before 156,710 fans.\"It's like a dream come true,\" Hernandez said.Sent off at odds of 18-1, Mystik Dan made the turn for home in front and stayed on the rail with Forever Young just to his outside and Sierra Leone on the far outside. It took a minute for the stewards to post the official results.\"Those were the longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby.\"I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"It was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- which is the closest margin you can have in horse racing -- and it was the first nose decision since Grindstone edged out Cavonnier in the 1996 Derby.The win was the first Kentucky Derby for Hernandez and McPeek, who teamed up to win the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. It is the first time since 1952 that a trainer has swept both races in the same year when Ben Jones won them both and the first time a jockey has accomplished the feat since 2009 when Calvin Borel won both on the same weekend.McPeek and Hernandez were a combined 0-for-33 prior to this week in the Oaks and Derby.\"Wow,\" McPeek said. \"You know, wow. I think what I'm most proud of is we didn't do it with Calumet Farm horses. We did it with working\u2011class horses. This colt is a product of a very simple setup. I lovely little filly named Ma'am that we raced. She was a hard tryer and she was classy; and fortunately, they decided to keep her as a mare. We talked about who to breed her to, and look what she produced.Goldencents is not a big number stallion, just putting that all together, I'm really proud of. Alan Shell foaled him at my farm in Lexington. This isn't a huge zillion\u2011dollar operation. We didn't throw money at this. We thoughtfully went through it all, and it's amazing.\"\n\nKenny McPeek is typically one of the more confident trainers in the backside at Churchill Downs.\n\nBut nothing like he has been the past two weeks.\n\nMcPeek, who had been second in the Kentucky Derby with Tejano Run in 1995 and second three times in the Kentucky Oaks, pulled off the Oaks-Derby double this year after calling his shot.\n\nTwo weeks prior to the Derby, McPeek stood just outside his barn after Mystik Dan and Thorpedo Anna worked and told several members of the media that he was going to make history in the 150th running of the Derby.\n\n\"Look, I wouldn't be surprised if I won them both,\" McPeek said. \"I feel that confident.\"\n\nExcuse me?\n\n\"They are two really good horses,\" McPeek said. \"Look we have been around the bulls eye on this and we have had some good runs but all of it has to come together. It's not easy.\n\n\"You have to have a lot to go right. If it's our turn it's our turn, if it isn't it isn't.\"\n\nWell, it was his turn.\n\nAfter guiding Thorpedo Anna to a victory in the Oaks on Friday, jockey Brian Hernandez rode closest to the rail down the stretch in the Derby to get Mystik Dan home first in a thrilling finish before 156,710 fans.\n\n\"It's like a dream come true,\" Hernandez said.\n\nSent off at odds of 18-1, Mystik Dan made the turn for home in front and stayed on the rail with Forever Young just to his outside and Sierra Leone on the far outside. It took a minute for the stewards to post the official results.\n\n\"Those were the longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby.\n\n\"I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- which is the closest margin you can have in horse racing -- and it was the first nose decision since Grindstone edged out Cavonnier in the 1996 Derby.\n\nThe win was the first Kentucky Derby for Hernandez and McPeek, who teamed up to win the Kentucky Oaks on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. It is the first time since 1952 that a trainer has swept both races in the same year when Ben Jones won them both and the first time a jockey has accomplished the feat since 2009 when Calvin Borel won both on the same weekend.\n\nMcPeek and Hernandez were a combined 0-for-33 prior to this week in the Oaks and Derby.\n\n\"Wow,\" McPeek said. \"You know, wow. I think what I'm most proud of is we didn't do it with Calumet Farm horses. We did it with working\u2011class horses. This colt is a product of a very simple setup. I lovely little filly named Ma'am that we raced. She was a hard tryer and she was classy; and fortunately, they decided to keep her as a mare. We talked about who to breed her to, and look what she produced.\n\nGoldencents is not a big number stallion, just putting that all together, I'm really proud of. Alan Shell foaled him at my farm in Lexington. This isn't a huge zillion\u2011dollar operation. We didn't throw money at this. {"uri": "8112009484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "07:24:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T07:24:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T07:23:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/05/state-has-a-grand-day-at-run-for-the-roses/", "title": "State has a grand day at Run for the Roses", "body": "It was a rarity and at the center of the attention as Oaklawn Racing Casino Resort at Hot Springs had an Oaks-Derby double, and the kings of thoroughbred racing are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway of Gould.\n\nTheir horse, Mystik Dan, won the Kentucky Derby on Saturday in Louisville, Ky., after a mythic stretch duel and got the $3 million first-place money on the last jump at the finish line.\n\nIt was a brilliant ride by Brian Hernandez, who along with trainer Kenny McPeek, became legends for winning the Kentucky Oaks and the Derby on the same weekend.\n\nJust like he did when he won the Southwest Stakes on Feb. 3 at Oaklawn, Hernandez was unhurried and then came barrelling down the stretch on the rail knowing exactly how much horse he had.\n\nWhat makes this even more remarkable is the Gasaways -- and yes, Lance was a standout football player at Arkansas-Monticello -- bred their mare Ma'am for a mere $10,000 stud fee.\n\nCompare that to second-place finisher Sierra Leone, who sold for $2.3 million as a 2-year-old. The show horse, Forever Young, cost his owners $760,000.\n\nA day earlier, Hernandez kicked home the McPeek-trained Thorpedo Anna -- winner of Oaklawn's Fantasy Stakes -- in a wire-to-wire, front-running win, making McPeek the first trainer in 72 years to win both the Oaks and the Derby.\n\nThe Gasaways own 4 G Racing and before Saturday's triumph had won a handful of races, but today they are owners of the No. 1 horse in the world.\n\nMystik Dan got bumped in the Arkansas Derby but still managed to get the show money and enough points to qualify for the Kentucky Derby.\n\nHe came out of that race in good shape though, and apparently there was never any doubt his next race would be in Louisville.\n\nMystik Dan was an 18-1 long shot.\n\nPeople come from all over the world for the Derby, not just fans of the fastest two minutes in sports, but jockeys and horses.\n\nIt may be the most diverse jockey colony in the world.\n\nThe Kentucky Derby is more than the No. 1 horse race each year, it is a party, a social gathering and a fundraiser (mostly for Churchill Downs Inc.). It is an event so big NBC covers it for almost five hours.\n\nIt was a tough but great card Saturday and had horses competing against each other named U.S. Army and Five Star General -- neither came close to the winner's circle.\n\nIn the Turf Classic that preceded the 150th Kentucky Derby, Naval Power, who was from Argentina, powered to the lead in the stretch to get beat at the wire by Program Training, who has lost just once in his previous five starts.\n\nThen came the long wait for the Run for the Roses to give every bettor a chance to place a bet like it was the last horse race they would ever wager on.\n\nWith a field of 20, the favorite Fierceness was at 3-1, the longest odds he had seen this year. The only time the winner of the Florida Derby by more than 13 lengths hasn't been favored was last year in the Breeder's Cup Juvenile, when he went off at 16-1 and won by more than six lengths.\n\nEven if he had finished better, he probably would have been taken down for interfering with Forever Young.\n\nOnly one horse in the field had won more money than Fierceness and that was Forever Young with more than $2 million in earnings. He came all the from Japan and he was 6-1. The other shipper from Japan was T O Password and he was 47-1. Both come from the bloodline of Ferdinand, who won the 1986 Derby.\n\nMystik Dan, his jockey, trainer and owners shocked the world of racing, and it put Oaklawn smack dab in the middle of the argument "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 99}], "image": "https://wehco.media.clients.ellingtoncms.com/img/photos/2023/10/13/WALLY_HALL_t600.jpg?4326734cdb8e39baa3579048ef63ad7b451e7676", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539947", "eventUri": "eng-9539947", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-02-03", "textStart": 610, "textEnd": 616}], "sentiment": 0.3960784313725489, "wgt": 173, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8111825725", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:45:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:45:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:45:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/horse-racing/news/mystik-dans-narrow-thrilling-kentucky-derby-win-ends-a-perfect-week-for-racing", "title": "Mystik Dan's Narrow, Thrilling Kentucky Derby Win Ends a Perfect Week for Racing", "body": "LOUISVILLE , KY -- Perhaps this is how a sport takes its first small step out of a creeping darkness that has come to define -- and sometimes threaten -- its existence: With one horse alone in the fading yellow glow of a spring evening, nothing between him and victory in the Kentucky Derby but a football field's worth of corduroy loam, a local workaday jockey pumping his arms in rhythm with the animal beneath him, man and colt together staving off exhaustion. Asking. Urging. Begging. With two other horses shrinking the distance separating them from the leader with every stride, fighting each other, until the three are almost one, and a crowd the size of a small city making a sound like an airplane climbing into the pale blue sky. With the finish line arriving, the trio inseparable. And with the roar becoming a wondrous, unknowing gasp, an exhalation that is equal parts uncertainty and joy, a sound at the heart of an ancient game.\n\nSo it was on Saturday at Churchill Downs in the rare American horse race that truly matters, that Mystik Dan, a bay colt sent off at 18-1 odds, shot into the lead along the rail at the quarter pole, a move that 38-year-old veteran Kentucky jockey Brian Hernandez learned from watching three-time Derby winner Calvin Borel, and galloped into open space, tantalizingly close to the wire but painfully far away. Behind him, Sierra Leone, at 5-1 the second choice in the 20-horse field, and Forever Young, the latest Japan-based horse to try to win the Derby's roses, tried to run him down. As soon as they hit the line, as Sierra Leone edged past Forever Young, the PHOTO sign was illuminated on the infield tote boards and on hundreds of monitors around the mammoth racetrack.\n\nAnd then... everyone waited. Mystik Dan's Churchill-based trainer, Kenny McPeek, who has won the Preakness and Belmont Stakes in a long and circuitous career, but never the Derby, was in his box near the finish. Chad Brown, Sierra Leone's four-time Eclipse Award-winning trainer, winner of nearly every significant race in American thoroughbred racing, was nearby in his. The typical Derby throng, this year 156,170 fans, waited in seats and boxes and concourses at the end of a long day.\n\nReplays were shown on monitors. Mystik Dan looked like the winner. Then a slow-motion replay was shown. Maybe not. Very close to the line, Mystik Dan's head rose as Sierra Leone's fell. A bob, they say in racing. Was it enough?\n\n\"I didn't think I won, watching it live,\" said Brown after the race. \"Then they showed the slo-mo, I thought maybe this could be a dead heat. Because I got a great (head) bob. I just wasn't in front. But it's tough to know which angles they're showing.\"\n\nMcPeek said, \"I thought we won when we hit the wire. There was a monitor sitting right behind us. Somebody pointed it out. They slo-mo'd it to the wire. I thought it was pretty obvious we won.\"\n\nTwo minutes passed. Three minutes. On the backstretch, Hernandez pulled up Mystik Dan and asked his outrider. \"The outrider said we think you won,\" said Hernandez. \"But they haven't made it official yet.\"\n\nFour minutes. There's nothing like this in racing, and few things like it anywhere in sports. Horses and riders have spent themselves. Owners and trainers have worked months for the Derby. Now the outcome is delayed. Bettors clutch tickets to their hearts; some will be cashed, others worthless. The day is over, but it's not over. It is a delay not at all like the 22 minutes after the end of the 2019 Derby, when an ominous sense of unsatisfying justice hung in the air before winner Maximum Security -- clearly the best horse that day -- was appropriately disqualified from first place, \"taken down\" in racing parlance, and plodding closer Country House declared a tepid, longshot winner. This was different. This was a delay worth living, an agony that makes the reward more meaningful.\n\nFive minutes.\n\nFinally. OFFICIAL replaced PHOTO on the boards and monitors. Another roar. Mystik Dan, a homebred owned and bred by an Arkansas group led by former small college football player Lance Gasaway and his wife, Sherilyn, had won the 150th Kentucky Derby by the margin of a nose over Sierra Leone. It was the closest Derby finish since 1996, when Grindstone ran down Cavonnier and also won by a nose, denying a first Derby win to an unknown, white-haired California trainer named Bob Baffert, who has since won the Derby six times and whose absence -- while in the third year of a Derby suspension levied by Churchill Downs -- from Saturday's race was conspicuous, but somehow less meaningful in the jetstream of such an enervating moment. It was the Derby's first three-horse photo finish since Jet Pilot, Phalanx and Faultless in 1947.\n\nWith Mystik Dan's victory, McPeek became the first trainer since Ben Jones in 1952 to win both the Kentucky Oaks for three-year-old fillies, which McPeek won Friday with Thorpedo Anna, and the Derby. He had predicted the win in his Oaks press conference the day before, when asked if he would be returning to the winning chair a day later. \"Count on it,\" McPeek said. After the Derby, he said, \"For three weeks, I've felt like we were going to win both races. I can't tell you why. Both horses have been so easy to deal with. There's been no drama. And we had two really good horses.\"\n\nA moment: One good horse race does not rescue a sport. Racing's wounds are deep and will not heal quickly. It was a year ago that the Derby unfolded as the first chapter in a months-long crisis that -- absent aggressive intervention and change -- had the potential to push the sport of racing closer to irrelevance and within range of extinction. Five thoroughbreds suffered catastrophic breakdowns and were euthanized in the 10 days leading to the Derby, and two more in races on the Derby undercard. Five horses were scratched from the body of the race, the most since 1936. Trainer Saffie Joseph, Jr. was suspended because two of his horses were among the dead (he was back in the Derby this year) and Hall of Fame trainer Todd Pletcher was bigfooted by a state veterinarian, when the vet scratched Pletcher's likely favorite Forte on the morning of the Derby.\n\nIt was a lousy week and a lousy day, and while 15-1 shot Mage's victory and his connections' rollicking infield celebration brought a moment of joy and relief (as did the entire Derby field finishing safely), it couldn't undo what had come before it. The Derby shuffled offstage, diminished in its present, less reliable as an antidote to any and all issues in the sport. The rest of the year was no better: Two weeks after the Derby, the Preakness was differently fraught, but no less painfully. Three-year-old Havnameltdown suffered a gruesome breakdown approaching the homestretch in the Chick Lang Stakes and was euthanized on the track; a few hours later National Treasure won a thrilling Preakness. The catch: Both were trained by Baffert.\n\nTwo more horses died on the track on the day of the Belmont Stakes, bringing the Triple Crown Day tally to five. Across the 40 days of the glossy Saratoga summer meet, 13 horses died in racing or training, including beloved filly Maple Leaf Mel's horrific collapse just short of the finish line on a Saturday with more than 44,000 sun-soaked spectators watching aghast. The sport was reeling, society beginning to turn away.\n\nChurchill Downs took steps. First, the track shut down its 2023 spring meet a month early, on June 2, and reopened in the fall. Horses competing in the Derby were subjected to rigorous daily attention by a team of veterinarians, charged with ensuring their soundness. They trained with biometric sensors designed to detect changes in gait that might indicate the beginnings of an injury. Upgraded surface maintenance equipment was put into use, a no-stone-unturned strategy to counter consistent findings that breakdown clusters are in some way connected to track surfaces. A PET scan unit was installed at the track.\n\nAnd, the kicker. There were no catastrophic breakdowns during Derby week, or on Derby Day. Is that because of the measures Churchill took to improve horse safety? Or did the roulette wheel of random outcomes simply spare the track, the race and the sport this year, after punishing it a year ago? It's impossible to know in real time. And a clean week does not arrest years of unattended slippage and tragedy. But this is unequivocally true: Zero dead horses is better than seven dead horses. And the recovery has to begin somewhere.\n\nIt could do worse than to begin with Mystik Dan. With McPeek. With Gasaway. With Hernandez.\n\nMystik Dan was born in 2021 to Gasaway's mare, Ma'am, a blue-collar daughter of one-time Derby starter Colonel John, who won four times in 23 career starts, totaling $167,923, mostly in claiming and low-level allowance races, never in a stakes race. She did not scream broodmare, but Gasaway bred her to 2013 and 2014 Breeders' Cup Dirt Mile winner Goldencents for a meager $10,000 stallion fee, and, voila. Gasaway marveled at all of it. \"I mean, who would have ever dreamed that a little filly, Ma'am, breed her for a $10,000 stud fee, and win the Kentucky Derby. It's just really surreal.\"\n\nMystik Dan, who was named for one of Gasaway's partners, Dan Hamby, and Hamby's father's work as a salesman for Mystik Tape, took an uncertain route to the Derby, via Arkansas. He was just fifth in January's Smarty Jones, but won the February Southwest Stakes by eight lengths. A third in the March 30 Arkansas Derby earned him enough points to make the Derby starting gate. Hernandez had ridden him in all but the desultory Smarty Jones. \"He just doesn't make mistakes,\" said McPeek. \"I go to big races and use other jockeys and say, 'I miss Brian.'\"\n\nHernandez is a rider's rider; his mounts have won $127 million in purses in 22 years, but he's never become famous. His Derby ride was a virtuoso performance. A week before the Derby, Mystik Dan drew the No. 3 post position in the 20-horse Derby field, which can be problematic. Hernandez turned it into an advantage and summoned his memory of his friend and Derby legend. Borel won the 2007 Derby with Street Sense, the 2009 Derby with Mine That Bird and the 2010 Derby with Super Saver, all with rail-skimming rides, true to his nickname of Calvin Bo-rail. When Hernandez drew the three hole, he watched those rides.\n\n\"Twenty years I've ridden here, I sat in the same corner as Calvin Borel. I got to watch him ride those Derbies. I said, 'You know what? We're going to roll the dice [and ride the rail].'\" It worked perfectly. Hernandez kept Mystik Dan inside all the way around, saving ground and staying patient. \"Nice and comfortable the whole way,\" Hernandez said. Turning for home, he slipped into a tiny hole inside Track Phantom and Joel Rosario. Half a minute later, he hit the wire, clear by the smallest unit of measurement in racing.\n\nA year since its nadir, a sport rose from its knees to begin walking again.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8112179993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:11:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:11:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:09:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/three-headed-thriller/article_9616b879-6d65-5b0b-82f2-9dad6074a58c.html", "title": "THREE-HEADED THRILLER", "body": "Sierra Leone (2), with jockey Tyler Gaffalione, Forever young, with jockey Ryusei Sakai, and Mystik Dan, with jockey Dan Brian Hernandez Jr., cross the finish line at Churchill downs during the 150th running of the Kentucky derby on Saturday in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBETH HARRIS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nPeople are also reading... La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday Bellin Gundersen Health System files trademark application for Emplify Health name, logo Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Amtrak adds second train between Twin Cities, Chicago; Borealis service will stop in La Crosse, Tomah, Winona Steve Cahalan: Valley View Mall to add more tenants, 7 Brew Coffee drive-thrus coming to La Crosse La Crosse man arrested for possession of fentanyl during traffic stop Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Onalaska teen faces charges for uploading child pornography 'Slow, thoughtful process': Emplify Health to become new name of Gundersen, Bellin group Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska Mount Horeb shooting: Students 'saw something' as teen approached school, notified staff La Crosse County home prices skyrocket 21% over last year; fewer sales than year prior Melrose man faces charges of stalking and vandalism in jealous rage DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Brian Hernandez Jr. squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1\u00bc miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nLove 0 {"uri": "2024-05-345282111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:44:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:44:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:34:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish/article_7e837804-4de6-5acd-9879-da8b732e07c4.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a three-horse photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone by a nose with Forever Young third in the tightest finish since 1996 on Saturday.\n\nSent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leona, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and bay colt walked in circles while the stunning result was settled.\n\nFierceness, the 3-1 favorite, finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nSierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nAP {"uri": "8111766479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:06:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:06:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:12:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13383941/Kentucky-Derby-victory-aboard-Mystik-Dan-provides-signature-win-jockey-Brian-Hernandez-Jr.html", "title": "Kentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for...", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) - Brian Hernandez Jr. will need a minute to digest his signature victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nMaybe even more time since the milestone derby capped the best weekend of a jockey career spent mostly under the radar.\n\nThe Louisiana native rode Mystik Dan to an epic win Saturday at Churchill Downs, sliding past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and holding off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish. Hernandez wasn\u00b4t even sure he had won until seeing the replay and keeping his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop.\n\n\"I\u00b4m like, woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,\" the 38-year-old said. \"But then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn\u00b4t really see them. And then they surged so quickly.\n\n\"I was like, 'Oh man, I hope we won. I hope we won.\u00b4 And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nHernandez\u00b4s derby victory aboard Mystik Dan at 18-1 odds came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire rout by 4 3/4 lengths in the 150th Kentucky Oaks. That made him the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel achieved the feat aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra, respectively, in 2009. Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. celebrates in the winner's circle after riding Mystik Dan to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson)\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez added. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn.\n\n\"I don\u00b4t know how long it\u00b4s going to take to sink in. It\u00b4s definitely a surreal moment.\"\n\nHernandez\u00b4s victory was fitting since he studied Borel\u00b4s derby wins aboard Mine That Bird and Super Saver (2010), along with being around him during 20 years of racing in Kentucky. Those lessons paid off as he broke through after four derby finishes ranging from eighth to 12th, including 11th last May on Sun Thunder.\n\nHis seminal moment shouldn\u00b4t have been shocking considering Hernandez already had an Eclipse Award to his name as top apprentice rider in 2004 along with a Breeders\u00b4 Cup Classic win in 2012 with Fort Larned. He also was third in the Preakness two years ago with Creative Minister and has a slew of graded stakes wins.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby brings a whole different type of recognition, along with a sparkling title that will precede Hernandez for the rest of his life. McPeek asserted immediately afterward that the rider can no longer be considered underrated after a \"brilliant\" ride and called the gutsy inside path taken to victory typical for the jockey.\n\n\"He knows what to do there,\" McPeek said. \"I always had a world of confidence in him. Rarely second-guess anything he does.\"\n\nHowever, the victory created a travel issue for Hernandez, who had planned on head to Louisiana on Sunday morning for a jazz festival. It\u00b4s a switch he was more than willing to make after two remarkable days that demonstrated what the right mounts can yield.\n\n\"You know, it\u00b4s horse racing, it\u00b4s not jockey racing,\" said Hernandez, who planned to celebrate with his wife on Saturday night. \"Just about any jockey out there, if they have the right horse, they can get them to the winner\u00b4s circle. You just you have to be willing to put in the time and the effort to find the right horses.\"\n\nThis story has been corrected to show Hernandez had one Breeders' Cup victory, not two.\n\nAP Kentucky Derby coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/kentucky-derby\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. rides Mystik Dan across the finish line to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky. {"uri": "2024-05-346862846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:00:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:00:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T13:40:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://thehornnews.com/kentucky-derby-smashes-35-year-record-for-t-v-ratings/", "title": "Kentucky Derby smashes 35-year record for T.V. ratings  - The Horn...", "body": "The 150th Kentucky Derby, won by Mystik Dan in a thrilling moment, attracted 16.7 million viewers, making it the most-watched Derby since 1989.\n\nThe race reached its peak viewership of 20.1 million between 7 and 7:15 p.m. EDT on Saturday when Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone, and Forever Young crossed the finish line together in the first three-horse photo finish since 1947. This marked the highest peak audience ever for the Derby on NBC.\n\n[Warning] U.S. law could rob you of your IRA, 401(k), and even your pension [sponsored]\n\nDespite the massive audience, Mystik Dan's trainer, Kenny McPeek, and the horse's owners are unsure whether the colt will compete in the Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which would require a quick two-week turnaround.\n\nThe horse will travel to Saratoga, New York, before a decision is made.\n\nOther trainers are also considering their options for the upcoming races. Chad Brown has decided to skip the Preakness with Sierra Leone, opting to train at Saratoga and run in the Belmont instead.\n\nBrad Cox is evaluating Catching Freedom and Just A Touch before making a decision, while the Japan-bred horses Forever Young and T O Password are set to return home.\n\nThe Preakness may lack some star power from the Derby, but it will still have plenty of exciting storylines with well-rested horses expected to compete.\n\nMcPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. are celebrating their remarkable achievement, as they both claimed rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is only the third trainer to accomplish this feat, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to do so.\n\n[Warning] U.S. law could rob you of your IRA, 401(k), and even your pension [sponsored]\n\nAs Hernandez prepares for the spotlight and the title that comes with winning the Kentucky Derby, he reflects on the significance of the achievement, knowing that he can now proudly say he has won the most prestigious race in the sport.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this article.", "source": {"uri": "thehornnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Horn News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derby", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Derby"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Derby"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preakness_Stakes", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Preakness Stakes"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photo_finish", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Photo finish"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NBC"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_H._Cox", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Brad H. {"uri": "8111783118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:43:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:43:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:41:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sports/sports-columnists/story/2024-05-04/kentucky-derby-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-forever-young", "title": "Bryce Miller: Thrill ride of a Kentucky Derby finish, unseen since 1947, crowns Mystik Dan", "body": "The 150th Kentucky Derby had to finish this way, right? It had to build the drama like an Mozartian opera, scorch the lungs for all their rose-covered worth and leave those in tow gasping in wide-eyed wonderment.\n\nA moment so historic, so wanting and ripe for theater, had to deliver a heart-stopping, jaw-dropping thrill ride of a finish. Predictable simply would not do. Mediocrity never would be allowed through the Central Avenue gates.\n\nA marvel, this one. As the trio of Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young bobbed and snorted to the verge of history, it became the closest three-way photo finish since 1947, when Holy Cross won the NCAA basketball crown.\n\nHoly Something, this.\n\nMystik Dan frantically finished this much better than Sierra Leone, the smallest of margins measureable in an endeavor with the deepest continuous roots in American sports.\n\nTwo minutes, 3.34 seconds of riveting, rollicking racing insanity.\n\n\"Unbelievable,\" winning jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. said.\n\nHas anything so unforgettable, so heart-pounding been so efficiently explained?\n\nSomething that started a mile-and-quarter earlier, a mile-and-quarter that began with hopes and dreams and breathtaking possibility, left a trio reaching and straining within a span of inches.\n\nThe top of the stretch became a seven-wide guessing game, keeping outcomes of all sizes, stripes and degrees of unlikelihood alive exhiliratingly late in a race that sits on mothballs for 364 days.\n\nThe elation of Myskik Dan trainer Kenny McPeek? Boundless.\n\nThe deflation of Sierra Leone counterpart Chad Brown? Derby sized.\n\n\"You get beat by a nose in the Kentucky Derby,\" he said, \"it's a tough one.\"\n\nThe victory came via a daring rail ride by Hernandez, who saved ground, stayed true and avoided the endless pitfalls of being inside during the most congested race of its kind.\n\nHe waited, endlessly patient. He pounced, at the absolute right time.\n\nHernandez eyeballed his moment in the second turn in front of 156,170 who leaned in to move closer to the glorious chaos beginning to unfold.\n\nThe burst felt like a slippery NFL running back squirting into the daylight.\n\n\"I had a nice little pocket there. I was like, 'Well, we'll just sit here and let them pile up,' \" Hernandez explained. \"Once Track Phantom move off the rail just a half a step, we were able to get through there. We might have taken out a little bit of the inside fence, but that's OK.\"\n\nThe dizzying crescendo at the finish caught everyone wondering how all this would be sorted, including and especially the winner.\n\n\"Right at the wire, they surged late and I was like, 'Oh, God, did we win the Kentucky Derby? (or not),\" said Hernandez, who asked the outrider who accompanied he and horse right after the race. \"That's a long two minutes. Yes, that was the longest two minutes in sports. The fastest two minutes and the longest.\"\n\nDid reaching back to 1947 fail to satisfy the way-back machine?\n\nWell, McPeek became the first trainer to win Friday's filly showcase Kentucky Oaks and the Derby the same weekend since fabled trainer Ben Jones with Real Delight and Hill Gail in 1952.\n\n\"Wow,\" said McPeek, to ask for his reaction to the dusty nugget. \"You know, wow.\"\n\nIt was more than simply the duel between Mystik Dan and Sierra Leone. As the runner-up and Forever Young charged and labor to contend, you couldn't slide a racing program between them at the frenzied finish.\n\nMystik Dan had seized the shortest route and built a cushion that initially looked as if it would continue growing into a crowning rather than a contest.\n\nThen, the thawing began.\n\nThe lead melted, first to interesting, then eye catching, finally and undeniably thrilling. The celebration, as uncertain and uncharted as it was, was preparing to begin.\n\n\"I have no idea yet,\" said Hernandez, asked for the plan. \"I've never won the Derby before.\"\n\nHernandez was supposed to take a 6 a.m. flight to New Orleans to attend Jazz Fest. He was quizzed about the probability he would make that flight.\n\nThe permanent postrace grin widened.\n\n\"I think we're going to have to reschedule now,\" he said.\n\nThe combination of Mystik Dan, Hernandez and McPeek left Louisville with $3 million of the record $5 million more. Add an immeasurable slice of history as part of the bounty.\n\nAt the heart of it, this wasn't about missing Southern California trainer Bob Baffert, the momentarily banished face of the sport. It wasn't about the disastrous Derby week of a year ago with dead horses and a deluge of questions. It wasn't about the darkening financial clouds that has pushed horse racing perilous close to the cliff's edge.\n\nIt was about what has made the Kentucky Derby the penultimate measuring stick of a sport that began in 1875, 10 years after the end of the Civil War.\n\nAnd Mystik Dan. The horse paid $39.22, but in the end the whole of it felt priceless.\n\nUnbelievable, Hernandez reminded us.\n\nHistory demands a flourish. Sometimes, like the first Saturday in May, it delivers. {"uri": "8111721782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:55:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:55:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:54:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/04/mystik-dan-southeast-arkansas-owned-horse-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-nose/", "title": "Mystik Dan, southeast Arkansas-owned horse, wins 150th Kentucky Derby by nose", "body": "It was only by a nose, but that was all it took for Mystik Dan to bring home a Kentucky Derby victory to southeast Arkansas.\n\nCo-owned by Star City farmer Lance Gasaway, Mystik Dan survived a late charge by Sierra Leone and Forever Young to win the first leg of horse racing's Triple Crown at Louisville, Ky., on Saturday in a photo finish. Gasaway, a former wide receiver at the University of Arkansas at Monticello, is part of the 4G Racing ownership team, which includes his cousin Brent Gasaway, Brent's wife Sharilyn Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III.\n\nMystik Dan, who had 18-1 odds coming into the Derby according to NBC Sports, paid $39.22 to win, $16.32 to place and $10 to show. Sierra Leone, the second favorite at 9/2 odds, paid $6.54 and $4.64 with a narrow runner-up finish, and Forever Young, at 7-1, paid $5.58 for third.\n\nBut the result wasn't confirmed until Churchill Downs released an official photo of the finish. Mystik Dan's nose reached the wire first, with Sierra Leone nearly beating him from the outside and Forever Young just an inch or so behind Sierra Leone.\n\n\"We felt perfectly confident we got the win,\" Lance Gasaway told NBC.\n\nMystik Dan jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., who won the Kentucky Oaks aboard Thorpedo Anna on Friday, probably sweated out the few minutes between the finish and final determination more.\n\n\"That was the longest few minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for the name and number above us,\" Hernandez told NBC. \"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won. It was a rush to sit here and wait for it.\"\n\nThe win came on a pair of significant anniversaries. Saturday's Kentucky Derby was the 150th running and also the first anniversary of the passing of Gasaway's father, Clint, who was 85.\n\n\"This is for him,\" Gasaway said, hoisting the winner's trophy. \"He's smiling down at us.\"\n\nMystik Dan, the winner of the Southwest Stakes at Oaklawn Park earlier this year, was the 17th qualifier for the Derby based on a points system Churchill Downs uses, but drew the No. 3 post, close to the inside. He stayed near the front of the pack, close to the rail, for most of the oval, but charged out to about a 2 \u00bd-length lead before Sierra Leone and Forever Young made their moves and narrowed the gap.\n\nThe next Triple Crown race is the Preakness Stakes in Baltimore on May 18, but Gasaway didn't exactly commit to the challenge. {"uri": "8112813379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:16:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:16:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:15:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/other/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_7c30f45d-06cb-5185-b2a0-2ceb2eb96339.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "GARY B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Sarah Kragthorpe, owner of Jitters, on moving the coffee shop Hinton woman boarded freight train rather than drive home drunk Family spokesman: Second autopsy of David Schultz planned, 'Don't feel comfortable with results' DEAR ABBY: Bitter son won't allow mom to find happiness Woodbury County Court Report for April 30, 2024 Paul Gausman's attorney claims $53,000 in fees for lawsuit against Sioux City school board Meet the ushers who help Sioux City's Orpheum Theatre move Sioux City cultural inclusion liaison settles lawsuit with USD North Sioux City propane explosion kills three in fire Blue Bunny, Jolly Time among Northwest Iowa products and companies vying for 'Coolest Thing Made in Iowa' Iowa Landscaping Company: 'Anything anybody can dream of, we can pretty much do.' Iowa homeowners age 65 and up are eligible for state tax exemption\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose\n\nA race fan sits in the stands Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, Associated {"uri": "8113178231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:22:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:22:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:22:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.zawya.com/en/life/sports/uae-derby-hero-forever-young-denied-historic-victory-in-150th-kentucky-derby-rj2gj1kg", "title": "UAE Derby hero Forever Young denied historic victory in 150th Kentucky Derby", "body": "The Japanese-owned galloper, who was looking to win a third colt's Classic, was beaten a close third in an absolute classic won by Mystik Dan\n\nJapan's hopes of pulling off an unprecedented global Derby treble were cruelly denied when Forever Young was narrowly beaten to third place in a spectacular 150th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.\n\nThe Japanese-bred son of Real Steel, who won the Saudi Derby and UAE Derby (G2) earlier this year, saw his chances suffer a significant setback when he was bumped by second-placed Sierra Leone in the crucial final two furlongs of the historic race.\n\nJockey Brian Hernandez Jr. had no such worries aboard Mystik Dan who travelled smoothly alongside the inside rail to hold on for the narrowest of victories in the sport - a short nose.\n\nSecond-favorite Sierra Leone, the mount of Tyler Gaffalione, got lucky at the line to edge Forever Young and his star Japanese rider Ryusei Sakai also by a nose.\n\nSakai enjoyed plenty of success in 2023 aboard Bathrat Leon, a multiple group stakes winner in Dubai and Saudi Arabia and made his Kentucky Derby debut in 2023 aboard Coninuar, third in the UAE Derby which was won by fellow Japanese runner Derma Sotogake.\n\nAfter the finish Hernandez, an American Eclipse Award-winning jockey and trainer Kenneth Peek, had to endure some anxious moments as the judges referred to the photo-finish camera before declaring Mystik Dan as the winner.\n\n\"That was the longest two minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up,\" Hernandez said during an interview on the track. \"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won.\"\n\nThe result appeared to energise the crowd of over 150,000 racegoers who had just witnessed another epic Kentucky Derby.\n\nLuck plays a big part in horse racing and jockey Hernandez said he was fortunate to find a tight gap on the inside rail as the field turned for home which put his horse in the clear.\n\n\"My horse, he was so game being up on the inside. I came through a really tight spot, we actually kind of climbed up on top of the rail a little bit,\" said Hernandez of his dangerous manoeuvre.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it. He shot off and I thought, 'Oh man, we have a chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nIt was an unforgettable weekend for trainer Kenneth McPeek and Hernandez who on Friday had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMcPeek became only the fourth trainer to land the prestigious double in the same year after Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek also hailed Hernandez saying he was \"probably one of the most under-rated riders in racing.\"\n\n\"But not anymore - right!\" McPeek exalted.\n\nopyright \u00a9 2022 Khaleej Times. {"uri": "8112798090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:55:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:55:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:55:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/other/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_5cc6dd71-7abc-5d01-88b6-ebbdc9862d23.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "GARY B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Dan Brady announces candidacy for Bloomington mayor Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church Normal man arrested in home invasion, sexual assault investigation Normal police investigating report of home invasion, sexual assault Suspect in Heartland college carjacking granted pretrial release 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Former Fairbury officer sentenced to 4 years in prison in sexual assault case Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Man waiting murder trial accused of contacting witness from McLean County Jail\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose\n\nA race fan sits in the stands Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, Associated {"uri": "8111798948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:07:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:07:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:06:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/mystik-dan-wins-2024-kentucky-025533708.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 2024 Kentucky Derby in a dramatic photo finish", "body": "Lightly regarded Mystik Dan scored a thrilling upset at the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, winning by a nose and bringing a career Triple Crown to trainer Kenny McPeek.\n\nRail-riding Mystik Dan stuck his snout in front of second favorite Sierra Leone and Forever Young for the dramatic three-horse photo-finish victory that took several minutes to hash out.\n\nHe was listed at 20-1 on the morning line and fans showed a little bit more faith in him, betting him down to 18-1 by the start.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if we had won,\" jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. told NBC Sports shortly after the race. \"So it was quite a rush to sit here and wait for it.\"\n\nMystik Dan came to Louisville with a relatively thin resume that included a third-place finish at the Arkansas Derby and a win at the Grade III Southwest Stakes.\n\nIt was the first Derby triumph for both McPeek and Hernandez. McPeek had previously trained filly Swiss Skydiver, the 2020 Preakness Stakes champion, and Sarava, long-shot winner of the 2002 Belmont Stakes.\n\nThe Derby win capped a remarkable 24 hours for McPeek and Hernandez, who teamed up with Thorpedo Anna to win the Kentucky Oaks on Friday.\n\nMcPeek effusively praised Hernandez and his ride.\n\nThe 3-1 favorite, Fierceness, came in 15th in the 20-horse field.\n\nHernandez, the son of a jockey and sibling of two other riders, recalled riding his bike as a 6-year-old, telling anyone who'd listen that someday he'd be a Kentucky Derby-winning jockey.\n\n\"This is a lifetime achievement,\" Hernandez said. \"This goes to our whole family.\"\n\nMystik Dan might have benefited from Sierra Leone and Forever Young bumping several times down the stretch as they desperately tried to down the leader and eventual winner.\n\n\"Oftentimes it's a game of inches,\" said Chad Brown, Sierra Leone's trainer.\n\nBrown said he was pleased with his horse's run Saturday, despite coming up a nose short.\n\n\"I'm so proud of his effort today. The horse did everything we asked him to do,\" Brown said. \"It just came up just a little bit short.\"\n\nMystik Dan's Triple Crown quest will continue on May 18 with the 149th running of the Preakness Stakes in Baltimore.\n\nBefore Saturday's 12th race at Churchill Downs unfolded, celebrities and big hats filled the clubhouse, grandstands and paddock under Louisville's famed twin spires.\n\nWynonna Judd performed the national anthem, leading a stable of boldface names from the entertainment world such as Sheryl Lee Ralph, Chris Tucker, Kid Rock, Jack Harlow, Jimmy Fallon, Travis Tritt, Josh Groban, Holly Robinson Peete and Richie Sambora.\n\nLifestyle maven Martha Stewart and football figures such as dateless Travis Kelce, Aaron Rodgers, Jameis Winston, Isiah Pacheco and Emmitt Smith were also in attendance.\n\nStewart gave the \"riders up\" call for jockeys to take their mounts.\n\nThe Derby day also included a host of other big-money races.\n\nLong shot Trikari rallied to a thrilling upset victory in the American Turf Stakes. The 47-1 dark horse roared past favorite Formidable Man in the final strides of the $600,000 race.\n\nGun Pilot pulled away to victory at the $1 million Churchill Downs Stakes, adding to the long winning resume of trainer Steve Asmussen.\n\nProgram Trading edged Naval Power to dramatically win the $1 million Turf Classic Stakes.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", Mystik Dan, though, held the inside right behind them.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nMystik Dan, ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr., busted through the pack after the final turn. After the turn, Fierceness fell way behind.\n\nMystik Dan led by several lengths in the final stretch, but Sierra Leone (9-2), the second-highest favorite, crept up from the outside, pushing Japanese horse Forever Young toward the railing.\n\nThose three horses were within noses of each other, but it was Mystik Dan's that crossed the line first.\n\nSierra Leone finished second and Forever Young finished third, while Fierceness finished 15th, 24\u00bd lengths behind.\n\nThis year's race came with much less controversy than last year's. A dozen horses died at Churchill Downs in the days, and even hours, leading up to last year's race.\n\nNotably absent from this year's race was Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert, who's two-year ban was extended through 2024, making this the third straight Kentucky Derby a Baffert-trained horse did not compete.\n\nA six-time winner at the Derby, Baffert was banned after 2021 Kentucky Derby winner Medina Spirit was stripped of the title due to a failed post-race drug test. {"uri": "8111767918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:16:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:16:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:14:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/horseracing/s-3231776", "title": "John Clay: 'I believe in mojo.' Trainer Kenny McPeek earns rare double in thrilling Derby photo finish.", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- For the 150th renewal, you could not have asked for a more thrilling Kentucky Derby.\n\nTrained by Lexingtonian Kenny McPeek, Mystik Dan edged hard-charging $2.3 million colt Sierra Leone and Japanese intruder Forever Young in a three-way photo finish by a nose (if that) to win a breathtaking Derby before 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nNot only did McPeek earn his first Kentucky Derby victory, in combination with Thorpedo Anna's win in the Kentucky Oaks on Friday, McPeek became the first trainer since the legendary Ben Jones in 1952 to pull off the Oaks/Derby double. Jones did it with Oaks winner Real Delight and Derby winner Hill Gail.\n\n\"Wow,\" said McPeek on Saturday when asked about the feat.\n\n\"For three weeks, I felt like we were going to win both races, I can't tell you why,\" said the trainer. \"I believe in mojo. I believe in positive energy and we had a lot of that.\"\n\nBrian Hernandez Jr. became the first jockey to win both the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby since Calvin Borel in 2009 on Rachel Alexandra in the Oaks and Mine That Bird in the Derby.\n\nA homebred owned by Arkansas' Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing, Daniel Hamby III and Valley View Farm, Mystik Dan won in a time of 2:03 3/5. At odds of 18-1, he paid $39.22 to win, $16.32 to place and $10 to show. The son of Goldencents had won the Southwest Stakes by 8 lengths on a muddy track at Oaklawn on Feb. 3, but had finished third behind Muth and Just Steel in the Arkansas Derby at Oaklawn on May 30.\n\n\"I'm pinching myself, wondering if this is real,\" Gasaway said. \"You just won the biggest horse race in America. Who would have dreamed it.\"\n\nThe 61-year-old McPeek won the 2002 Belmont Stakes with Sarava and the 2020 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver, but was 0 for 9 in his home state's famous race. His best finish was second with Tejano Run all the way back in 1995.\n\nIt was a heartbreaking loss for the connections of Sierra Leone, who had won the Toyota Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland on April 6.
