{"uri": "8111707911", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:31:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:31:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:31:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/horse-racing/news/brian-hernandez-mystik-dan-kentucky-derby-jockey-winner/b1f845c717ba247b63c12438", "title": "Who is Brian Hernandez? What to know about Mystik Dan's Kentucky Derby-winning jockey", "body": "Led by his humble steed -- and a smart bit of strategy -- Brian Hernandez etched his name in Kentucky Derby history Saturday night.\n\nThe Louisiana native took his place among the stars in eye-catching fashion, leading Mystik Dan to glory with a photo finish at the 2024 iteration of the Run for the Races. It couldn't have been any closer -- Mystik Dan just outpaced Sierra Leone and Forever Young to capture the gold.\n\n\"This is unbelievable,\" Hernandez said. \"That was the longest few minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up. ... It's hard to put into words.\"\n\nIn the process, Hernandez added to his family's rich legacy in the world of horse racing. To reach a career summit after 20 years as a jockey is one thing. To do so when riding swirls in your blood is an entirely different proposition.\n\nWith that, here's what you need to know about Hernandez, one of just eight jockeys to capture both the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby in the same year.\n\nMORE: How much prize money does the Kentucky Derby winner get in 2024?\n\nHernandez spearheaded Mystik Dan's ascent to the upper echelons of racing lore, pushing his thoroughbred out in front with frantic instructions. Hernandez's impressive tactical acumen, coupled with his charger's natural athleticism, that brought trainer Kenny McPeek and owners Lance Gasaway, Daniel Hamby and 4G Racing to victory lane.\n\nHe isn't entirely new to making history. Hernandez led stallion Fort Larned to victory in the 2012 Breeders' Cup Classic. He also has an Eclipse Award for Outstanding Apprentice Jockey in his treasure chest. That chest got a whole lot glitzier Saturday, however, when he raced out in front and held off menacing runs by Sierra Leone and Forever Young to take his place in the history books.\n\n\"Around the far turn, my horse was so game being up on the inside,\" Hernandez said after the race. \"I came through a really tight spot and we kind of climbed up on top of the rail a bit. When he shot through that spot and was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it, he shot off. I was like, 'Oh man, we have a shot to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nHernandez isn't the first member of his family to find joy atop the back of a thoroughbred. That status belongs to his father, Brian Sr., who enjoyed a lengthy if unspectacular career as a rider in the southern Louisiana horse-racing circuit.\n\nAnd he's not the only family member to follow in his father's footsteps. His brother, Colby and sister, Courtney, also gravitated to the the stables, earning $58.1 million and $1.2 million in career earnings, respectively.\n\n\"This is a lifetime achievement, this goes to our whole family,\" Hernandez said. \"To be able to live that dream that I had when I was a 6-year-old kid, riding my bike around my grandparents farm and telling them I was going to win the Kentucky Derby one day, well, here we are.\"\n\nThe win for Mystik Dan at the Kentucky Derby cemented the first Kentucky Oaks-Kentucky Derby double by a jockey since 2009. It came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna by 4 \u00be lengths that led to a Kentucky Oaks win.\n\nThe 38-year-old became the first jockey since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel completed the Derby/Oaks double in 2009.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby has been surreal for Hernandez. He recalled wanting to win the \"greatest two minutes in sports\" as something he's yearned for since he was a child.\n\nRELATED: How Mystik Dan held off Sierra Leone, Forever Young in dramatic Kentucky Derby finish\n\n\"I always dreamed of winning the Kentucky Derby when I my my grandparents have a photo of me when I was six years old,\" he said. \"I used to ride around in my dad's jock pants on my bicycle [and] tell him I was gonna win the Kentucky Derby someday. So to to be able to do this with uh, with Kenny [McPeek] and all our family here it was. It's unbelievable.\"\n\nThe Kentucky Derby shared the adorable childhood photo of Hernandez on their X profile on Sunday with a caption \"dreams do come true.\"\n\n\"This is the weekend that I don't think a Disney movie can be made of. {"uri": "8112817051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:21:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:21:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:20:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://uk.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/mystik-dan-triumphs-at-kentucky-derby-marking-third-consecutive-year-horse-with-151-odds-or-worse-wins-race-3474558", "title": "Mystik Dan Triumphs At Kentucky Derby, Marking Third Consecutive Year Horse With 15-1 Odds Or Worse Wins Race By Benzinga", "body": "Benzinga - by Bibhu Pattnaik, Benzinga Staff Writer.\n\nIn a dramatic finish, Mystik Dan, under the guidance of jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., secured the victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby on Saturday.\n\nWhat Happened: The race, which took place at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky, saw Mystik Dan narrowly triumph over Sierra Leone and Forever Young in one of the Derby's tightest finishes ever.\n\nThe Associated Press reported that this is the 10th time in the Derby's history that the race has been decided by a nose, the smallest margin in horse racing.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged out Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third. Sierra Leone, the race's most expensive horse, was valued at $2.3 million.\n\nThe result was so close that officials took several minutes to confirm Mystik Dan's win.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" is how Brian Hernandez Jr., Mystik Dan's jockey, described the wait for the result.\n\nThe winner claimed the largest share of the $5 million purse, amounting to $3.1 million. The race drew a crowd of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest since 2018.\n\nAlso Read: Virtual Horse Racing Game Photo Finish Announces New Funding - Meet The Investors And Next Steps\n\nThis victory marks a significant milestone for Hernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek, who also achieved success in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nFierceness, a 3-1 favorite, finished in 15th place.\n\nWhy It Matters: The Kentucky Derby has a history of surprising outcomes. NBC Connecticut reported Rich Strike's victory in 2022, the second-biggest upset in derby history.\n\nStrike overcame 80-1 odds to beat the field at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe race also has a notorious jinx associated with the No. 17 post position, which has never produced a winner in 149 previous derbies.\n\nMoreover, the derby has faced controversies in recent years. In 2022, trainer Bob Baffert sued Churchill Downs over a two-year ban following the disqualification of his horse, Medina Spirit, for failing a drug test after winning the 2021 derby.\n\nThe 2023 derby also saw the death of several horses at Churchill Downs, casting a shadow over Mage's victory.\n\nNow Read: EXCLUSIVE -- Kentucky Derby Fans Can Score $100K Prize With Web3-Powered SuperFecta Scratch-Off\n\nThis content was partially produced with the help of Benzinga Neuro and was reviewed and published by Benzinga editors.\n\nPhoto: Shutterstock", "source": {"uri": "uk.investing.com", {"uri": "8112797591", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:54:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:54:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:54:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://qctimes.com/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_089ee2cf-226b-54ce-a82c-1ae9fdb69160.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "GARY B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Davenport man was under surveillance, subject of investigation before he was killed Unidentified company considering Davenport for $800 million data center Victims identified from Sunday I-80 crash in Scott County Scott County Jail overcrowding sends Davenport double homicide suspect to Muscatine Pleasant Valley staff, school board member admonished by state campaign ethics board Eve's Garden and Greenhouse comes to fruition in old Friday's Market spot in Davenport Pending Death Notices for the Quad-Cities, April 30, 2024 Peoria man dead, two others injured after crash on I-80 in Scott County Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Fareway, Express Factory Outlet, McDonald's Search warrant: Davenport duo accused of double murder were ready to 'shoot it out with the police' 288 new apartments going up in Bettendorf near TBK Bank Sports Complex Two arrested in connection to December death in rural Sherrard Davenport woman with ties to slain man faces drug charges Iowa homeowners age 65 and up are eligible for state tax exemption Pending Death Notices for the Quad-Cities, May 1, 2024\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose\n\nRace fans watch a race Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, Associated "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/qctimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/d6/3d692be8-48d1-578c-9585-98ceefc8cd59/6637eecd68fa7.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539947", "eventUri": "eng-9539947", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-18", "textStart": 393, "textEnd": {"uri": "8111738946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:25:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:25:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:24:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-the-closest-3-horse-photo/article_1c6a97d6-ef29-5e5f-b23f-24dc18f54850.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947", "body": "By BETH HARRIS - AP Racing Writer\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx, who was another head in front of Faultless.\n\nThis one was much tighter.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hard Rock ramping up hiring efforts Former UVA Wise College Board Member Gives $1 Million to school COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Ian Scammell (Grundy) gets time to shine in UVa-Wise Spring Game NASCAR: The Bluefield Boys have found a niche in NASCAR PREP BASEBALL: Falcons finish season sweep of John Battle Nominations reach 29 for Gene \"Pappy\" Thompson Award PREP FOOTBALL: Sullivan East's Laisure felt a higher calling led him to Colorado TUESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Brandon Edwards (J.I. Burton), Matthew Nunley (Honaker), Tyler Hash (Tazewell), Maya Owens (Holston), Reagan Evans (Rural Retreat), Erin Rasnake (Lebanon), Taylor Preston (Marion), Braelyn Scammell (Patrick Henry), Chase Wolfenbarger (Tennessee High) among notable performers THURSDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Abingdon (baseball), John Battle (softball) clinch Mountain 7 District titles; Tennessee High girls tennis team claims district crown; Lee High baseball team scores 29 runs; Trajan Cannon (Patrick Henry), Kailyn Breeding and Cooper Hurst (Richlands) also among stars MONDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Ashton Leonard and Carly Compton (Tennessee High), Connor Smith (Chilhowie), Jed McCoy (Eastside), Eli Hucks (Virginia High), Collyn Neff (Union), MJ Musser (Holston) , Jordan Frazier (J.I. Burton), Julia Barton (Honaker) among stars WEDNESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Blair Rutherford and Alex Brown (Patrick Henry), Taylor Childress (John Battle), Emmaleigh Banks (Eastside), Will Rollins (Rye Cove), Ella Moss (Marion), Madyson Doss (Sullivan East), Hayden Baker (Ridgeview) among stars LOCALS IN COLLEGE NOTES: UVa's Matthew Buchanan (Lebanon) enjoyed thrill of pitching at Fenway Park MOTORSPORTS: Stanley is a hometown hero at Lonesome Pine PREP BASEBALL: Abingdon gets 2-0 verdict over Virginia High as freshman catcher Judge Dillow, strong pitching overrule Bearcats HIGH SCHOOL BASEBALL: Chilhowie extends perfect mark in the Hogoheegee District\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Chad Brown, trainer of Sierra Leone. \"But I'm so proud of the horse.\"\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed for a wire-to-wire win in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna. McPeek is the first trainer to sweep both races since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek's only other victory in a Triple Crown race was also a shocker: 70-1 Sarava won the 2002 Belmont Stakes -- the biggest upset in that race's history. The colt spoiled the Triple Crown bid of War Emblem.\n\nThe winning owners are cousins Lance and Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby III, all from Arkansas. They bred Mystik Dan.\n\n\"We've done it with what I call working-class horse,\" McPeek said, explaining the colt's sire and dam weren't big names.\n\nSharilyn Gasaway, Brent's wife, said, \"It is surreal for sure. We feel like we're just ordinary people and we've got an amazing horse.\"\n\nSierra Leone returned $6.54 and $4.64. Forever Young was another nose back in third and paid $5.58 to show.\n\nCatching Freedom was fourth, followed by T O Password of Japan, Resilience, Stronghold, Honor Marie and Endlessly. Dornoch was 10th and then came Track Phantom, West Saratoga, Domestic Product, Epic Ride, Fierceness, Society Man, Just Steel, Grand Mo the First, Catalytic and Just a Touch.\n\nAP horse racing: https://apnews.com/hub/horse-racing\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8112115235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:09:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:09:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:09:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/sports/uae-derby-hero-forever-young-denied-historic-victory-in-150th-kentucky-derby", "title": "UAE Derby hero Forever Young denied historic victory in 150th Kentucky Derby", "body": "Japan's hopes of pulling off an unprecedented global Derby treble were cruelly denied when Forever Young was narrowly beaten to third place in a spectacular 150th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.\n\nThe Japanese-bred son of Real Steel, who won the Saudi Derby and UAE Derby (G2) earlier this year, saw his chances suffer a significant setback when he was bumped by second-placed Sierra Leone in the crucial final two furlongs of the historic race.\n\nJockey Brian Hernandez Jr. had no such worries aboard Mystik Dan who travelled smoothly alongside the inside rail to hold on for the narrowest of victories in the sport - a short nose.\n\nSecond-favorite Sierra Leone, the mount of Tyler Gaffalione, got lucky at the line to edge Forever Young and his star Japanese rider Ryusei Sakai also by a nose.\n\nSakai enjoyed plenty of success in 2023 aboard Bathrat Leon, a multiple group stakes winner in Dubai and Saudi Arabia and made his Kentucky Derby debut in 2023 aboard Coninuar, third in the UAE Derby which was won by fellow Japanese runner Derma Sotogake.\n\nAfter the finish Hernandez, an American Eclipse Award-winning jockey and trainer Kenneth Peek, had to endure some anxious moments as the judges referred to the photo-finish camera before declaring Mystik Dan as the winner.\n\n\"That was the longest two minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up,\" Hernandez said during an interview on the track. \"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won.\"\n\nThe result appeared to energise the crowd of over 150,000 racegoers who had just witnessed another epic Kentucky Derby.\n\nLuck plays a big part in horse racing and jockey Hernandez said he was fortunate to find a tight gap on the inside rail as the field turned for home which put his horse in the clear.\n\n\"My horse, he was so game being up on the inside. I came through a really tight spot, we actually kind of climbed up on top of the rail a little bit,\" said Hernandez of his dangerous manoeuvre.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it. He shot off and I thought, 'Oh man, we have a chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nIt was an unforgettable weekend for trainer Kenneth McPeek and Hernandez who on Friday had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMcPeek became only the fourth trainer to land the prestigious double in the same year after Ben Jones in 1952.\n\nMcPeek also hailed Hernandez saying he was \"probably one of the most under-rated riders in racing.\"", "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khaleej times"}, "authors": [{"uri": win.\n\nAfter the race, McPeek gave credit to Hernandez for his performance.\n\n\"Brian just did an amazing job,\" he said. \"I mean, just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride.\"\n\n\"Probably one of the most underrated riders in racing, but not anymore,\" he added.\n\nWhen asked about his accomplishment of winning the Oaks and the Derby in the same year, McPeek {"uri": "2024-05-345885139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:17:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:17:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:14:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://dailytimes.com.pk/1192246/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-thriller/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby thriller", "body": "Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby on Saturday, snatching victory over Sierra Leone at the wire in a scintillating first leg of US flat racing's Triple Crown at Churchill Downs.\n\nTrained by Kenny McPeek and ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr., Mystik Dan squeezed through on the inside going into the final straight and held off -- by less than a nose -- the late charges by second-favorite Sierra Leone and Japanese raider Forever Young with a photo needed to sort out the order.\n\nAfter the fury of the race, McPeek and Hernandez had to wait several minutes to see their horse, who went off at 18-1, confirmed as the winner.\n\n\"That was the longest two minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\n\"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won.\"\n\nFierceness, the pre-race favorite trained by Todd Pletcher and ridden by John Velazquez, challenged around the final turn but faded late to finish 15th in the field of 20.\n\nThe exciting finish capped a celebratory week at Churchill Downs, where last year's Kentucky Derby was overshadowed by a string of horse deaths that reached 12 before racing was shut down last June.", "source": {"uri": "dailytimes.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sajid_salamat@dailytimes.com.pk", "name": "Sajid Salamat", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Hernandez_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Brian Hernandez Jr."}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Thoroughbred_Racing_(United_States)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Triple Crown {"uri": "8111796287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:03:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:03:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:02:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5472117/2024/05/04/mystik-dan-2024-kentucky-derby-winner-150th/", "title": "The people and moments that made Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The thing about a life-changing event that takes two minutes to finish: every move, every decision, even every non-decision matters. Except it's not just the moves, the decisions and the non-decisions made in those two minutes that matter; it's a lifetime of split-decision choices that combine to create a life and, in one case on a muggy Saturday evening, make history.\n\nTo unspool the story of Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan's historic run along the rail and into the record books requires far more than a rewind around the Churchill Downs track. It includes a decision to not bail on a dinner date 30-plus years ago and a hunt for bloodstock information in the basement of a college library years before even that. It necessitates a commitment to a would-have-been retired mare and a father convincing his son to fall in love with horse racing. It requires one jockey to study another rail-riding rider, and a partnership between a collection of people who compete with the big names but intentionally never cared about being one of them.\n\nOn the historic 150th running of this race, Mystik Dan delivered a breath-holding finish, beating second-place Sierra Leone and third-place Forever Young in the first three-horse photo finish since 1947. So close was the finish, not even winning jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. was certain what happened, asking an outrider as he eased Mystik Dan if he'd won the Kentucky Derby.\n\nIt took an agonizing five minutes for the answer to arrive, the 156,710 spectators on hand going from euphoric as the three horses neared the wire to near-stunned silence as they, like the jockey, awaited the decision.\n\nFinally, Mystik Dan's name flashed on the big board, the crowd in the stands whooping in joy, the outrider sharing the news with Hernandez. \"It took about two minutes, and then finally when they said, 'Yeah, you've just won the Kentucky Derby, I was like, 'Oh wow, that's a long two minutes. That was the longest two minutes in sports -- from the fastest two minutes to the longest by far.''\n\nPerhaps the only person not surprised was trainer Ken McPeek. The Kentucky-based trainer practically made like Babe Ruth and called his shot all week. On Friday, when he sat at a press conference to celebrate his Kentucky Oaks winner Thorpedo Anna, it was suggested that perhaps he'd return for another winning presser the next day. \"Count on it,'' he said. When the promise was delivered, McPeek celebrated on the track, holding his daughter Annie's hand tight.\n\nBy combining the winning ride with that of Thorpedo Anna, McPeek became the first trainer since Ben Jones in 1952 to win the Kentucky Oaks-Kentucky Derby double, and Hernandez the first jockey to do so since Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nIt is fitting that Hernandez matched Borel. In the longer view of this race, the one that makes more like \"It's A Wonderful Life\" and considers how even the most inconsequential of decisions lead to an epic life, it was Borel that Hernandez cued up on the videos to study. Borel was known around the track as Calvin Bo-Rail for his love and comfort with riding along the rail, a spot plenty of jockeys would prefer to avoid. When Mystik Dan drew post position three, Hernandez and McPeek started talking about how they might be able to turn what plenty envisioned as a disadvantage into an advantage. Hernandez discovered the secret sauce in the recaps of Borel's rides.\n\nIn the immediate here and now, in the 2:03.34 it took Mystik Dan to cover the 1 \u00bc miles, the race was won because Hernanedez Jr. steered the horse on a brilliant ride. He followed Track Phantom along the rail, and when the lead horse gave him a half-step's worth of room, he squeezed Mystik Dan through the narrow space that opened like the sliver of light beneath a doorframe, holding on to the finish line to win by a nose. Favorite Fierceness finished 15th.\n\nBut this race was won long before Hernandez cued up the video. It was won some 40 years ago when a young McPeek buried himself in the University of Kentucky agriculture library to educate himself on BloodHorse and thoroughbred records. Taken to Keeneland by his grandfather, McPeek never saw himself doing much else other than horse racing. He jokes that his ag library basement studies might have resulted in better grades than his normal coursework, but it's only because it fed a passion.\n\nAll that studying and poking around, though, created a sort of horse-racing Everyman. He prefers to touch every bit of horse racing and is respected as much as a bloodstock agent as a trainer. He even created an app -- Horses Now -- for replays. He's a big believer in the industry, well-liked and well-respected among his peers for his loyalty and decency and his willingness to keep things simple. Horse racing is a big business, and an expensive one, the animals often owned by conglomerates over individuals. McPeek has purposefully tried to eschew that approach. \"I think what I'm most proud of is, we didn't do with Calumet Farm horses,'' he said, citing the big-breeding conglomerate in Lexington. \"We did it with working-class horses.''\n\nMcPeek trained Mystik Dan's mare, Ma'am, and when she neared retirement, he convinced Lance, Brent and Sharilyn Gasaway not to retire her but to breed her with Goldencents, a 2013 Derby entrant. That they agreed goes to the trust the owners put in McPeek, but also back to their own horse-racing roots and their little moments that led them to a small-ish racehorse with the biggest of wins.\n\nLance Gasaway, you might argue, is the Mystik Dan of college football. That is to say, perhaps a tad overlooked. A record holder and Hall of Famer, he starred not at Arkansas but at Arkansas-Monticello, where he was an NAIA All-American for the Boll Weevils. He got into horse racing at the urging of his dad, Clint, the two partnering at Oaklawn, their home track. Their biggest and best shot at the limelight came with Wells Bayou, who won the Louisiana Derby and was targeted for the Kentucky Derby until COVID struck and moved the race to September.\n\nClint died about a year ago, and as Lance sat on the dais, he got more than a little choked up when he recalled his father's influence. \"To me, this is for him,'' he said. \"Dad would have loved it. He loved the game.'' But a few years ago, back when Ma'am was about to be retired, Clint decided he was getting too old to get into breeding horses. Lance opted to bring in his first cousin, Brent.\n\nThirty-five years ago, Brent was meant to meet his now-wife Sharilyn for a date, but he was late. And then later. Turns out he was at the track, still at the races. Sharilyn was less than thrilled -- at least until Brent that night popped the question. When Sharilyn quit her full-time job, the couple opted to get into horse racing full-time, about the same time that Clint and Lance got into the game. When Lance needed a new partner for breeding and, eventually, in the ownership of Mystik Dan, Sharilyn and Brent made perfect sense.\n\nSitting side-by-side, sandwiched between McPeek and Hernandez, Lance and Sharilyn both seemed a bit wide-eyed and happily dazed. Asked how they might celebrate, Lance deadpanned, \"I don't know. I never won the Derby before.''\n\nNeither had McPeek. But now, with his own Triple Crown -- he won the Preakness in 2020 with Swiss Skydiver and the Belmont in 2002 with Sarqva -- he at least had an inkling. \"I'm going to go back to the barn and hug all the staff and all the family,'' he said. \"And then my house is wide open if anyone wants to come over.''\n\nMystik Dan may have won the Derby in two minutes of maneuvering, but it took a million smaller moments to create the masterpiece.", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Athletic"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dana_o_neil@theathletic.com", "name": "Dana O'Neil", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8112701895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "18:54:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T18:54:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:53:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/uncertain-plans-for-150th-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-others-leave-questions-for-preakness/MVSJY5U4UVGGVN7KYNUFIH4WPE/", "title": "Uncertain plans for 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "Trainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dayton Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", {"uri": "8111792215", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:56:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/kentucky-derby-victory-aboard-mystik-dan-provides-signature-win-for-jockey-brian-hernandez-jr/article_fe5d3858-38a6-5391-a98a-1e5cbf112128.html", "title": "Kentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr. celebrates in the winner's circle after riding Mystik Dan to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Brian Hernandez Jr. will need a minute to digest his signature victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nMaybe even more time since the milestone derby capped the best weekend of a jockey career spent mostly under the radar.\n\nThe Louisiana native rode Mystik Dan to an epic win Saturday at Churchill Downs, sliding past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and holding off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish. Hernandez wasn't even sure he had won until seeing the replay and keeping his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop.\n\n\"I'm like, woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,\" the 38-year-old said. \"But then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn't really see them. And then they surged so quickly.\n\n\"I was like, 'Oh man, I hope we won. I hope we won.' And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nHernandez's derby victory aboard Mystik Dan at 18-1 odds came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire rout by 4 3/4 lengths in the 150th Kentucky Oaks. That made him the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel achieved the feat aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra, respectively, in 2009. Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez added. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn.\n\n\"I don't know how long it's going to take to sink in. It's definitely a surreal moment.\"\n\nHernandez's victory was fitting since he studied Borel's derby wins aboard Mine That Bird and Super Saver (2010), along with being around him during 20 years of racing in Kentucky. Those lessons paid off as he broke through after four derby finishes ranging from eighth to 12th, including 11th last May on Sun Thunder.\n\nHis seminal moment shouldn't have been shocking considering Hernandez already had an Eclipse Award to his name as top apprentice rider in 2004 along with a Breeders' Cup Classic win in 2012 with Fort Larned. He also was third in the Preakness two years ago with Creative Minister and has a slew of graded stakes wins.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby brings a whole different type of recognition, along with a sparkling title that will precede Hernandez for the rest of his life. McPeek asserted immediately afterward that the rider can no longer be considered underrated after a \"brilliant\" ride and called the gutsy inside path taken to victory typical for the jockey.\n\n\"He knows what to do there,\" McPeek said. \"I always had a world of confidence in him. Rarely second-guess anything he does.\"\n\nHowever, the victory created a travel issue for Hernandez, who had planned on head to Louisiana on Sunday morning for a jazz festival. It's a switch he was more than willing to make after two remarkable days that demonstrated what the right mounts can yield.\n\n\"You know, it's horse racing, it's not jockey racing,\" said Hernandez, who planned to celebrate with his wife on Saturday night. \"Just about any jockey out there, if they have the right horse, they can get them to the winner's circle. You just you have to be willing to put in the time and the effort to find the right horses.\"\n\nThis story has been corrected to show Hernandez had one Breeders' Cup victory, not two.\n\nAP Kentucky Derby coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/kentucky-derby", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "gary_b_graves@eagletribune.com", "name": "Gary B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose\n\nRace fans watch a race Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, Associated {"uri": "8113560945", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:04:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:04:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:03:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.nola.com/news/will-kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan-run-in-preakness/article_895b1adc-0b0a-11ef-a176-5f515a68df69.html", "title": "'A surreal feeling:' Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan's owners look to future races", "body": "Sharilyn Gasaway, Shreveport native and one of the owners of Mystik Dan, told The Shreveport-Bossier Advocate Sunday afternoon that they haven't decided yet if Mystik Dan will run in the Preakness, because it will be \"all about the health of the horse.\"\n\nMystik Dan, Lafayette jockey bring Kentucky Derby win home to Louisiana in photo finish\n\nShe saw Mystic Dan the morning after the Derby and said he was bright-eyed and seemed very happy and content \"or maybe he just wanted more peppermints,\" she laughed. He will get walked Sunday and then slowly work up to training again.\n\nAbout having the winning horse of the Kentucky Derby, she said it's \"still kind of a surreal feeling, starting to sink in a bit.\"\n\nAlong with her husband, Brent, the other owners are Lance Gasaway, Daniel Hamby III, and Valley Wire Farm.\n\nThe jockey was Brian Joseph Hernandez, Jr. from Lafayette and the trainer is Kenneth G. McPeek.\n\nIf Mystik Dan runs in the Preakness, she said Hernandez will be the jockey. Hernandez rode Mystik Dan for all of the Kentucky Derby preliminary races.\n\nThe Preakness is two weeks away. The last time Mystik Dan ran within two weeks of a big race, he ended up with a lung infection that had to be treated with antibiotics and rest. She said the team doesn't want something like that to happen to Mystik Dan again.\n\nThe veterinarians will be evaluating and watching Mystik Dan carefully now, especially his food intake, which she said can show a lot about how a horse feels.\n\nDeciding on the Preakness will be a last minute decision, she said. \"We want to do right by the horse.\"\n\n\"We're just so blessed with this horse. He's super talented, nothing we did,\" she said. \"You can try and put together the best mix,\" she said referring to selective breeding, \"but God's ultimately in control.\"\n\nTwelve years ago, Sharilyn and Brent bought their first horse which he named after her, \"Sharilyn Jean.\" That horse broke its maiden at a $10,000 claiming race. {"uri": "2024-05-345276270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:26:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:26:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:24:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://eu.courier-journal.com/story/sports/columnists/c-l-brown/2024/05/04/mystik-dan-trainer-kenny-mcpeek-kentucky-derby-2024-churchill-downs/73105051007/", "title": "Kenny McPeek sweeps at Churchill Downs: Trainer wins Kentucky Derby and Kentucky Oaks 150", "body": "Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to win the Kentucky Oaks and Kentucky Derby in the same year since 1952 thanks to Mystik Dan's electric photo finish in the 150th Run for the Roses.\n\nMcPeek won Friday's Oaks with Thorpedo Anna. He'd boasted earlier in the week that he wouldn't be surprised if he won both races. He was that confident in both his horses. Mystik Dan defied his post draw in winning.\n\nSince Ferdinand won in 1986 from Gate 1, only Real Quiet in Post 3 had won after breaking from the first three posts. Mystik Dan joined that short list.\n\nSome might say the Derby was won well before the 20-horse field took to the track Saturday at Churchill Downs.\n\nLike McPeek, there were a lot of trainers looking for their first win in the Derby. McPeek finished second the first time he had an entrant in the Derby with Tejano Run in 1995.\n\nEven Bill Mott and Brad Cox, who are Derby winners, were seeking that elation that comes from seeing your horse come in first. Both were awarded Derby wins when the first-place horse was disqualified. Mott won in 2019 with Country House after Maximum Security was disqualified for interference. Cox won with Mandaloun in 2021 after Medina Spirit failed a drug test.\n\nTodd Pletcher and D. Wayne Lukas were the only trainers entering the race who had experienced crossing the finish line first in the Derby.\n\nWith six-time winner Bob Baffert -- who is tied with Ben Jones for the most Kentucky Derby wins -- serving another year suspension at Churchill Downs, it secured an open door for the first-timers to have a chance at it.\n\nIt also helped that Amr Zedan, owner of Muth, opted against transferring his horse from Baffert to another trainer in order to compete in the Derby. Muth had won his last two races including the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby, where he beat Kentucky Derby entrants Just Steel and Mystik Dan.\n\nThe draws also created some luck for the field, as the favorites Fierceness and Sierra Leone were positioned in what, historically, have been difficult posts to win the Derby from.\n\nNo horse had ever won from the 17 post, which Fierceness was initially slated to start. He avoided having to fight history when he moved up to No. 16 after Encino scratched, but it still was not the ideal place for him. Sierra Leone's knack for coming from behind nearly came to fruition despite having to break from the No. 2 post.\n\nAll of those moments created the opening for Mystik Dan to ride right through and secure Kentucky Derby 150 for McPeek.", "source": {"uri": "courier-journal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Courier-Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Oaks", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Oaks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epsom_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Epsom Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_trainer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Horse trainer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Churchill_Downs", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Churchill Downs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_(horse)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ferdinand (horse)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Run_for_the_Roses_(song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Run for the Roses (song)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Quiet", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Real Quiet"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_I._Mott", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "William I. {"uri": "8112794568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:50:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:50:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:50:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/other/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_acd4e3e5-1a3b-55e8-8492-50d824a7dbf5.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Former McDowell man serving life sentence for murder killed in prison McDowell shortstop Eli Elliott signs to play with Ferrum College City of Marion announces new city clerk Former McDowell High School counselor charged with sex acts on a student makes court appearance McDowell family grateful for help during girl's medical crisis Work begins to renovate McDowell County's Rec Center Man charged with driving vehicle of dead man Man sentenced to prison for second-degree murder in Marion Marion couple charged with child abuse appear in court A heckler tried to derail Trevor Noah's speech at Wake Forest University. He answered her question Alumni Spotlight: Ceara Carmack Couple charged by McDowell Sheriff's Office with theft Leading the way: McDowell softball seniors come through one more time as championship nears Appalachian State football player Jack Murphy dies Victim, suspect in Monday shooting in Marion still hospitalized\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose\n\nRace fans watch a race Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, Associated {"uri": "8113654781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:04:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:04:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/horse-racing/kentucky-derby-wwe-mcpeek-belt-32744613", "title": "WWE award special wrestling belts to winners of 150th Kentucky Derby", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr (left) and Kenny McBeek with Mystik Dan show off their WWE belts\n\nThe winners of the 150th Kentucky Derby have received an unexpected additional honour.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr pulled out off one of the greatest feats in horse racing at the weekend.\n\nThey combined to win the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna on Friday at Churchill Downs.\n\nThen 24 hours later they landed the big one, the Kentucky Derby, after Mystik Dan prevailed in a three-way photo-finish, the first for 77 years.\n\nMcPeek became the first trainer to complete the double since Ben Jones in 1952 while Hernandez emulated Calvin Borel who won both races in 2009.\n\nOn Sunday after receiving the traditional garland of roses, the McPeek barn were handed another memento.\n\nA representative of WWE, World Wrestling Entertainment, delivered specially made champions' belts.\n\n\"In recent years we have been presenting a championship to the champions of sport at the highest level across the United States and the world,,\" said the representative.\n\n\"It's my honour to present you guys these customised Kentucky Derby 150th running champion undisputed championships for the undisputed champion of the Kentucky Derby. We've got a horse bridle version here as well as our normal version there.\"\n\nThe Kentucky Derby is the first leg of the US Triple Crown but the chance of Mystik Dan heading to Pimlico for the next leg, the Preakness Stakes, appear slim.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" said McPeek. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me.\n\n\"We'll just watch him over the next week. {"uri": "8111922680", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:51:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:51:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:50:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-thriller-1821656.html", "title": "Mystik Dan Wins 150th Kentucky Derby Thriller - UrduPoint", "body": "Louisville, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 5th May, 2024) Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby on Saturday, snatching victory over Sierra Leone at the wire in a scintillating first leg of US flat racing's Triple Crown at Churchill Downs.\n\nTrained by Kenny McPeek and ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr., Mystik Dan squeezed through on the inside going into the final straight and held off -- by less than a nose -- the late charges by second-favorite Sierra Leone and Japanese raider Forever Young with a photo needed to sort out the order.\n\nAfter the fury of the race, McPeek and Hernandez had to wait several minutes to see their horse, who went off at 18-1, confirmed as the winner.\n\n\"That was the longest two minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to hang that number up,\" Hernandez said.\n\n\"It was exciting when we hit the wire, but I wasn't sure if we won.\"\n\nFierceness, the pre-race favorite trained by Todd Pletcher and ridden by John Velazquez, challenged around the final turn but faded late to finish 15th in the field of 20.\n\nThe exciting finish capped a celebratory week at Churchill Downs, where last year's Kentucky Derby was overshadowed by a string of horse deaths that reached 12 before racing was shut down last June.\n\nThis year, the storied venue not only unveiled a sparkling new paddock enclosure but added 2,200 tons of new dirt to the track as part of wide-ranging safety changes made after an investigation by the Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority (HISA) found no one cause for the deaths.\n\nAll appeared to go smoothly and safely on Saturday, the crowd of nearly 157,000 treated to a classic racing spectacle.\n\nHernandez credited his win to his move through a tight gap on the inside rail as they turned for home.\n\n\"My horse, he was so game being up on the inside. I came through a really tight spot, we actually kind of climbed up on top of the rail a little bit,\" said Hernandez, who said his boot actually brushed the rail.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it. He shot off and I thought, 'Oh man, we have a chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said, calling Hernandez \"probably one of the most under-rated riders in racing.\"\n\n\"But not anymore - right!\" McPeek crowed.\n\nOn Friday, McPeek and Hernandez had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMcPeek became just the fourth trainer to complete the Oaks-Derby double in the same year and the first since Ben Jones in 1952.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_McPeek", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Kenneth McPeek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Churchill_Downs", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Churchill Downs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Hernandez_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Brian Hernandez Jr."}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Thoroughbred_Racing_(United_States)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Louisville, Kentucky"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Louisville, Kentucky"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todd_Pletcher", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Todd Pletcher"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_R._Velazquez", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "John R. {"uri": "2024-05-345344210", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:37:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:37:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:19:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/article288197860.html", "title": "What happened to Fierceness, West Saratoga and all the other 2024 Kentucky Derby also-rans?", "body": "Click below to view more coverage from the Lexington Herald-Leader and Kentucky.com at the 150th Kentucky Derby on May 4 at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nThe finish of the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby was worthy of the Run for the Roses historic milestone.\n\nMystik Dan held off a late charge from Sierra Leone and Forever Young to win in a photo finish after going off at 18-1 odds. Mystik Dan gave Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek his first Kentucky Derby victory and gave McPeek the first Derby-Kentucky Oaks double for a trainer since 1952.\n\nWhat happened to everybody else in the field? Here's a look.\n\nThe other horses in the photo finish\n\nWith Mystik Dan leading at the final turn, Blue Grass Stakes winner Sierra Leone, who was 17th at the first turn, and Forever Young, who was in the middle of the pack early, made a late charge from the outside. That charge came just short with a photo finish confirming Mystik Dan had just edged out Sierra Leone.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" Sierra Leone's trainer, Chad Brown, said. \"But he's a tremendous horse, nearly undefeated. I'm just so lucky to have him, so proud of his effort today.\n\n\"He did what we asked him to do, just came up a little bit short. (I didn't think I won) watching it live, but then when they started showing the slo-mo, I thought maybe this could be a dead heat because I got a great bob. I just wasn't in front.\"\n\nForever Young finished third, just missing becoming the first Japan-bred horse to win the Derby.\n\nCatching Freedom finishes fourth\n\nBrad Cox-trained Catching Freedom took a similar path to Mystik Dan, emerging from the pack along the rail in the final turn but was passed down the stretch by Sierra Leone and Forever Young.\n\n\"Overall I was very happy with Catching Freedom's effort,\" Cox said. \"I really was and the ride Flavien (Prat) gave him. We'll regroup, not sure where we'll land.\"\n\nT O Password, the other Japan-bred horse in the field, was never in contention for the win but made a late charge to finish fifth.\n\n\"He didn't break well,\" jockey Kazushi Kimura said. \"This was his third time running and he was in a new country. He probably wasn't 100% mature. Today he finished up strong. I hope the horse can stay for the Preakness.\"\n\nThe favorite looked in good position early\n\nFlorida Derby winner Fierceness, the 3-1 race favorite, jumped out of the gate but recovered to be among a four-wide pack leading at the first turn. Fierceness was still in third with four furlongs to go.\n\nAfter Mystik Dan made his charge to the lead along the inside rail in the final turn, Fierceness faded, finishing 15th.\n\n\"He had the hop at the start, and we kind of had to hustle a little more than we wanted to,\" trainer Todd Pletcher said. \"Got some pressure on both sides coming by the eighth pole. ... Finally got to the position we wanted, but (jockey) Johnny (Velazquez) said he was a little bit too geared up at that point.\"\n\nThe pace-setters\n\nJust Steel, Epic Ride and Track Phantom helped set the early pace alongside Fierceness but all finished out of contention. Track Phantom was 11th, Epic Ride was 14th and Just Steel, who is trained by D. Wayne Lukas, was 17th.\n\n\"I was on the lead for a while,\" Track Phantom's jockey, Joel Rosario, said. \"He ran his race but we couldn't hang in there. He did his best.\"\n\nJockey Keith Asmussen said Just Steel was squeezed leaving the gate, and Lukas said the early pace was too fast.\n\n\"It was probably a little too fast for the opening quarter-mile,\" Epic Ride's jockey, Adam Beschizza, said. \"I was a little too aggressive going past the wire. It was a rough, busy race. I was able to keep it uninterrupted for the most for him. It's just probably a bit too far.\"\n\nThe rest of the field\n\nSanta Anita Derby-winner Stronghold was fourth heading into the final turn but finished seventh, just behind Wood Memorial winner Resilience. Honor Marie, who was last at the first turn, finished eighth.\n\n\"My race was over coming out of the gate,\" Honor Marie's jockey, Ben Curtis, said. \"I got speared from both sides, I lost an iron and had to put it back in. He was nearly down on his head but I gave him time to pick himself up. He didn't get the smoothest first quarter of a mile and I just let him float around a bit after that. Then I took to the inside because I didn't want to give away any more ground. He paid for the early exertion but he ran a credible race.\"\n\nEndlessly and Dornoch rounded out the top 10.\n\n\"He had a very bad trip,\" Dornoch's trainer, Danny Gargan, said. \"He was eliminated early. He got very tired. I'm disappointed in the way he ran today.\"\n\nWest Saratoga, whose trainer Larry Demeritte became the first Black trainer to saddle a horse in the Derby since 1989, finished 11th.\n\nDomestic Product (12th), Society Man (16th), Grand Mo the First (18th), Catalytic (19th) and Just a Touch (20th) were never really in the mix.", "source": {"uri": "kentucky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8111782942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:41:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:41:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:40:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.columbian.com/news/2024/may/04/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-by-a-nose-in-a-3-horse-photo-finish-at-churchill-downs/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in a 3-horse photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "Mystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.", "source": {"uri": "columbian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Columbian"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phantom_(horse)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Phantom (horse)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forever_Young_(Alphaville_song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Forever Young (Alphaville song)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colt_(horse)", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Colt (horse)"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Gambling/Sports", "label": "dmoz/Games/Gambling/Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Barrel_Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Barrel Racing", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://pcdn.columbian.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/AP24125836041901.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539947", "eventUri": "eng-9539947", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1607843137254903, "wgt": 164, "relevance": 1}

And we skipped the Rebel (at Oaklawn Park) because it was too short as well.\n\n\"So we'll watch him over the next week, and probably decide then. It will be a last-minute decision. We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nMystik Dan, ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr., pulled off an 18-1 upset in Saturday's 1-1/4 mile Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs when he finished a nose ahead of Sierra Leone, who was another nose in front of Forever Young.\n\nSierra Leone's trainer, Chad Brown, said the horse would not run the Preakness Stakes and will instead be brought to Saratoga Race Course in upstate New York where he will train for the June 8 Belmont Stakes.\n\n\"He's a little tired. He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, he was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" said Brown. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nJapanese-bred colt Forever Young was scheduled to return to Japan on Tuesday, meaning the Preakness could be without the top three finishers from the Kentucky Derby. -
