{"uri": "8112071714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "08:32:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T08:32:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:26:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/three-headed-thriller/article_55aba4f5-5b90-51e3-a835-c3725ef3075d.html", "title": "THREE-HEADED THRILLER", "body": "Sierra Leone, with jockey Tyler Gaffalione, (2), Forever young, with jockey Ryusei Sakai, and Mystik Dan, with jockey Dan Brian Hernandez Jr., cross the finish line at Churchill downs during the 150th running of the Kentucky derby on Saturday in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBETH HARRIS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The 150th Kentucky Derby produced one of the most dramatic finishes in its storied history -- three noses at the wire.\n\nMystik Dan desperately fought to hang on with two challengers coming to him in the closing strides. He did, too, after a delay of several minutes while the closest three-horse photo finish since 1947 was sorted out.\n\nThat year, Jet Pilot won by a head over Phalanx and a length ahead of Faultless.\n\nMystik Dan, an 18-1 shot, edged Sierra Leone by a nose, with Forever Young another nose back in third on Saturday. Sierra Leone was the most expensive horse in the race at $2.3 million.\n\nLong shots Track Phantom and Just Steel led the field through the early going, with 3-1 favorite Fierceness racing three-wide just off the leaders.\n\nAt the top of the stretch, everything changed.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hard Rock ramping up hiring efforts Former UVA Wise College Board Member Gives $1 Million to school Nominations reach 29 for Gene \"Pappy\" Thompson Award PREP BASEBALL: Falcons finish season sweep of John Battle THURSDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Abingdon (baseball), John Battle (softball) clinch Mountain 7 District titles; Tennessee High girls tennis team claims district crown; Lee High baseball team scores 29 runs; Trajan Cannon (Patrick Henry), Kailyn Breeding and Cooper Hurst (Richlands) also among stars TUESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Brandon Edwards (J.I. Burton), Matthew Nunley (Honaker), Tyler Hash (Tazewell), Maya Owens (Holston), Reagan Evans (Rural Retreat), Erin Rasnake (Lebanon), Taylor Preston (Marion), Braelyn Scammell (Patrick Henry), Chase Wolfenbarger (Tennessee High) among notable performers MONDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Ashton Leonard and Carly Compton (Tennessee High), Connor Smith (Chilhowie), Jed McCoy (Eastside), Eli Hucks (Virginia High), Collyn Neff (Union), MJ Musser (Holston) , Jordan Frazier (J.I. Burton), Julia Barton (Honaker) among stars NASCAR: The Bluefield Boys have found a niche in NASCAR WEDNESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Blair Rutherford and Alex Brown (Patrick Henry), Taylor Childress (John Battle), Emmaleigh Banks (Eastside), Will Rollins (Rye Cove), Ella Moss (Marion), Madyson Doss (Sullivan East), Hayden Baker (Ridgeview) among stars PREP BASEBALL: Abingdon gets 2-0 verdict over Virginia High as freshman catcher Judge Dillow, strong pitching overrule Bearcats MOTORSPORTS: Stanley is a hometown hero at Lonesome Pine HIGH SCHOOL BASEBALL: Chilhowie extends perfect mark in the Hogoheegee District LOCALS IN COLLEGE NOTES: UVa's Matthew Buchanan (Lebanon) enjoyed thrill of pitching at Fenway Park PREP BASEBALL: Elizabethton stuns Tennessee High in District 1-AAA tourney HIGH SCHOOL BASEBALL: Richlands continues turnaround with VHS win\n\nTrack Phantom drifted off the rail, opening a hole that Hernandez squeezed Mystik Dan through, and the bay colt suddenly found another gear. He quickly opened up a daylight advantage on the field.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.'\"\n\nTo Mystik Dan's outside, Sierra Leone and Forever Young took up the chase in the middle of the track.\n\nAs Mystik Dan sped along the rail, Sierra Leone lugged in and bumped Forever Young three times in the stretch, but jockey Ryusei Sakai didn't claim foul.\n\nMystik Dan got so close to the rail that Hernandez's boot struck it.\n\n\"But I think we can buy another pair of boots,\" he said.\n\nThe winner's share of the record $5 million purse was $3.1 million, with the jockey and trainer typically earning 10% each.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" McPeek said. \"Brian is one of the most underrated jockeys, but not anymore, right?\"\n\nSierra Leone, the second choice at 9-2 odds, and Forever Young from Japan came up just short at the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs, the largest crowd since 2018.\n\nIt was just the 10th Kentucky Derby decided by a nose -- the closest margin in horse racing -- and the first since Grindstone edged Cavonnier to wear the garland of red roses in 1996.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes in the heat and humidity as the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\n\"The longest few minutes of my life,\" Hernandez said, after he and Mystik Dan walked in circles while the stunning result was settled. \"To see your number flash up to win the Derby, I don't think it will sink in for a while.\"\n\nFierceness finished 15th in the field of 20 3-year-olds. Owner Mike Repole is 0 for 8 in the derby. He had the favorite in 2011 with Uncle Mo, who was scratched the day before the race with an illness. Last year, Forte was scratched the morning of the race as the favorite with a bruised foot.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1\u00bc miles over a fast track in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22, $16.32 and $10.\n\nTags Sports {"uri": "2024-05-345864458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:35:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:35:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T08:25:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://en.as.com/other_sports/how-much-prize-money-did-mystik-dan-get-for-winning-2024-kentucky-derby-n/", "title": "How much prize money did Mystik Dan get for winning 2024 Kentucky Derby?", "body": "In a thrilling climax that ended in a photo finish, Mystik Dan, ridden by American jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., emerged as the champion of the 150th edition of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. It was a race filled with suspense and excitement as Mystik Dan narrowly edged past competitors Sierra Leone and Forever Young, securing victory by mere centimetres at Churchill Downs.\n\nDespite not being among the favoured contenders, Mystik Dan defied the odds with a stunning performance, clinching the prestigious horse race with odds of 18-1. Reflecting on his unexpected triumph, Hernandez Jr. said it was an \"indescribable feeling\" in an interview with NBC immediately after the race.\n\n2024 Kentucky Derby prize money\n\nThere was a $5 million prize purse will be up for grabs at the 2024 Derby, and per The Athletic's Andrew DeWitt and Drew Jordan, only the Breeders' Cup Classic - a race held at alternating venues every November - has a larger purse among American events, at $7 million.\n\nOf the $5 million purse at the 2024 Derby, which is distributed among the first five finishers, $3.1 million went to the victor, Mystik Dan with $1 million due to the runner-up, Sierra Leone.\n\nAccording to a prize-money breakdown by racing expert Keeler Johnson, the horse's owner typically takes home 80% of the payout, with 10% each shared out to the jockey and the trainer.", "source": {"uri": "as.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "as"}, "authors": [{"uri": "michael_reaves@as.com", "name": "Michael Reaves", "type": "author", {"uri": "2024-05-345275152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:23:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:23:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:21:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/article288288140.html", "title": "Mystik Dan wins historic 2024 Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish at Churchill Downs", "body": "Mystik Dan won a three-way photo finish over Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a historic 150th edition of the Grade 1, $5 million Kentucky Derby from a full field of 20 horses on Saturday night beneath the Twin Spires at Churchill Downs in Louisville.\n\nMystik Dan, saddled by Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek and ridden by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., provided the first combination Oaks-Derby double since 1952 with their narrow win.\n\nThe McPeek-Hernandez duo teamed up to win the Kentucky Oaks with Thorpedo Anna on Friday evening at Churchill. The last jockey to do the Oaks-Derby double was Calvin Borel in 2009 with Rachel Alexandra and Mine That Bird. The last trainer to do the double was Ben Jones in 1952 with Real Delight and Hill Gail.\n\nMcPeek is only the fourth-ever trainer to do the Oaks-Derby double in the same year.\n\nAfter Friday's Kentucky Oaks was contested over a sloppy track and rain threatened throughout Saturday, the Derby was run over a fast main track at Churchill.\n\nIt didn't matter. McPeek and Hernandez won in both conditions at Churchill Downs this weekend.\n\nMcPeek was previously 0-for-9 in the Derby, with his best finish being second with Tejano Run in 1995.\n\nHernandez had been o-for-4 in the Derby, with his best finish being eighth with McCraken in 2017.\n\n\"Brian just did an amazing job,\" McPeek said post race on NBC, praising the jockey, Hernandez, multiple times.\n\nMystik Dan (who broke from post position 3) is owned by Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing (Brent Gasaway and Daniel Hamby. This was the first Kentucky Derby for all of Mystik Dan's owners.\n\nThe horse went off at 18-1 odds in the Derby.\n\nMystik Dan had accrued 46 Derby qualifying points, which included a third-place finish in the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby on March 30 at Oaklawn Park and a win in the Grade 3 Southwest Stakes in early February at Oaklawn Park.\n\nMystik Dan had 20-1 morning-line odds following last week's post position draw, before he was bet down to the 18-1 odds he went off at.\n\nThe horse is now 3-1-1 in seven career starts. He entered the Derby with career earnings of $641,360, a total that will significantly increase after Saturday's result.\n\nThe bay-colored horse was bred in Kentucky and was sired by Goldencents. Mystik Dan's dam was Ma'am, by Colonel John.\n\nA homebred, Mystik Dan earned his first career win at Churchill Downs last November.\n\nThe 2024 Derby Day attendance was 156,710 spectators at Churchill Downs, an increase of more than 6,000 fans from the crowd of 150,335 people that gathered for last year's race.\n\nJockey Irad Ortiz Jr. dominates Derby undercard races\n\nAs always, several high-quality stakes races took place on the Derby undercard Saturday at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe early undercard races were dominated by jockey Irad Ortiz Jr., who won each of the Grade 2, $600,000 Twin Spires Turf Sprint Stakes, Grade 1, $1 million Derby City Distaff Stakes and Grade 2, $665,000 Longines Churchill Distaff Turf Mile Stakes.\n\nOrtiz won each of those races for a different trainer: Ortiz was aboard Cogburn for Steve Asmussen in a 2 1/4-length victory in the Turf Sprint, Vahva for Cherie DeVaux in a 2-length victory in the Derby City Distaff and Chili Flag (FR) for Chad Brown in a win that came by a neck in the Churchill Distaff Turf Mile.\n\nThe 88-year-old trainer D. Wayne Lukas teamed up with jockey Jaime Torres to win the Grade 2, $600,000 Pat Day Mile Stakes by 1 1/4 lengths with Seize the Grey, and trainer H. Graham Motion paired with jockey Umberto Rispoli to win the Grade 2, $600,000 American Turf Stakes with 47-1 long shot Trikari.\n\nAsmussen also won the Grade 1, $1 million Churchill Downs by 2 1/2 lengths with Gun Pilot, who was ridden by Cristian Torres.", "source": {"uri": "kentucky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lexington Herald Leader"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112806435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:07:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:07:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:06:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/sports/other/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_50adb4ea-3a16-5b56-8c50-21a3d81df4d9.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "GARY B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday Bellin Gundersen Health System files trademark application for Emplify Health name, logo Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Amtrak adds second train between Twin Cities, Chicago; Borealis service will stop in La Crosse, Tomah, Winona Steve Cahalan: Valley View Mall to add more tenants, 7 Brew Coffee drive-thrus coming to La Crosse Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire La Crosse man arrested for possession of fentanyl during traffic stop Onalaska teen faces charges for uploading child pornography 'Slow, thoughtful process': Emplify Health to become new name of Gundersen, Bellin group Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school Mount Horeb shooting: Students 'saw something' as teen approached school, notified staff La Crosse County home prices skyrocket 21% over last year; fewer sales than year prior Melrose man faces charges of stalking and vandalism in jealous rage\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose 1 of 11\n\nA race fan sits in the stands Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, The jockey is Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nHernandez said after the race he wasn't sure if they had won.\n\n\"So it was quite a rush to sit here and wait for it,\" he told NBC Sports.\n\nMystik Dan was called an \"underdog\" in the race and made up time in the second half of the race.\n\nNola.com's sports betting team suggested to bet on longshot Mystik Dan 20-1.\n\nBefore the race, Sharilyn Gasaway {"uri": "8112558018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:18:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:18:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:17:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/276723/connections-savor-kentucky-derby-win-from-mystik-dan", "title": "Connections Savor Kentucky Derby Win From Mystik Dan", "body": "Mystik Dan could race in the May 18 Preakness (G1) or await the June 8 Belmont (G1).\n\nWith Churchill Downs closed on May 5, the day after the Kentucky Derby (G1), jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. had planned to be on a flight to Louisiana that morning for a rare Sunday off from riding to enjoy live music during the day at the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival.\n\nBut the rider and other connections of Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan were instead at Churchill Downs, speaking to an audience, rather than within one.\n\n\"I'm standing here with all these cameras in front of me. I'm like, 'Wow, what just happened?'\" he said.\n\nHernandez scrapped his travel, choosing instead to celebrate dinner the evening of May 4 with his wife, Jamie, and other family and friends at Jeff Ruby's Steakhouse in Louisville, Ky.\n\nNot far from Mystik Dan's stall outside the barn of trainer Kenny McPeek on Sunday morning, Hernandez, McPeek, and Lance and Sharilyn Gasaway -- members of the partnership that owns Mystik Dan -- looked tired but happy.\n\nSign up for BloodHorse Daily\n\nThe same description applied to the horse, who, as is typical for a Kentucky Derby winner, was led out of his stall for a photo opportunity before a throng of photographers and media. He was subdued and, after a bath, returned inside the barn to walk some laps in the shedrow before being led back to his stall. He wore a blanket celebrating him as the winner of the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nMystik Dan showed signs of his hard race, in which he outlasted Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a three-horse photo finish.\n\n\"Look, most trainers don't talk about all this. But cards on the table, face up -- he left three quarts (of) feed,\" McPeek said. \"We couldn't hardly get everybody out of the barn until midnight, so he couldn't really get a great night's rest.\"\n\nMcPeek was noncommittal about whether Mystik Dan, who races for Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing, Daniel Hamby III and Valley View Farm, would pursue the May 18 Preakness Stakes (G1) at Pimlico Race Course or await the June 8 Belmont Stakes (G1), taking place this year at Saratoga Race Course. The 1 3/16-mile Preakness and Belmont Stakes, shortened to 1 1/4 miles this year due to being at Saratoga, are the remaining legs of the Triple Crown, a series last swept by Justify in 2018. Justify became the 13th winner of the Triple Crown.\n\nIn part due to the lure of the Triple Crown, and the eventual stallion value that comes to a horse that can sweep the series, Kentucky Derby winners often return in the Preakness. But some have skipped the race, most recently Rich Strike in 2022, to await the Belmont, where he ran sixth.\n\nLast year's Kentucky Derby winner, Mage , ran third in the Preakness. His connections then bowed out of running him in the Belmont.\n\nMcPeek noted that Mystik Dan ran below form when he previously raced him on two weeks of rest in the fall of 2023, finishing fifth in an allowance optional claiming race at Churchill Downs Nov. 25. Since then, the trainer has given his colt a month or more off between starts.\n\nLance and Sharilyn Gasaway said they plan to have input in whether Mystik Dan races on a short turnaround in the Preakness, with their emphasis on what's best for their colt, a homebred bay 3-year-old of Goldencents .\n\nThe colt, who they bred out of the Colonel John mare Ma'am , won the Feb. 3 Southwest Stakes (G3) at Oaklawn Park this winter and was third in the Arkansas Derby (G1) preceding the Kentucky Derby. He now has earnings of $3,741,360, earning the bulk of that with his first-place finish worth $3.1 million in the Derby.\n\n\"It's all about the horse. See how the horse comes out of the race, give him two or three days,\" Lance Gasaway said. \"If he comes out of it good, we'll look at it. If not -- we'll look at the horse more than anything.\"\n\nMcPeek said he and his wife Sherri would leave for Saratoga to prepare his stable for horses for being sent there soon.\n\nThe trainer said, \"There's a better-than-average chance that we're going to send him and some others to Saratoga\" from Churchill Downs.\n\nHe plans to have Mystik Dan resume training in the middle of this week.\n\nThorpedo Anna , McPeek's Kentucky Oaks (G1) winner for owners Brookdale Racing, Mark Edwards, Judy Hicks, and Sherri McPeek's Magdalena Racing, was also photographed Sunday. She could also be headed soon to Saratoga. Thorpedo Anna is pointed to either the $500,000 Acorn Stakes (G1) June 7 there or the $2 million Belmont Stakes against males. Not having originally been a Triple Crown nominee, she would require a $50,000 supplement to race in the Belmont.\n\nMcPeek, who won the 2020 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver and the 2002 Belmont Stakes with longshot Sarava , was asked if he would have reservations about running the two together in the Belmont.\n\n\"Yes, I would. I can't get Brian on both of them,\" he said of the jockey, whom he again credited with a ground-saving, difference-making ride in the Derby.", "source": {"uri": "bloodhorse.com", "dataType": "news", Forever Young from Japan and Sierra Leone gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs.\n\nThe crowd waited several minutes before the result was reviewed by the stewards and declared official.\n\nHernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies on Friday with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nMystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22 to win.\n\nThe 150th Run for the Roses would have been unrecognizable to the 10,000 people who attended that first race at an unknown track on the rural outskirts of Louisville, Kentucky. Now more than 157,000 pack into Churchill Downs from all over the world for a dayslong spectacle of huge hats and mint juleps, where most grandstand tickets cost more than $500 and celebrities celebrate in lavish suites high above the track.\n\nThe sun was shining Saturday, and Derby-goers didn't have to contend with the bad news that put a damper on the race last year, when seven horses died in the week leading into the race. They posed for pictures in front of a sign commemorating the anniversary and whispered about the celebrities who made an appearance.\n\nKentucky native Wynonna Judd was at the track to sing the National Anthem. Martha Stewart was the day's grand marshal, charged with saying \"Riders' Up!\" to start race. The dirt surface was upgraded to fast a couple hours before the race after being muddy to start the day's card.\n\nBefore the race, Fierceness was holding as the 7-2 favorite, followed by Sierra Leone at 5-1. Forever Young, from Japan, was at 6-1, followed by Catching Freedom at 8-1 and Just a Touch at 10-1.\n\nThe costliest colt in the 20-horse field was Sierra Leone at $2.3 million, which came in second.\n\n'A lot of times you buy an expensive horse like that, and they can't run,' said Peter Brandt before the race. He's one of the six owners. 'We've very, very lucky he's made it this far. We're looking forward to this race but also looking forward to the future of taking care of this horse.'\n\nConversely, Larry Demeritte shelled out just $11,000 to buy Saratoga West. The 74-year-old Bahamas native has won 180 races and nearly $5 million in purse money since he started training in 1984. Demeritte is just the second Black trainer since 1951 to saddle a horse for the derby.\n\n'This is truly amazing how we got to this position with this horse,' he said.\n\nThe Kentucky Derby winner earns $3.1 million from the record purse of $5 million.\n\nSierra Leone with jockey Tyler Gaffalione (2), Forever Young with jockey Ryusei Sakai and Mystik Dan with jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., cross the finish line at Churchill Downs during the 150th Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Kentucky, May 4, 2024.\n\nForever Young is one of two entries from Japan. Wayne Lukas, the 88-year-old trainer with four Kentucky Derby wins, saddled Just Steel. Frankie Dettori, the famed Italian jockey, was back to ride Society Man at age 53 after a 24-year absence.\n\nTrainer Todd Pletcher, who saddled Fierceness, was in the Kentucky Derby for the 24th year and it never gets old. And we skipped the Rebel (at Oaklawn Park) because it was too short as well. \"So we'll watch him over the next week, and probably decide then. It will be a last-minute decision. We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nMystik Dan, ridden by Brian Hernandez Jr., pulled off an 18-1 upset in Saturday's 1-1/4 mile Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs when he finished a nose ahead of Sierra Leone, who was another nose in front of Forever Young. He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, he was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" said Brown. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely {"uri": "8112861443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:26:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:26:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:24:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/horseracing/s-3232370", "title": "Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan continuing on to the Preakness far from a sure thing", "body": "When the officials from Pimlico Race Course called Kenny McPeek on Sunday morning to offer an official invitation to the Preakness Stakes, the trainer had but one question.\n\n\"Can I bring my dog?\" McPeek asked with a grin.\n\nWhile McPeek got the go-ahead to bring his yellow Labrador Sonny to Baltimore, the trainer was noncommittal on whether Kentucky Derby 150 winner Mystik Dan will be running the second jewel of the Triple Crown on May 18.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness. Not yet,\" McPeek said after the phone call. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. We skipped the Rebel (Stakes) because it was back too quick, as well. ... It'll be one of those (decisions) where we take it up to the last minute.\"\n\nMystik Dan did leave some feed in his tub Saturday night after winning a three-horse photo finish with runner-up Sierra Leone and third-place finisher Forever Young.\n\nCoupled with Thorpedo Anna's win in Friday's Kentucky Oaks, McPeek became the first trainer to execute the Oaks/Derby double since the legendary Ben Jones accomplished the feat for Calumet Farm in 1952.\n\n\"An overnight sensation, 40 years later,\" McPeek joked Sunday.\n\nSaturday was a win for the good guys. The 61-year-old McPeek is a Tates Creek High School and University of Kentucky graduate who admits he spent a good portion of his time in the library at the UK agricultural school pouring over the bloodline histories in the BloodHorse and the old Thoroughbred Record.\n\nHis first Kentucky Derby horse, Tejano Run, finished second in 1995. He won the 2002 Belmont with Sarava and the 2022 Preakness with the filly Swiss Skydiver. He was 0-for-9 in the Derby, however, including 2002 when he saddled the favorite, Harlan's Holiday. After a seventh-place finish, the owners moved the colt to a different trainer.\n\nMystik Dan was a different colt, however. Outside of the post-time favorite Fierceness, Mystik Dan had run the only triple-digit Beyer Speed Figure -- 101 for his 8-length win in the Grade 3 Southwest Stakes -- in the Derby field. It's the biggest audience since 1989", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr. celebrates in the winner's circle after riding Mystik Dan to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race at Churchill Downs Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Louisville, Ky.\n\nSTAMFORD, Conn. (AP) -- Mystik Dan's nose victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby drew 16.7 million viewers, the biggest audience for the race since 1989.\n\nViewership peaked at 20.1 million from 7 to 7:15 p.m. EDT on Saturday, when 18-1 shot Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young hit the wire together in the Derby's first three-horse photo finish since 1947. That marked the biggest peak audience ever for the Derby on NBC.\n\nThe 16.7 million viewers was up 13% from last year's 14.8 million.\n\nNBC Sports said Sunday it was the biggest Derby audience since 18.5 million watched Sunday Silence win in 1989, when the race was shown on ABC.\n\nNBC Sports and Churchill Downs Inc. have agreed to a multiyear contract extension that will keep the Derby on the {"uri": "8111863166", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:37:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:37:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:36:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://njtoday.news/2024/05/05/mystik-dan-wins-150th-kentucky-derby-in-three-way-photo-finish/", "title": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby in three-way photo finish", "body": "In a thrilling upset that left spectators on the edge of their seats, Mystik Dan, an underdog with odds of 16-1, clinched victory at the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe race, held at Churchill Downs, unfolded in a nail-biting crescendo as the valiant colt, ridden by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. and trained by Kenny McPeek, surged past the finish line, leaving pre-race favorites trailing in his wake.\n\nThe dramatic climax of the race saw Mystik Dan holding off the late charges of Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a photo finish that took several minutes to confirm.\n\nDespite the tense competition, Mystik Dan's unwavering determination secured him the coveted title, crossing the finish line with a winning time of 2:03.24.\n\nThe victory marked a historic moment for trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., who clinched their first Derby win together. Mystik Dan's triumph also capped off a remarkable weekend for the connections, following their success in the Kentucky Oaks (G1) with Thorpedo Anna.\n\nOwned by Brent Gasaway's 4G Racing, Lance Gasaway, and Daniel Hamby III, Mystik Dan's journey to victory is a tale of perseverance and passion. Bred from the mare Ma'am and sired by Goldencents, the colt's triumph is a testament to the dedication of his owners and the astute guidance of his trainer.\n\nThe 150th Kentucky Derby saw a star-studded turnout, with celebrities gracing the red carpet at Churchill Downs. From Super Bowl champion Travis Kelce to music icon Smokey Robinson and Hollywood star Chris Tucker, the event shimmered with glitz and glamour, adding to the aura of excitement surrounding the historic race.\n\nWith millions of viewers tuning in from around the world, the Kentucky Derby reaffirmed its status as one of the most prestigious events in horse racing. As the longest continually held sporting event in America, the Derby's legacy was further enriched by Mystik Dan's remarkable underdog victory, reminding us all of the enduring spirit of competition {"uri": "8112800516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:59:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:59:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:58:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/other/kentucky-derby-preakness-mystik-dan-sierra-leone-catching-freedom-just-a-touch-forever-young-fierceness/article_4d84950d-bdd9-539d-a8fc-c689f0043a89.html", "title": "Status of Mystik Dan, others leave questions for Preakness", "body": "GARY B. GRAVES Associated Press\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The second jewel of horse racing's Triple Crown could be missing 150th Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan and other co-stars, quashing hopes for a rematch after the thrilling three-wide photo finish in the milestone race.\n\nTrainer Kenny McPeek and the horse's ownership wouldn't commit to whether the colt would race in the 149th Preakness on May 18 in Baltimore, which requires a quick two-week turnaround. Mystik Dan will travel to Saratoga, New York, before they decide whether to enter him in the 1 3/16 mile Preakness.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning outside his barn on Churchill Downs' back side. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Update: Suspect in highway shooting found dead after pursuit, I-80 standoff Police: Two arrested after vehicle pursuit in Napa Young in Napa: The problem with Napa drivers BottleRock organizers break down closure, access details around Napa's new Festival La Onda Woman gets six-year prison term for fatal 2022 Napa car crash Napa County Planning Commission denies controversial Vida Valiente winery application Napa County starts rezoning for multi-family housing sites An 'incredible ride': Napa Valley small business owner bakes gluten-free bread, pastries and more. Police: Man arrested after armed robbery of American Canyon convenience store Napa Land Trust gains 1,300-acre Mead Ranch on Atlas Peak All smoke and mirrors? Police records reveal Napa dispensaries are chill Friends, schoolmates remember Napa teen who died in shooting St. Helena goes ahead with vineyard rezoning for housing NFL Draft: Napa coaches praise Bowers, calling first-rounder a nice guy who works hard Authorities: Man arrested in Napa County with thousands of fentanyl pills, faces rape warrant\n\nThe picturesque track in upstate New York will host the Triple Crown's final jewel for the next three years while Belmont Park is being reconstructed. The Belmont has also been shortened to a 1 1/4 mile, matching the Derby distance that Mystik Dan won by a nose over Sierra Leone and Japan-bred Forever Young in the closest three-way finish since 1947.\n\nThe five-week gap follows a more normal race schedule for many thoroughbreds and some trainers might opt to head to Saratoga to acclimate horses sooner.\n\nChad Brown said Sierra Leone will skip the Preakness and leave on Monday to train at Saratoga and run the Belmont. Considering how much it took for Sierra Leone to navigate other horses and chase down Mystik Dan before falling a nose short at the wire, rest sounds necessary.\n\n\"He's a real laid back horse but when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nLouisville-born trainer Brad Cox is watching Catching Freedom (fourth) and Just A Touch (20th) before deciding their next steps. Forever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password (fifth) are headed home on Tuesday.\n\nThat could leave the Preakness without some Derby star power at first glance, though it won't lack for plotlines with a number of well-rested horses expected to compete at Pimlico Race Course.\n\nHall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert could have two entrants as he seeks to follow up National Treasure's victory there last spring. He trains Santa Anita Derby runner-up Imagination and Arkansas Derby winner Muth, who missed the Derby after failed legal attempts by owner Amr Zedan to get him in despite Baffert's suspension by Churchill Downs through the end of 2024.\n\nAs McPeek and the owners ponder a decision, he and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. basked in a wash of congratulations for a Derby victory that put them in exclusive company.\n\nSaturday's win helped both claim rare weekend sweeps of the Derby and Kentucky Oaks for fillies. McPeek is just the third trainer to do that and first since Ben Jones (who did it twice) in 1952, while Hernandez is the eighth rider to achieve the feat and first since fellow Louisiana native and Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009.\n\nMeanwhile, Mystik Dan just stood calm and unfazed as a cluster of onlookers took photos and selfies as workers bathed him outside the barn. He was then draped with the winner's blanket signifying his Derby win before being led back to his stall with a WWE-style title belt laying on an outer wall. Oaks-winning filly Thorpedo Anna also made a brief appearance and soaked in the attention.\n\nHernandez is preparing for his own life-changing spotlight and title after claiming the sport's marquee race. He dined with his family after the Derby but didn't sleep much, a routine that figures to go on for the next few days amid a flood of interview requests. At some point he hopes to get his mind around all that has happened, but he already has a response ready.\n\n\"When somebody asks what my profession is, I'm able to tell them I'm a professional jockey. And then the first question they normally ask is, 'Have you ever won the Kentucky Derby?' I can say that now.\"\n\nClose\n\nA race fan sits in the stands Saturday at Churchill Downs before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race in Louisville, Ky.\n\nBrynn Anderson, Associated {"uri": "8112308508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "12:12:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T12:12:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T12:12:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/racing/arid-41388802.html", "title": "Mystic Dan clings on for victory in Kentucky Derby thriller", "body": "Sierra Leone came home strongly but couldn't quite give his Coolmore owners compensation for City Of Troy's disappointing display in the 2000 Guineas, while Japanese raider Forever Young was another nose back in third.\n\nThe 150th 'Run for the Roses' took place on a 10-furlong dirt track described as running fast after a glorious day in Louisville had dried up Friday night's rain.\n\nA crowd of 156,710 packed into Churchill Downs let out an almighty roar, as Track Phantom took an early lead, flanked by Just Steel and the favourite Fierceness.\n\nThat trio held sway until the turn for home, when Mystik Dan burst through on the inside rail and quickly stormed into a three-length lead.\n\nSierra Leone and Forever Young fought hard to claw back the deficit and were closing in on the leader with every stride, but the finishing line came just in time for Mystik Dan.\n\nIt completed a memorable double for the successful trainer and jockey, who had won the Kentucky Oaks with\n\nThorpedo Anna\n\n24 hours earlier, and McPeek told NBC Sports: \"Brian just did an amazing job - just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride.\n\n\"The draw (stall three) helped us from the beginning but Brian is amazing, probably one of the most underrated riders in racing, but not anymore, right!\"\n\nHernandez admitted the long wait for the result to be confirmed was agonising, stating: \"This is just unbelievable, that was the longest few minutes I've ever felt in my life, waiting for them to put that number up.\n\n\"It was exciting when we hit the front but I wasn't sure we had won, so it was quite a rush to stay there and wait for it.\n\n\"This is a lifetime achievement. This goes to our whole family, we've all worked all our lives for this and it's hard to describe what kind of feeling this is.\n\n\"I always told myself I was never going to step into the Derby winner's circle until I can do it on the back of a horse, so to be able to live that dream from when I was a six-year-old kid on my grandparents' farm, telling them all I was going to the Kentucky Derby one day - and here we are.\n\n\"It surely makes the last 20 years of getting up at five in the morning and finding horses to ride and finding people to give us opportunities all come to fruition on days like yesterday and today.\n\n\"It's hard to put into words and it's probably going to take about a week to sink in before we say hey, we won the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks in the same year.\"\n\nTrainer Chad Brown said of runner-up Sierra Leone: \"To get beaten a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one, but that's professional sports and at this level you're going to win some and lose some, and often times it's going to come down to a matter of inches.\n\n\"He's a tremendous horse, he's nearly undefeated and hasn't lost by much in both of his defeats and I'm just so lucky to have him and so proud of his effort today.\n\n\"He did everything we asked him to do and it came up just a little bit short, but hats off to the winner, and Ken McPeek having the Derby and Oaks winners, to him and his team, they really did a fabulous job.\n\n\"The Derby gods can be cruel sometimes, making you wait, and some trainers never have one, so if I'm lucky enough to be back in the same position, I'll be grateful for that.\"\n\nBen Curtis, champion apprentice in Ireland back in 2010, finished eighth on Honor Marie, while Frankie Dettori was 16th of the 20 runners on Society Coming in second-place behind Mystik Dan was one of the race's favorites, Sierra Leone, with Forever Young coming in a close third-place finish.\n\nMystik Dan's team will also take home the the top prize from a purse worth $2 million more than last year. Totaling $5 million, first-place Mystik Dan's team has earned $3.1 million, while second-place Sierra Leone will take home $1 million and third-place gets $500,000. Fourth-place will take home $250,000 and fifth-place earned $150,000.\n\nA total of 20 horses galloped down the iconic Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky on Saturday. Heading into the race, the horse with the best morning-line odds were Fierceness at 3-1 and then Sierra Leone at 9-2. Other horses with better odds included Forever Young at 6-1 and Catching Freedom at 8-1.\n\nLike the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes will air live on NBC and Peacock.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346649139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:07:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:07:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:42:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.wdrb.com/sports/crawford-churchill-still-buzzing-over-derby-finish----and-the-bumpy-battle-for/article_2d4f49d2-0b02-11ef-a311-1f17f6912818.html", "title": "CRAWFORD | Churchill still buzzing over Derby finish -- and the bumpy battle for second", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (WDRB) - A morning after the closest Kentucky Derby finish in 28 years and the first three-horse photo finish in 72 years, the Churchill Downs backside was still buzzing not only over Mystik Dan's victory by a nose, but over the bumping battle for second between Sierra Leone and Japanese contender Forever Young.\n\nPhotographs after the race showed Sierra Leone's jockey, Tyler Gaffalione, reaching out with his left hand and making contact with Forever Young and his rider, Ryusei Sakai. Sierra Leone made a stirring rally, having to go eight-wide on the track, to get second in the race. The third-place finish for Forever Young was the best ever for a horse out of Japan.\n\nAsked why no claim of foul was made after the race, owner Susumu Fujita's racing manager, Hiroshi Ando, told Churchill Downs, \"Claims of foul do not happen much in Japan. It is the stewards' call, not us.\"\n\nNo stewards inquiry was posted after the race, which Mystik Dan won in a time of 2:03.34, the fifth time in the past 10 runnings of the Kentucky Derby that the winning time was in excess of 2:03 (American Pharoah, Always Dreaming, Justify and Country House also failed to break 2:03).\n\nSierra Leone and Foreverr Young raced in incredibly tight quarters down the lane as both furiously tried to reel in Mystik Dan, who made an inside move under jockey Brian Hernandez and drew clear in midstretch.\n\nThe effort his horse gave to get up for second encouraged trainer Chad Brown, though he said he wouldn't take the colt to the Preakness.\n\n\"There was so much bumping going on there,\" Brown said. \"When horses are fatigued, they have a tendency to lean in a bit like he did with his last two wins and it's going to be more exaggerated when they're more tired. He had so much to do and by the time he got to the eighth pole, he was leaning in a bit.\"\n\nGaffalione said after the race on Saturday, \"I felt like I had plenty of horse,\" Gaffalione said. \"He wanted to lean in today and made it a little difficult. I had a hard time keeping him straight and it definitely cost us. He gives you everything. Very responsive but he loses concentration.\"\n\nBrown said his jockey was trying to get room to use the whip with his left hand, which the horse responds to. But the bumping made that impossible.\n\n\"What Tyler was attempting to do is make room for his left stick, which the horse really respects, and keep him straight,\" Brown said. \"And he was looking for sort of a pathway to use his left stick. But with the bumping, the tight duel between those two horses, it disarmed him with the stick. All he had was a rein to pull on and it really hurt his momentum. He couldn't use it because he had no room to use his left stick without hitting his horse. He didn't want to do that either. So he was trying create a path not only to straighten out my horse who really respects that, he was trying not to foul the other horse with the stick.\"\n\nBrown said, given all of the adversity, he thought his horse ran well enough to win, but just didn't get the result in the end.\n\n\"I'm disappointed with the result, but I'm so proud of the horse, Brown said. \"In my mind, he ran the best race. That's no disrespect to the winner. It's just, it's a hard race to win, everything has to go right. With the winner, the horse showed up and was prepared right and he ran terrific. You have to have a trip where everything goes right. It's not (Mystik Dan's) fault the doors opened for him, I wish that would have happened for me. But I don't think less of the winner's performance. It's just an example of two trips. But that's what has to happen here. For us, I don't think we had a bad trip. But our horse was very far back on a track that favors speed and he had to go around a lot of horses and he had a ton of ground to make up. To almost get there despite all that, I really feel he ran the best race. We'll see going forward the rest of the year where he stacks up with the entire body of work.\"\n\nAs for the Japanese contingent, they, too, will head home disappointed in the result, but encouraged that they're getting closer.\n\nAndo said that trainer Yoshito Yahagi was disappointed Forever Young lost, but \"how he ran his race made us so proud.\"\n\nRelated Stories:\n\nBOZICH | After dramatic Derby win, McPeek says it's too soon to commit Mystik Dan to PreaknessMystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky DerbyChurchill Downs welcomes race fans for milestone Kentucky Derby 150CRAWFORD | Hernandez takes Mystik Dan on a rail ride to Kentucky Derby glory\n\nCopyright 2024 WDRB Media. {"uri": "8112799187", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:56:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:56:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:56:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/horse-racing/news/mystik-dan-preakness-kentucky-derby-winner-triple-crown-race/3a5a5110df8049828502a50c", "title": "Will Mystik Dan run the Preakness? Latest news about 2024 Kentucky Derby winner's plans for next Triple Crown race", "body": "Mystik Dan put himself into the history books Saturday, winning the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby. Now, the horse's ownership group is facing a key question in the wake of its big win.\n\nWill they run the Preakness Stakes and compete for a Triple Crown title, or will Mystik Dan sit the race out and take aim at the Belmont Stakes crown?\n\nSome may presume that the group would answer \"yes\" without hesitation. After all, only 13 horses have won the Triple Crown, so why wouldn't Mystik Dan's group try to become the 14th?\n\nBut nowadays, trainers and owners are much more aware of their horse's needs, so if they believe there is a benefit to resting the horse, they won't hesitate to do it.\n\nHere's what to know about Mystik Dan's potential Preakness run and why he isn't guaranteed to be in the field at Pilmico.\n\nMORE: How much prize money does the Kentucky Derby winner get in 2024?\n\nMystik Dan's ownership group has not yet decided if the 3-year-old colt will compete in the Preakness Stakes, as trainer Kenny McPeek revealed Sunday at Churchill Downs.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek told reporters, per ESPN. \"I ran him back once in two weeks, and it completely backfired on me. ... So we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those [situations] where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nMystik Dan wouldn't be the only Kentucky Derby contender to skip the Preakness. Sierra Leone, who finished second in the race, won't be running in the race and will instead take aim at the Belmont Stakes.\n\n\"He's a real laid-back horse but, when we brought him out, was a little more tired than he normally is after his races,\" Sierra Leone's trainer Chad Brown said. \"I think giving him the five weeks to the Belmont is definitely the right thing to do.\"\n\nThe last Kentucky Derby winner not to run the Preakness was Rich Strike in 2022. Rich Strike was a late entrant to the Derby field but later ran the Belmont Stakes.\n\nMORE: What to know about Brian Hernandez, the jockey of derby-winning Mystik Dan\n\nPart of the reason that more horses are skipping the Preakness Stakes is that it is held just two weeks after the Kentucky Derby. That scheduling pattern is holding true in 2024.\n\nThe 149th running of the Preakness will take place on Saturday, May 18. The post time for the race is 6:50 p.m. ET from Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.\n\nJustify was the last Kentucky Derby winner to also win the Preakness. He did so in 2018 en route to winning the Triple Crown by winning the Belmont Stakes three weeks later.\n\nMORE: How Mystik Dan got his unique name\n\nThirteen horses have won the Triple Crown. Only two have achieved the feat since 1979: Justify in 2018 and American Pharoah, who ended a 37-year Triple Crown drought in 2015.\n\nHere is the full list of Triple Crown-winning horses and jockeys, {"uri": "8113747492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:06:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:06:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:05:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10119969-preakness-2024-known-odds-schedule-and-mystik-dan-predictions", "title": "Preakness 2024: Known Odds, Schedule and Mystik Dan Predictions", "body": "With final betting odds of 18-1, Mystik Dan wasn't among the top picks to win the 2024 Kentucky Derby. Yet, the Ken McPeek-trained colt raced to victory at Churchill Downs on Saturday, beating out Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a photo finish.\n\nNow, the focus shifts to the second leg of horse racing's three-race Triple Crown schedule: the Preakness Stakes, scheduled for May 18. The big question at this point is whether Mystik Dan will be among the horses in the field.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday morning, per Gary B. Graves of the Associated Press. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those [situations] where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\"\n\nSierra Leone and Forever Young won't be racing the Preakness. So, who will be competing at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore in less than two weeks?\n\nHere's everything we know about the 2024 Preakness Stakes thus far.\n\nThe betting window for Preakness futures bets closed Saturday about an hour before the Kentucky Derby. At that time, Mystik Dan had 45-1 odds to win the Preakness. However, those will surely improve once new lines are released.\n\nIf Mystik Dan races the Preakness, he will likely be among the top favorites. For one, he just won the Kentucky Derby. Also, the field isn't likely to be stacked due to plenty of Derby horses not being entered into the race.\n\nHowever, there's also one non-Derby horse to keep a close eye on: Muth.\n\nBefore the Preakness futures window ended, Muth had the best odds to win the race at 7-2. There's a good chance he'll still be the favorite over Mystik Dan when new odds come out.\n\nMuth didn't race the Kentucky Derby because trainer Bob Baffert is suspended from Churchill Downs through the end of the year due to 2021 Derby winner Medina Spirit failing a test betamethasone, a banned steroid.\n\nBut Baffert has been allowed to enter horses at races at Pimlico Race Course. Last year, he was victorious at the Preakness for the eighth time, as National Treasure crossed the finish line first.\n\nMuth has finished either first or second in each of his first six races, which included a win at the Arkansas Derby in March. So he appears poised to be the front-runner at this year's Preakness.\n\nBut Mystik Dan now has an impressive resume himself. He owns three victories, with two coming over his past three races. He also hasn't finished worse than third during that span.\n\nIt's possible that Catching Freedom (who finished fourth in the Kentucky Derby) will race the Preakness. Trainer Brad Cox has not yet decided to enter the colt and is monitoring him for the time being, according to Graves.\n\nMuth may not be the only Baffert-trained horse in the Preakness field. He could also enter Imagination, who was the runner-up at the Santa Anita Derby last month.", "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bleacher Report"}, "authors": {"uri": "8112344047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "12:46:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T12:46:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T12:45:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/sports/localsports/commentary-150th-kentucky-derby-provides-a-finish-for-the-ages/article_f4ef6178-0a7d-11ef-9fd5-77776fc2d789.html", "title": "Commentary: 150th Kentucky Derby provides a finish for the ages", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- There have been tight finishes to a Kentucky Derby before, but never one as close as the thoroughbred racing world witnessed Saturday.\n\nMystik Dan, breaking sharply from the third post position, secured a spot on the rail and, quite simply, never left it. However, there was a lot of racing luck involved, because the strategy employed by jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. was to drop back in the early going and save his mount's best for the homestretch.\n\nThe good fortune commenced when no other rider in front of him opted to take his place on the inside. Mystik Dan dropped back as far as eighth place in the run around the first turn and, with a virtual highway open in front of him down the backstretch, began to close in on those in the vanguard.\n\nEven rounding the far turn, no other jockey opted to save ground by dropping over to the rail. Possibly, the reason for hesitancy was the fact that rain had doused the Downs' surface Friday evening. Water does roll downhill and, especially on the banked turns, the inside dries last.\n\nRegardless of the water content, Mystik Dan continued to close ground and pulled even with the leaders at the top of the home lane. Opening a two-length lead midway down the stretch, Hernandez kept busy with his mount, as danger was developing from the outside.\n\nLocked in a head-and-head battle, Sierra Leone and the Japanize-import Forever Young were closing with a rush, the latter leaning on his immediate rival and bumping him several times during the stretch run. As this duo closed in, it became a question of whether they would overtake Mystik Dan before or after crossing the finish line.\n\nThey didn't quite make it, but it was awfully close. The photo-finish camera revealed Mystik Dan a nose in front and Sierra Leone a nose ahead of Forever Young. In the previous renewals of the Kentucky Derby, there has never been a finish in which the first three finishers have been separated by only two noses.\n\nSaturday's 150th renewal now possesses that distinction.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346807926", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:52:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:52:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:41:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.kentucky.com/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/article288336705.html", "title": "For the first time, a Japanese horse hit the board in the Ky. Derby. A win will come soon.", "body": "As the 2024 Kentucky Derby came to a thrilling end -- with a trio of horses hitting the finish line separated by mere inches on Saturday night -- Churchill Downs track announcer Travis Stone bellowed an iconic race call from his perch high above the action.\n\n\"Here's the wire! Photo finish! Three noses on the wire: Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone and Forever Young in an international thriller!\"\n\nMystik Dan edged out the other two horses for the win in a three-way photo finish to capture a historic 150th running of the Derby.\n\nStone's signature call of the race ended on that crescendo thanks in part to the great race run by Forever Young, who became the first Japanese horse to finish in the money in the Derby with his third-place effort. That result confirmed the years of progress made by Japanese horses in the pursuit of finally winning the Run for the Roses.\n\nForever Young and fellow Japan-bred T O Password -- who are both great grandsons of 1989 Kentucky Derby winner Sunday Silence -- rewrote the record books for Japanese performance in the Derby. In addition to Forever Young's third-place effort, T O Password used a late charge to finish in fifth, a more-than credible effort given his long-shot 48-1 post-time odds.\n\nForever Young, who battled second-place finisher Sierra Leone in a rough-and-tumble stretch run, went off at 7-1 odds.\n\nThe first time a horse shipped from Japan to Louisville to run the Kentucky Derby was in 1995, when Ski Captain finished 14th. The first time a horse born in Japan competed in the Derby was Master Fencer, who finished sixth as a long shot in 2019.\n\nForever Young and T O Password represented the seventh and eighth horses all-time with ties to Japan to compete in the Run for the Roses, and they produced the two best results from that group.\n\n\"He's a very fast closing horse,\" Forever Young's jockey, Ryusei Sakai, told media members prior to the Derby via a translator. \"He's got that late kick.\"\n\nSakai, along with trainer, Yoshito Yahagi, both made their Derby debuts with Forever Young, who is 5-0-1 in six career starts and has amassed more than $2.5 million in career earnings.\n\nAt least one Japanese horse has competed in each of the last three Kentucky Derbys: Crown Pride was 13th in 2022, Mandarin Hero was 12th in 2023 and Derma Sotogake was sixth in 2023.\n\nAs the pedigree of Japanese horses has improved, so has their prominence.\n\nThere's a reason Forever Young had 7-1 odds at post time of this year's race: He came to Kentucky undefeated in five previous starts. T O Password arrived at Churchill Downs a perfect 2-for-2 in his racing career.\n\nAnd in running quality races Saturday night beneath the Twin Spires, both horses bucked significant historical trends.\n\nForever Young made the Kentucky Derby gate as a result of winning the Grade 2 UAE Derby in late March. Before him, UAE Derby runners who then raced in Louisville had never finished better than fifth in the Kentucky Derby. In addition to delivering Japan its first top-three finisher in Kentucky Derby history, Forever Young did the same for runners from the UAE Derby, a race that has existed since 2000.\n\nForever Young also became the first foreign-born horse to finish in the money in the Kentucky Derby since Great Britain-bred Bold Arrangement ran second in 1989.\n\nT O Password -- who earned his Derby spot via the Japanese qualifying pathway -- was lightly raced entering the Derby. Only one horse (Leonatus in 1883) has won the Derby with just two previous races. While T O Password finished more than six lengths behind winner Mystik Dan and behind a finishing group that also included fourth-place runner Catching Freedom, T O Password's fifth-place effort still saw him finish above a slew of top Derby contenders, including morning line and post-time favorite Fierceness (15th).\n\n\"He didn't break well,\" T O Password's jockey, Kazushi Kimura, said after the Derby. \"This was his third time running and he was in a new country. He probably wasn't 100% mature. Today he finished up strong. I hope the horse can stay for the Preakness.\"\n\nThe next step from this clear progression is for a Japanese horse to go and win the Derby, which is a feat easier said than done.\n\nNo horse bred outside of North America has won the Kentucky Derby since Great Britain's Tomy Lee in 1959.\n\nBut it's clear Japanese horses have arrived in a big way on the global racing stage.\n\nIn 2021, Japan made a big mark at the Breeders' Cup World Championships at Del Mar when Loves Only You won the Filly & Mare Turf and Marche Lorraine won the Distaff. These were the first Japanese horses to win a Breeders' Cup race.\n\nLast Friday, the Japanese also nearly scored a win on Kentucky Oaks Day at Churchill Downs: Sakai, Forever Young's jockey, was aboard T O Saint Denis in a front-running, second-place effort in the Grade 2 Alysheba Stakes.\n\nBut with the Breeders' Cup box checked, all eyes are now on the Kentucky Derby for Japanese horse racing's next big moment.\n\nAnd it should be coming soon.\n\n\"Of course they want to win the Derby,\" Sakai said of the Japanese horse racing industry prior to this year's race.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345321890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:32:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:32:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:03:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/04/kentucky-derby-victory-aboard-mystik-dan-provides-signature-win-for-jockey-brian-hernandez-jr/", "title": "Kentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Brian Hernandez Jr. will need a minute to digest his signature victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nMaybe even more time since the milestone derby capped the best weekend of a jockey career spent mostly under the radar.\n\nThe Louisiana native rode Mystik Dan to an epic win Saturday at Churchill Downs, sliding past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and holding off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish. Hernandez wasn't even sure he had won until seeing the replay and keeping his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop.\n\n\"I'm like, woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,\" the 38-year-old said. \"But then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn't really see them. And then they surged so quickly.\n\n\"I was like, 'Oh man, I hope we won. I hope we won.' And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nHernandez's derby victory aboard Mystik Dan at 18-1 odds came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire rout by 4 3/4 lengths in the 150th Kentucky Oaks. That made him the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel achieved the feat aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra, respectively, in 2009. Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez added. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn.\n\n\"I don't know how long it's going to take to sink in. It's definitely a surreal moment.\"\n\nHernandez's victory was fitting since he studied Borel's derby wins aboard Mine That Bird and Super Saver (2010), along with being around him during 20 years of racing in Kentucky. Those lessons paid off as he broke through after four derby finishes ranging from eighth to 12th, including 11th last May on Sun Thunder.\n\nHis seminal moment shouldn't have been shocking considering Hernandez already had an Eclipse Award to his name as top apprentice rider in 2004 along with a Breeders' Cup Classic win in 2012 with Fort Larned. He also was third in the Preakness two years ago with Creative Minister and has a slew of graded stakes wins.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby brings a whole different type of recognition, along with a sparkling title that will precede Hernandez for the rest of his life. McPeek asserted immediately afterward that the rider can no longer be considered underrated after a \"brilliant\" ride and called the gutsy inside path taken to victory typical for the jockey.\n\n\"He knows what to do there,\" McPeek said. \"I always had a world of confidence in him. Rarely second-guess anything he does.\"\n\nHowever, the victory created a travel issue for Hernandez, who had planned on head to Louisiana on Sunday morning for a jazz festival. It's a switch he was more than willing to make after two remarkable days that demonstrated what the right mounts can yield.\n\n\"You know, it's horse racing, it's not jockey racing,\" said Hernandez, who planned to celebrate with his wife on Saturday night. \"Just about any jockey out there, if they have the right horse, they can get them to the winner's circle. You just you have to be willing to put in the time and the effort to find the right horses.\"\n\n___\n\nThis story has been corrected to show Hernandez had one Breeders' Cup victory, not two.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Hernandez_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Brian Hernandez Jr."}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jockey", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jockey"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mine_That_Bird", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Mine That Bird"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filly", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Filly"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_racing", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Horse racing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Churchill_Downs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Churchill Downs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Associated Press"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisiana", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Louisiana"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Louisiana"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_A._Jones", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Ben A. {"uri": "2024-05-345317418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:31:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:31:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-05-04/kentucky-derby-victory-aboard-mystik-dan-provides-signature-win-for-jockey-brian-hernandez-jr", "title": "Kentucky Derby Victory Aboard Mystik Dan Provides Signature Win for Jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.", "body": "LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Brian Hernandez Jr. will need a minute to digest his signature victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby.\n\nMaybe even more time since the milestone derby capped the best weekend of a jockey career spent mostly under the radar.\n\nThe Louisiana native rode Mystik Dan to an epic win Saturday at Churchill Downs, sliding past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and holding off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish. Hernandez wasn't even sure he had won until seeing the replay and keeping his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop.\n\n\"I'm like, woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,\" the 38-year-old said. \"But then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn't really see them. And then they surged so quickly.\n\n\"I was like, 'Oh man, I hope we won. I hope we won.' And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nHernandez's derby victory aboard Mystik Dan at 18-1 odds came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire rout by 4 3/4 lengths in the 150th Kentucky Oaks. That made him the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel achieved the feat aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra, respectively, in 2009. Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez added. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn.\n\n\"I don't know how long it's going to take to sink in. It's definitely a surreal moment.\"\n\nHernandez's victory was fitting since he studied Borel's derby wins aboard Mine That Bird and Super Saver (2010), along with being around him during 20 years of racing in Kentucky. Those lessons paid off as he broke through after four derby finishes ranging from eighth to 12th, including 11th last May on Sun Thunder.\n\nHis seminal moment shouldn't have been shocking considering Hernandez already had an Eclipse Award to his name as top apprentice rider in 2004 along with a Breeders' Cup Classic win in 2012 with Fort Larned. He also was third in the Preakness two years ago with Creative Minister and has a slew of graded stakes wins.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby brings a whole different type of recognition, along with a sparkling title that will precede Hernandez for the rest of his life. McPeek asserted immediately afterward that the rider can no longer be considered underrated after a \"brilliant\" ride and called the gutsy inside path taken to victory typical for the jockey.\n\n\"He knows what to do there,\" McPeek said. \"I always had a world of confidence in him. Rarely second-guess anything he does.\"\n\nHowever, the victory created a travel issue for Hernandez, who had planned on head to Louisiana on Sunday morning for a jazz festival. It's a switch he was more than willing to make after two remarkable days that demonstrated what the right mounts can yield.\n\n\"You know, it's horse racing, it's not jockey racing,\" said Hernandez, who planned to celebrate with his wife on Saturday night. \"Just about any jockey out there, if they have the right horse, they can get them to the winner's circle. You just you have to be willing to put in the time and the effort to find the right horses.\"\n\n___\n\nThis story has been corrected to show Hernandez had one Breeders' Cup victory, not two.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
