{"uri": "8111788074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:55:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:55:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:49:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/sports/ap-sports-summarybrief-at-10-42-p-m-edt/article_9ff3f3ab-abf6-5fd1-8861-9654e2587d71.html", "title": "AP Sports SummaryBrief at 10:42 p.m. EDT", "body": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a dramatic three-horse photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone and Forever Young for the upset victory. It was the 10th Derby to be decided by a nose, the closest margin in horse racing. Sent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs on Saturday. Hernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies a day earlier with Thorpedo Anna. Mystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22 to win.\n\nEdwards scores 43 points, Reid erupts in 4th to help Timberwolves beat Nuggets 106-99 in Game 1\n\nDENVER (AP) -- Anthony Edwards scored a playoff career-high 43 points, Naz Reid had 14 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter and the Minnesota Timberwolves beat the defending NBA champion Denver Nuggets 106-99 in Game 1 of the second-round series Saturday night. Edwards was unstoppable in the first half, scoring 25 points, and Reid took over in the fourth quarter. Game 2 is Monday night in Denver. Three days after undergoing knee surgery, Timberwolves coach Chris Finch was on the bench in the second row, next to the scorer's table and behind assistant coach Micah Nori, who did the instructing, roaming and switching. Two-time NBA MVP Nikola Jokic had 32 points, eight rebounds and nine assists for Denver.\n\nMessi has a record-setting game with a goal and 5 assists in Inter Miami's 6-2 win over Red Bulls\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- Lionel Messi set three MLS records with a goal and five assists as Inter Miami trounced the New York Red Bulls 6-2. His six goal contributions, five assists and five assists in a half were all league records. Fresh after earning MLS Player of the Month Award for April, Messi has scored and assisted in six consecutive league matches. Luis Su\u00e1rez had three goals and Matias Rojas scored twice as Inter Miami scored six unanswered goals to come from a 1-0 deficit at halftime. Inter Miami remains atop the Eastern Conference with 24 points. Dante Vanzeir gave New York the first-half lead. The Red Bulls dropped to 4-2-5.\n\nReal Madrid wins its record-extending 36th Spanish league title after Barcelona loses at Girona\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Real Madrid has won its record-extending 36th Spanish league title after securing an insurmountable 13-point lead over second-place Girona with four games remaining. Madrid reclaimed the domestic crown after beating Cadiz 3-0 earlier Saturday and Barcelona then lost 4-2 at Girona. Only a victory by Barcelona would have stopped Madrid from celebrating. Girona leapfrogged Barcelona and pushed its Catalan rival into third place at 14 points behind Madrid. Madrid hosts Bayern Munich in the Champions League on Wednesday with their semifinal evenly balanced after a 2-2 first-leg draw in Germany.\n\nTaylor Pendrith leads Byron Nelson as one of several seeking first PGA Tour victory\n\nMcKINNEY, Texas (AP) -- Taylor Pendrith has a one-shot lead going into the final round of the CJ Cup Byron Nelson. The Canadian is among several leaders seeking his first PGA Tour victory. Pendrith chipped in twice for consecutive eagles to kick-start his round of 8-under 63. It's the third time for back-to-back eagles on tour this season. Pendrith is at 19 under, one shot ahead of second-round leader Jake Knapp. First-round leader Matt Wallace is another shot back in a tie with Ben Kohles.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nKentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode Mystik Dan to victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby to complete the most rewarding weekend of his career. The Eclipse Award winner and Breeders' Cup champion won the milestone derby a day after guiding filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire victory by 4 3/4 lengths in the Kentucky Oaks. He became the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009, fitting considering Hernandez studied Borel's derby wins and spent time with him in his Kentucky racing career. And, he's no longer under the radar as a jockey.\n\nKentucky Derby fans pack the track for the 150th Run for the Roses\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Fans packed into Churchill Downs Saturday for the 150th Kentucky Derby, the longest continuously held sporting event in the country, and many said they felt the milestone made race day feel extra special this year. Some said that as they approached the track, they imagined what Churchill Downs must have been at that first race on May 17, 1875, when patrons arrived to watch the horses by riding horses there themselves. The 150th Run for the Roses would be unrecognizable to the 10,000 people who attended that first race. More than 157,000 arrived at Churchill Down from all over the United States for a dayslong spectacle of huge hats and mint juleps.\n\nYankees slugger Aaron Judge ejected for first time in his career\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- New York Yankees slugger Aaron Judge was ejected for the first time in his career when he argued a called third strike by plate umpire Ryan Blakney in the seventh inning of Saturday's game against the Detroit Tigers. With one out, Judge took a full count fastball from Tyler Holton that he thought was slightly outside. Blakney rang him up, Judge glanced back and was ejected. After starting to walk back to the dugout, Judge returned to argue the call and manager Aaron Boone continued the argument.\n\nMaple Leafs star Auston Matthews is available for Game 7 with Bruins after sitting last 2 games\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- Maple Leafs star and NHL goal-scoring leader Auston Matthews is available for their Game 7 matchup with the Boston Bruins. Matthews missed the last two games while dealing with an unspecified illness and had just four shots combined in Games 3 and 4. He had the Game 2 winner for the Maples Leafs, who are tied with Boston 3-3 in the first-round series. Toronto also announced that goalie Joseph Woll will not play in Game 7 due to an injury sustained in Game 6. Ilya Samsonov will get the nod between the pipes in his place. Samsonov started the first four games of the series when Toronto fell into a 3-1 hole and was outscored 12-6.\n\nHaaland scores 4 in another win for Man City. Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though\n\nErling Haaland scored four goals in another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown. Yet Arsenal isn't going away in this title race. Haaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton. It was a response to Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth a few hours earlier. Arsenal retained its one-point lead over City but the defending champions have three games left. That's one more than Arsenal. {"uri": "8111693095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:17:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:17:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:09:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/meet-brian-hernandez-jockey-rode-233525769.html", "title": "Meet Brian Hernandez, the jockey who rode Mystik Dan to victory in Kentucky Derby 2024", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr. was all smiles with the biggest race of his life hanging in the balance.\n\nThe 38-year-old jockey from Lafayette, Louisiana, knew what the photo finish was going to reveal; that he and Mystic Dan emerged victorious by a nose over Sierra Leone in Kentucky Derby 150.\n\nHernandez broke an 0-for-4 drought and made history Saturday at Churchill Downs, becoming just the eighth jockey to hit the Oaks/Derby double. The last person to do it was a fellow Louisianan, Calvin Borel (2009).\n\nHernandez also delivered Lexington-based trainer Kenny McPeek his first Derby win in 10 tries. McPeek became just the third trainer (and the first since 1952) to hit the Oaks/Derby double.\n\nIt was also successful debut for owners Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing (Brent Gasaway) and Daniel Hamby.\n\nAfter a dominant 4 3/4-length win Friday in Oaks 150 aboard Thorpedo Anna, Hernandez and the son of Goldencents broke from Post 3 at 18-1 odds and covered 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34.\n\nIt was too close to call at the finish line at the finish line between them and Sierra Leone, ridden by reigning Oaks winner Tyler Gaffalione.\n\nMystik Dan improved to 3-1-1 across seven career starts -- and undefeated with Hernandez aboard with Saturday's win. The duo was coming off a third-place finish in the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby on March 30 at Oaklawn.\n\nThe son of a jockey, Hernandez began galloping horses for trainer Dale Angelle at age 12 and began his riding career at Delta Downs in November 2003, exercising horses in the mornings before high school classes and riding at night.\n\nAfter graduating from high school in May 2004, he headed to Churchill Downs, where he rode for a few weeks before returning to Louisiana and capturing his first riding title at Evangeline Downs.\n\nHernandez made his Derby debut in 2016, when he placed 12th with Tom's Ready. Until Saturday, his best finish was eighth in 2017 with McCraken.\n\nHe and McPeek have teamed up for each of his past three starts in the Run for the Roses. He placed ninth in 2021 with Tiz the Bomb and 11th last year with Sun Thunder.\n\nThis story will be updated.\n\nReach Louisville men's basketball reporter Brooks Holton at bholton@gannett.com and {"uri": "8112777722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "20:27:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T20:27:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T20:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.capitalgazette.com/2024/05/05/preakness-kentucky-derby-champion-mystik-dan-wait-and-see/", "title": "Preakness 2024: Kentucky Derby champ Mystik Dan a wait-and-see for second leg of Triple Crown", "body": "Kentucky Derby champion Mystik Dan will rest and recover over the next week before his owners and trainer Kenny McPeek make a \"last-minute decision\" about whether to point him toward the May 18 Preakness Stakes, expected to feature a field dominated by fresher horses.\n\nAs the new champ posed for photos outside his barn at Churchill Downs on Sunday morning, co-owner Lance Gasaway said he would only want his horse to run in the $2 million Preakness if he has a strong chance to win. He noted that Bob Baffert-trained Muth, who beat Mystik Dan in the March 30 Arkansas Derby, is one of several well-rested contenders lining up to run at Pimlico Race Course.\n\n\"You take those horses in there at full speed, who have been off a month and a half and we're coming in off two weeks, that's a big ask of this horse,\" Gasaway told reporters in Louisville. \"We'll have to see how he comes out of the race.\"\n\nMcPeek said Mystik Dan will walk the next few days before he returns to training on the track at Churchill Downs, probably Wednesday. \"So we'll watch him over the next week, and probably decide then,\" he said of a possible Preakness entry (the deadline is May 13). \"It will be a last-minute decision. We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nMcPeek, who has won all three Triple Crown races after Mystik Dan outlasted Sierra Leone and Forever Young in a thrilling photo finish Saturday, acknowledged his reluctance to run back on short rest.\n\n\"When I ran him back in two weeks before, it completely backfired on me,\" he said, alluding to a pair of starts from Mystik Dan's 2-year-old season. He finished fifth in a flat performance at Churchill Downs in November, 13 days after his breakout victory on the same track.\n\nIf Mystik Dan were to skip the Preakness, he would be the second Derby champion to do so in the last three years after longshot winner Rick Strike went straight from Kentucky to the Belmont Stakes in 2022. Such a move would rekindle fears that the second jewel in the Triple Crown is becoming an afterthought. Few trainers even consider running their Derby horses two weeks later at Pimlico, believing the quick turnaround to be too great an ask for 3-year-olds no longer conditioned for such condensed rigor.\n\nThe last four Preakness winners did not run in the Derby. Justify was the last to win both races on his way to a Triple Crown in 2018.\n\nMuth earned enough qualifying points for a berth in the Derby and would have been among the top contenders, but his trainer, Baffert, remains barred from Churchill Downs because of the medication violation that cost Medina Spirit his 2021 Derby victory. Owner Amr Zedan sued unsuccessfully to get his horse into the 20-horse Derby field. Muth will instead enter the Preakness off seven weeks of rest.\n\nBaffert won his eighth Preakness last year with a similarly fresh horse, National Treasure, and his pair of Muth and Imagination, runner-up in the April 6 Santa Anita Derby, will present a daunting obstacle to any Derby runner looking to bounce back at Pimlico.\n\nNeither Sierra Leone nor Forever Young, the two horses that nearly caught Mystik Dan in the Derby, will run in the Preakness. Sierra Leone is headed for trainer Chad Brown's barn at Saratoga, New York, where he'll train for the June 8 Belmont Stakes (to be held at Saratoga Race Course because Belmont Park is under renovation). Forever Young is scheduled to fly back to Japan before a possible return to U.S. competition later this year.\n\nTrainer Brad Cox hasn't ruled out a Preakness run for Catching Freedom, but the Maryland Jockey Club did not include the fourth-place Derby finisher on its initial list of possible contenders, indicating that Cox is leaning against it.\n\nOther possible Preakness entrants include Seize the Grey, winner of the Pat Day Mile on the Derby undercard and trained by six-time Preakness winner D. Wayne Lukas; Copper Tax, winner of the April 20 Federico Tesio Stakes at Laurel Park, and Informed Patriot, winner of the April 20 Bathhouse Row Stakes at Arkansas' Oaklawn Park and trained by two-time Preakness winner Steve Asmussen.\n\nThe connections of Uncle Heavy, fifth in the April 6 Wood Memorial, and Tuscan Gold, third in the Louisiana Derby and trained by two-time Preakness winner Brown, will decide between the Preakness and the Peter Pan Stakes at New York's Aqueduct Racetrack, the Daily Racing Form reported.\n\nPimlico was the scene for one of McPeek's most satisfying victories when the relentless filly Swiss Skydiver outfought Baffert-trained Derby champion Authentic in the pandemic-delayed 2020 Preakness.\n\nWhen Maryland Jockey Club interim president Mike Rogers called Sunday morning to extend a formal Preakness invitation to Mystik Dan, McPeek thanked him and asked but one question: Would his ubiquitous yellow Labrador, Sonny, be allowed to accompany the Derby champion to Pimlico?\n\nIt was a jovial moment, and Preakness organizers hope to have both horse and dog on hand for the third Saturday in May.\n\nWhether that will be a reality remains an open question.", "source": {"uri": "capitalgazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Capital Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": "childs_walker@capitalgazette.com", "name": "Childs Walker", "type": "author", He took off down the stretch and built a slight lead.\n\n\"When he shot through that spot, he was able to cut the corner and I asked him to go for it,\" Hernandez said. \"He shot off and I'm like, 'Oh man, I've got a big chance to win the Kentucky Derby.\"'", "source": {"uri": "canoe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Canoe"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@canoe.com", "name": "Associated {"uri": "8114381097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:01:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:01:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:01:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.on3.com/teams/kentucky-wildcats/news/kentucky-derby-the-agony-of-defeat-churchill-downs/", "title": "Kentucky Derby: The Agony of Defeat", "body": "The pain starts in the shin, wraps around the back of the leg and creeps up into the lower back. That's the pain of walking miles and miles around Churchill Downs over a week's time and it's incomparable to what the connections of Forever Young and Sierra Leone must feel after coming up inches short of winning the Kentucky Derby.\n\nThe 150th running of the Kentucky Derby delivered in the best way possible. Patrons were welcomed to the racetrack with a beautiful spring day that didn't make men sweat through their tailored suits. Anticipation bubbled in the air throughout the day until the horses reached the starting gate for post time at the Kentucky Derby.\n\nBrian Hernandez guided Mystik Dan down the rail and the horse appeared to pull away down the stretch, but only for a moment. Forever Young and Sierra Leone were closing quickly, but could they catch him? The latter had enough in the tank, but couldn't stay in a straight line.\n\n\"I felt like I had plenty of horse,\" said Sierra Leone's rider, Tyler Gafflione. \"He wanted to lean in today and made it a little difficult. I had a hard time keeping him straight and that definitely cost us. He gives you everything, very responsive but he loses concentration.\"\n\nThat lean-in on Forever Young frustrated many of the Japanese horse's backers, who believed an inquiry could've moved him up to second. They weren't as gracious as Chad Brown, Sierra Leone's trainer who is still searching for his first Derby winner.\n\n\"You get beat a nose in the Kentucky Derby, it's a tough one,\" said Brown. \"But he's a tremendous horse, nearly undefeated. I'm just so lucky to have him, so proud of his effort today. He did what we asked him to do, just came up a little bit short.\"\n\nLife is a game of inches. Having grace after coming up inches short in an agonizing defeat is admirable.\n\nSomething unusual happened following the Kentucky Derby. A frequent flyer to the Infield on the biggest race day of the year, I'm familiar with the roars that follow the horses. For the first time, there was not a roar once the horses crossed the finish line.\n\nA quiet confusion filled the air. It was eerie.\n\nHours of build-up for the two-minute sprint ended dramatically with uncertainty. Nobody knew who won. Most in the crowd thought Mystik Dan held on, but no one holding a No. 3 ticket was willing to begin the celebration until a replay was shown. Even then, the response was tepid. Once the photo finish was revealed, my elated neighbor could finally exhale and enjoy a winning Pick 4 wager.\n\nThurby brought the heat, quite literally. A day after sweaty, long lines, patrons got cooled down by off-and-on rain on Oaks Day. It was welcomed with open arms. The poncho stayed packed away until the clouds began to roll in just after Thorpedo Anna crossed the finish line first. What followed was a Derby Week tradition, the post-race downpour.\n\nI've been stuck in plenty of those. The protocol is simple: hide under the tarp for a good old-fashioned tarp party. This was an extended one. After about 30 minutes, my friend told us to peek out underneath the tarp: we were the only people still in the middle of the Infield. My hat is still drying out from the deluge.\n\nSpeaking of hats, what once was excluded for Derby Day has now become a year-round trend. Yankee Doodle called it macaroni, but I'm not sure what the trendsetters are saying to describe wide-brimmed hats that are covered in different fabrics and feathers. One person I spotted at a post-Derby party had a used match tucked into the side of his hat and I don't think I've seen anything cooler in my life.\n\nThe new development in this year's fashion is the wife beater. Yes, the ribbed sleeveless shirt is back in style, but only if it's worn beneath a suit. It was all of the rage all Derby weekend among the racetrack's most stylish guests, a category which does not include myself.\n\nChurchill Downs track announcer Travis Stone is the best of the best. How can you tell? The key to the race was punctuated by Stone in real-time. \"Mystik Dan cut the corner!\" The drama could be felt through his voice until they reached the finish line. \"Here's the wire -- PHOTO FINISH -- three noses on the wire, Mystik Dan, Sierra Leone, and Forever Young in an International Thriller!\"\n\nThe world watched the finish in awe. On the same day NBC extended its contract with the first leg of the Triple Crown through 2032, the Kentucky Derby drew an average of 16.7 million viewers, the most since 1989. It peaked from 7-7:15 pm with 20.1 million viewers, the leargest peak audience ever for a Kentucky Derby on NBC.\n\nFriday afternoon I was devastated by a mistake. Three others trusted me to put together a Pick 5 ticket. We singled the opener and continued riding the good vibes until the last leg. In the final race a 20-1 Mike Maker horse crossed the finish line first. I was betting Mike Maker horses all day, surely I didn't throw it out on accident, right? Wrong.\n\nI kicked myself for making that costly $850 mistake until the American Turf. Graham Motion's turf horses always get at least a second look and on Kentucky Derby Day I was willing to wager a little extra on the long shot. Trikari finished first at 47-to-1. For the first time in a long time, I finished my week of wagering with more money in my pocket than when I started. It only takes one.\n\nThanks to everyone who tuned in for all of our coverage leading into the Kentucky Derby. The response from folks I saw last week was overwhelming. It's a grind, but it's all worth it. Thousands of folks checked out what a multitude of racing experts had to say about the race on the KSR YouTube Channel. They provided excellent insight, but none of them could replicate Kaitlin Free's performance. A frequent contributor on the big screen from the Paddock, in the interview below she basically described exactly how the race would unfold the day before it happened. {"uri": "8112543216", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:07:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:07:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:04:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/sport/archives/2024/05/06/2003817439", "title": "Mystik Dan wins Kentucky Derby photo finish - Taipei Times", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr will need a minute to digest his signature victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby on Saturday. Maybe even more time since the milestone derby capped the best weekend of a jockey career spent mostly under the radar.\n\nThe Louisiana native rode Mystik Dan to an epic win at Churchill Downs, sliding past favorite Fierceness along the rail at the final turn and holding off Sierra Leone and Forever Young by a nose in an epic three-horse photo finish.\n\nHernandez was not even sure he had won until seeing the replay and keeping his eyes glued to the flat screen that showed the continuous loop.\n\n\"I'm like: 'Woo, I think we just won the Kentucky Derby,' but then those horses, they were so far out there, you couldn't really see them, and then they surged so quickly,\" the 38-year-old said. \"I was like: 'Oh man, I hope we won. I hope we won.' And then when they hung up our number, it was just instant relief.\"\n\nHernandez's derby victory aboard Mystik Dan at 18-1 odds came a day after he rode filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire rout by four and three-quarter lengths in the 150th Kentucky Oaks.\n\nThat made him the first jockey to complete the Derby-Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel achieved the feat in 2009 aboard Mine That Bird and filly Rachel Alexandra respectively. Kenny McPeek became the first trainer to earn the double since Ben Jones in 1952.\n\n\"We came into the weekend thinking we had really good chances both Friday and Saturday,\" Hernandez said. \"To have the horses pull it off for us, we really have to thank all the guys back in the barn.\"\n\n\"I don't know how long it's going to take to sink in. It's definitely a surreal moment,\" he added.\n\nHernandez's victory was fitting since he studied Borel's derby wins aboard Mine That Bird and Super Saver (2010), along with being around him during 20 years of racing in Kentucky.\n\nThose lessons paid off as he broke through after four derby finishes ranging from eighth to 12th, including 11th last May on Sun Thunder.\n\nHis seminal moment should not have been shocking considering Hernandez already had an Eclipse Award to his name as top apprentice rider in 2004 along with a Breeders' Cup Classic win in 2012 with Fort Larned. He was also third in the Preakness two years ago with Creative Minister and has a slew of graded stakes wins.\n\nWinning the Kentucky Derby brings a whole different type of recognition, along with a sparkling title that will precede Hernandez for the rest of his life.\n\nMcPeek said immediately afterward that the rider can no longer be considered underrated after a \"brilliant\" ride, and called the gutsy inside path taken to victory typical for the jockey.\n\n\"He knows what to do there,\" McPeek said. \"I always had a world of confidence in him. LiMay 5, 2024 at 1:09 AM\n\nLightly regarded Mystik Dan scored a thrilling upset at the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, winning by a nose and bringing a career Triple Crown to trainer Kenny McPeek.\n\nRail-riding Mystik Dan stuck his nose in front of second favorite Sierra Leone for the dramatic three-horse photo-finish victory that took several minutes to hash out.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if we had won,\" jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. told NBC Sports shortly after the race. \"So it was quite a rush to sit here and wait for it.\"\n\nMystik Dan came into the Derby with a relatively thin resume that included a third-place finish at the Arkansas Derby and a win at the Grade III Southwest Stakes.\n\nIt was the first Derby triumph for both McPeek and Hernandez. McPeek had previously trained filly Swiss Skydiver, the 2020 Preakness Stakes champion, and Sarava, long-shot winner of the 2002 Belmont Stakes.\n\nMcPeek effusively praised Hernandez and his ride.\n\n\"Just a brilliant, brilliant, brilliant, brilliant jockey and ride,\" the trainer said. \"Brian's amazing.\"\n\nMystik Dan's Triple Crown quest will continue on May 18 with the 149th running of the Preakness Stakes in Baltimore.\n\nBefore Saturday's 12th race at Churchill Downs unfolded, celebrities and big hats filled the clubhouse, grandstands and paddock under Louisville's famed twin spires.\n\nWynonna Judd performed the national anthem, leading a stable of boldface names from the entertainment world such as Sheryl Lee Ralph, Chris Tucker, Kid Rock, Jack Harlow, Jimmy Fallon, Travis Tritt, Josh Groban, Holly Robinson Peete and Richie Sambora.\n\nLifestyle maven Martha Stewart and football figures such as dateless Travis Kelce, Aaron Rodgers, Jameis Winston, Isiah Pacheco and Emmett Smith were also in attendance.\n\nThe Derby day also included a host of other big-money races.\n\nLong shot Trikari rallied to a thrilling upset victory in the American Turf Stakes. The 47-1 dark horse roared past favorite Formidable Man in the final strides of the $600,000 race.\n\nGun Pilot pulled away to victory at the $1 million Churchill Downs Stakes, adding to the long winning resume of trainer Steve Asmussen.\n\nProgram Trading edged Naval Power to dramatically win the $1 million Turf Classic Stakes.\n\nSeize The Grey won the $600,000 Pat Day Mile Stakes.\n\nChili Flag took the $750,000 Churchill Distaff Turk Miles Stakes.\n\nVahva rallied late to win the $100,000 Derby City Distaff.\n\nCogburn raced to victory at the $600,000 Turf Sprint Stakes.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_k_li@aol.com", "name": "David K. But after today's win at the historic 150th running of the Kentucky Derby, Mystik Dan became a multi-million dollar horse.\n\nThis year's prize pool for the Kentucky Derby was one of the biggest ever at a whopping $5 million - and Mystik Dan's connections are going to get the majority of that money.\n\nAccording to Equibase, Mystik Dan receives $3.1 million in prize money for his victory. That's six times his career winnings from his first six career races combined.\n\nMystik Dan isn't the only horse leaving Churchill Downs with a good chunk of change though. Second-place finisher Sierra Leone will also become an instant millionaire, more than doubling his career earnings with a $1 million prize.\n\nThird-place finisher Forever Young from Japan won $500,000. Catching Freedom, who finished fourth, won $250,000. Finally, Japan's T O Freedom takes home $150,000 after finishing fifth.\n\nIt remains to be seen how long Mystik Dan's connections want to keep the horse racing. Once they decide whether to pursue the Triple Crown and race him at Pimlico, they may have to make the business decision whether to keep racing him or put him out to stud.\n\nThe real earning potential in a race horse isn't in the races they compete in, but in post-racing stud fees, which can go into the hundreds of thousands if they start producing race winners.\n\nWill Mystik Dan keep Now, with the booming popularity of the NFL and other professional team sports, horse racing has been pushed further down the list in terms of general public recognition on a daily basis.\n\n\"But in America, with so many sports competing for the entertainment dollar, we've become a society that is focused on the big events. The Super Bowl. A lot of people don't even watch the NFL until you get to the Super Bowl. Golf. Many people don't pay attention to golf until you get to the Masters or the U.S. Open. A lot of people don't watch NCAA basketball until you get to the NCAA Tournament. The same applies to the Kentucky Derby.\"\n\nThe Kentucky Derby was officially a sell out of course. Back when tickets were available, standing-room general admission tickets had a starting price of $275. A private suite would run you $135,000 to reserve to watch the Run for the Roses.\n\nIf you wanted to have a seat at Churchill Downs, well, those were priced at a minimum of $650. {"uri": "2024-05-345281481", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:42:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:42:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:35:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://eu.courier-journal.com/story/sports/horses/kentucky-derby/2024/05/04/jockey-brian-hernandez-mystik-dan-kentucky-derby-2024-churchill-downs/73088678007/", "title": "Meet Brian Hernandez, the jockey who rode Mystik Dan to victory in Kentucky Derby 2024", "body": "Brian Hernandez Jr. was all smiles with the biggest race of his life hanging in the balance.\n\nThe 38-year-old jockey from Lafayette, Louisiana, knew what the photo finish was going to reveal; that he and Mystic Dan emerged victorious by a nose in Kentucky Derby 150.\n\nHernandez broke an 0-for-4 drought and made history Saturday at Churchill Downs, becoming just the eighth jockey to hit the Oaks/Derby double. The last person to do it was a fellow Louisianan, Calvin Borel (2009).\n\nHernandez also delivered trainer Kenny McPeek his first Derby win in 10 tries. McPeek became just the third trainer (and the first since 1952) to hit the Oaks/Derby double.\n\nAfter his dominant 4 3/4-length win Friday in Oaks 150 aboard Thorpedo Anna, Hernandez and the son of Goldencents broke from Post 3 at 18-1 odds and covered 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34.\n\nMystik Dan improved to 3-1-1 across seven career starts -- and undefeated with Hernandez aboard with Saturday's win. The duo was coming off a third-place finish in the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby on March 30 at Oaklawn.\n\nThe son of a jockey, Hernandez began galloping horses for trainer Dale Angelle at age 12 and began his riding career at Delta Downs in November 2003, exercising horses in the mornings before high school classes and riding at night.\n\nAfter graduating from high school in May 2004, he headed to Churchill Downs, where he rode for a few weeks before returning to Louisiana and capturing his first riding title at Evangeline Downs.\n\nHernandez made his Derby debut in 2016, when he placed 12th with Tom's Ready. Until Saturday, his best finish was eighth in 2017 with McCraken.\n\nThis story will be updated.", "source": {"uri": "courier-journal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Courier-Journal"}, Reactions to Mystik Dan's Kentucky Derby win", "body": "The 156,710 attendees present for Mystik Dan's photo-finish victory in the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby Saturday erupted as the horses rounded the turn.\n\nSeveral challengers battled for the lead in the tight race, but, ultimately, three horses surged in the final moments - Sierra Leone, Forever Young and Mystik Dan.\n\nIt was Mystic Dan by a nose.\n\nThe Kentucky Derby winner, now 3-1-1 in seven career starts, entered the Run for the Roses at 18-1 odds. Second-place finisher Sierra Leone went at 9-2 odds, while third-place finisher Forever Young went at 6-1 odds.\n\nAnd while Mystik Dan will take home $3.1 million, spectators savvy enough to bet on him should be pleased to learn the horse paid $39.22 to win.\n\nNaturally, with a finish so iconic, fans around the globe were eager to give their reactions. Here are some of the standouts.\n\nShock. Disbelief. Celebration.\n\nOne fan even reposted a clip of basketball commentator Kevin Harlan's viral calling of No. 13 Furman men's basketball's upset of No. 4 Virginia in the first round of the 2023 NCAA Tournament, during which he yells \"Did we just see what we think we saw? uncalled fouls.\n\nAnd, of course, there were several people who likened the exciting finish to the Dinoco 400 in the 2006 Disney Pixar classic film \"Cars.\"\n\nThe race ends in a photo finish where lead character Lightning McQueen sticks out his tongue in hopes of crossing the finish line first, but instead ends up causing a three-way tie.\n\nHere's one safe bet for the day: Not even the Derby, {"uri": "8111812792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:27:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:27:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:25:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/sports/ap-sports-summarybrief-at-11-15-p-m-edt/article_9ff3f3ab-abf6-5fd1-8861-9654e2587d71.html", "title": "AP Sports SummaryBrief at 11:15 p.m. EDT", "body": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a dramatic three-horse photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone and Forever Young for the upset victory. It was the 10th Derby to be decided by a nose, the closest margin in horse racing. Sent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs on Saturday. Hernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies a day earlier with Thorpedo Anna. Mystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22 to win.\n\nKentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode Mystik Dan to victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby to complete the most rewarding weekend of his career. The Eclipse Award winner and Breeders' Cup champion won the milestone derby a day after guiding filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire victory by 4 3/4 lengths in the Kentucky Oaks. He became the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009, fitting considering Hernandez studied Borel's derby wins and spent time with him in his Kentucky racing career. And, he's no longer under the radar as a jockey.\n\nEdwards scores 43 points, Reid erupts in 4th to help Timberwolves beat Nuggets 106-99 in Game 1\n\nDENVER (AP) -- Anthony Edwards scored a playoff career-high 43 points, Naz Reid had 14 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter and the Minnesota Timberwolves beat the defending NBA champion Denver Nuggets 106-99 in Game 1 of the second-round series Saturday night. Edwards was unstoppable in the first half, scoring 25 points, and Reid took over in the fourth quarter. Game 2 is Monday night in Denver. Three days after undergoing knee surgery, Timberwolves coach Chris Finch was on the bench in the second row, next to the scorer's table and behind assistant coach Micah Nori, who did the instructing, roaming and switching. Two-time NBA MVP Nikola Jokic had 32 points, eight rebounds and nine assists for Denver.\n\nMessi has a record-setting game with a goal and 5 assists in Inter Miami's 6-2 win over Red Bulls\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- Lionel Messi set three MLS records with a goal and five assists as Inter Miami trounced the New York Red Bulls 6-2. His six goal contributions, five assists and five assists in a half were all league records. Fresh after earning MLS Player of the Month Award for April, Messi has scored and assisted in six consecutive league matches. Luis Su\u00e1rez had three goals and Matias Rojas scored twice as Inter Miami scored six unanswered goals to come from a 1-0 deficit at halftime. Inter Miami remains atop the Eastern Conference with 24 points. Dante Vanzeir gave New York the first-half lead. The Red Bulls dropped to 4-2-5.\n\nTaylor Pendrith leads Byron Nelson as one of several seeking first PGA Tour victory\n\nMcKINNEY, Texas (AP) -- Taylor Pendrith has a one-shot lead going into the final round of the CJ Cup Byron Nelson. The Canadian is among several leaders seeking his first PGA Tour victory. Pendrith chipped in twice for consecutive eagles to kick-start his round of 8-under 63. It's the third time for back-to-back eagles on tour this season. Pendrith is at 19 under, one shot ahead of second-round leader Jake Knapp. First-round leader Matt Wallace is another shot back in a tie with Ben Kohles.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nYankees slugger Aaron Judge ejected for first time in his career\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- New York Yankees slugger Aaron Judge was ejected for the first time in his career when he argued a called third strike by plate umpire Ryan Blakney in the seventh inning of Saturday's game against the Detroit Tigers. With one out, Judge took a full count fastball from Tyler Holton that he thought was slightly outside. Blakney rang him up, Judge glanced back and was ejected. After starting to walk back to the dugout, Judge returned to argue the call and manager Aaron Boone continued the argument.\n\nHaaland scores 4 in another win for Man City. Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though\n\nErling Haaland scored four goals in another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown. Yet Arsenal isn't going away in this title race. Haaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton. It was a response to Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth a few hours earlier. Arsenal retained its one-point lead over City but the defending champions have three games left. That's one more than Arsenal. Burnley slipped closer to relegation with a 4-1 loss to Newcastle.\n\nReal Madrid wins its record-extending 36th Spanish league title after Barcelona loses at Girona\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Real Madrid has won its record-extending 36th Spanish league title after securing an insurmountable 13-point lead over second-place Girona with four games remaining. Madrid reclaimed the domestic crown after beating Cadiz 3-0 earlier Saturday and Barcelona then lost 4-2 at Girona. Only a victory by Barcelona would have stopped Madrid from celebrating. Girona leapfrogged Barcelona and pushed its Catalan rival into third place at 14 points behind Madrid. Madrid hosts Bayern Munich in the Champions League on Wednesday with their semifinal evenly balanced after a 2-2 first-leg draw in Germany.\n\nCavaliers and Magic to settle playoff series standoff with Game 7 -- the 'best two words in sports'\n\nCLEVELAND (AP) -- The Cavs and Magic are going to the limit. Unable to find a way to win on the road, Cleveland and Orlando will settle their series on Sunday with a Game 7, a fitting conclusion between two teams that have put their strengths and weaknesses on public display for six games. Only one advances to face the Boston Celtics, who will be well-rested for whichever team escapes this stalemate. The Magic forced Game 7 with a 103-96 at home on Friday night by withstanding a 50-point performance from Cleveland guard Donovan Mitchell.\n\nMax Verstappen ties Alain Prost's record with 6th pole-winning run to open an F1 season\n\nMIAMI GARDENS, Fla. (AP) -- Max Verstappen inched closer to a third consecutive win at the Miami Grand Prix on Saturday by continuing his long domination of Formula 1 qualifying. The three-time reigning F1 champion won his seventh consecutive pole, but first at Miami, where Verstappen failed to earn the top starting spot in the first two races around Hard Rock Stadium, yet still won them both. The pole-winning run tied Verstappen with Alain Prost in opening the season with six consecutive poles. Prost did it in 1993. Verstappen opened Saturday with a win in the sprint race and ended the day with his 38th career pole. The Red Bull driver beat the Ferraris of Charles Leclerc and Carlos Sainz Jr. and will lead the field to green on Sunday for the first of F1's three races this year in the United States.", "source": Two years ago, Woodford County's Eric Reed, the trainer of an even bigger longshot Derby winner, chose to keep Rich Strike out of the Preakness Stakes. Reed said McPeek will make sure the Derby didn't take too much out of Mystik Dan.\n\n\"These decisions are tough, because you've got a lot of fallout from the press, and the media and political stuff, you know, history. But Kenny knows, he knows how to handle that situation. And guarantee, whatever decision he makes will be the right one for that horse.\"\n\nReed said Richie, as he was known around the farm, needed longer to recover, mentally, and ran a different type of race.\n\n\"He was a deep closer, and Pimlico was for horses that can be up near the pace, they have to have some some tactical early speed. He had none of that. So you know, we had two great big things going against us.\"\n\nReed said McPeek, who pulled off a rare one-two by winning the Kentucky Oaks the day before, is a great trainer who'll make the right decision for Mystik Dan. The connections now have a chance to contend for the even more prestigious Triple Crown. But will they send him to Pimlico?\n\nAt the trophy presentation after winning the Kentucky Derby, Mystik Dan's co-owner Lance Gasaway was asked if he'll run in the Preakness Stakes in two weeks at Pimlico. Gasaway, who was clearly overcome with emotion at the time, could only respond with a \"we'll discuss it.\"\n\nThis shouldn't be too hard of a decision for Mystik Dan's but it has proven to be so for a number of Kentucky Derby winners in recent years. 2022 Kentucky Derby winner Rich Strike and 2019 Kentucky Derby winner Country House were both pulled from the ensuing Preakness Stakes race due to health reasons.\n\nLast year's Derby winner, Mage, finished third.\n\nThe final decision will most likely be made by Mystik Dan's trainer, Kenneth McPeek. This was McPeek's first win in the Run for the Roses so the opportunity to make history has to be appealing at a certain level. He knows Pimlico well, having trained Swiss Skydiver to victory in the 2020 Preakness Stakes.\n\nBut the Preakness is just two weeks away and one of the reasons that only three horses in the last 10 years have won both is that fresh horses who just missed qualifying for the Kentucky Derby will be allowed to compete.\n\nLest we forget, two-time Triple Crown winner Bob Baffert was not able to enter any of his horses into the Derby this year and he's got a stable full of contenders who are probably eager to steal a Triple Crown bid from Mystik Dan's connections.\n\nWill Mystik Dan make the trip to Pimlico? {"uri": "8112380713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:21:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:21:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:21:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://thesportsgrail.com/who-is-jockey-brian-bj-hernandez-jr-bio-age-height-family-wife-and-career-earnings/", "title": "Who is jockey Brian 'BJ' Hernandez Jr, bio, age, height, family, wife and career earnings", "body": "Here is all you need to know about Brian \"BJ\" Hernandez Jr including his height and bio\n\nBrian \"B.J.\" Hernandez Jr won the 2024 Kentucky Derby with Mystik Dan trained by Kenneth McPeek.\n\nMystik Dan's trainer, Ken McPeek, makes history by being the first trainer to win the Oaks and Derby in the same year since 1952.\n\nBrian \"B.J.\" Hernandez Jr is a joceky born on November 3, 1985, in Lafayette, Louisiana. On November 29, 2003, in Louisiana's Delta Downs, he won his first race as a professional in 2003.\n\nHis height stands at 5 feet 11 inches and he weighs 86 kg.\n\nThe American Eclipse Award-winning jockey in Thoroughbred horse racing rode his first winning horse at Delta Downs in Vinton, Louisiana, in 2003. Three years later, in the 2006 Indiana Derby (G2), the rookie jockey rode Cielo Gold to victory, marking the first of his 51 career graded stakes wins.\n\nBrian got exposed to riding ever since he was born. In southern Louisiana, racing has traditionally been a family affair. But the Hernandez family, who ride, has taken it to a whole new level. He was born into a family of riders. His father and brothers all are riders.\n\nThe pinnacle of Hernandez's career came with his Breeders' Cup Classic triumph in 2012 with Ian Wilkes's Fort Larned. His most well-known accomplishment was working with Girvin, who for trainer Joe Sharp won the 2017 Louisiana Derby (G2) and Risen Star (G2).\n\nThe first Hernandez child to carry on his father's legacy was Brian Jr. Having gone by \"B.J.\" since childhood and now has surpassed his father in notoriety. He won the Eclipse Award in 2004 for being the top apprentice, and he with Fort Larned won the Breeders' Cup Classic in 2012. With 1,224 career wins, he is now chasing close on his father's record.\n\nHe won the Kentucky Derby in 2024 while riding Mystik Dan, with guidance from Kenny McPeek. Riding Thorpedo Anna, McPeek's other horse, he had won the Kentucky Oaks the day before.\n\nHis major racing wins are Kentucky Derby (2024), Kentucky Oaks (2024), Louisiana Handicap (2004), Remington Springboard Mile Stakes (2004), Indiana Derby (2006, 2012), Edgewood Stakes (2007), Ack Ack Handicap (2012), Cornhusker Handicap (2012), Indiana Derby (2012), Indiana Oaks (2012, 2023), Whitney Handicap (2012), Beaumont Stakes (2013), Illinois Derby (2013), Opening Verse Stakes (2016, 2020). In the American Classics/Breeders' Cup wins, he clinched Kentucky Derby (2024) and Breeders' Cup Classic (2012).\n\nBrian \"B.J.\" Hernandez Jr's father was Brian Hernandez Sr, a former jockey. His brother Colby Hernandez and Courtney Hernandez are also into horse riding.\n\nThe Thoroughbred jockey resides in Simpsonville, Kentucky alongside his wife, Jamie and three kids Joshlyn, Benjamin and Anabelle. Hamby's father, Daniel Hamby Sr., was a salesman for Mystik brand tape. They combined that with his first name to create \"Mystik Dan.\"\n\nOblisk placed 12 bets total: four bets for $250 on Mystik Dan to win, four for him to place, and four for him to show. After cashing out his bets, he collected $59,986 at the wage booth outside section 322.\n\nHis friend, Craig Gough, also bet on Mystik Dan and predicted the first four finishers with a superfecta bet, taking home approximately $8,500. {"uri": "8112354696", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "12:57:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T12:57:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T12:56:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2024/05/05/the-best-dressed-man-at-the-kentucky-derby-also-happened-to-be-on-the-winning-side-of-mystik-dans-photo-finish/", "title": "The Best-Dressed Man At The Kentucky Derby Also Happened To Be On The Winning Side Of Mystik Dan's Photo Finish", "body": "The 150th Kentucky Derby was going to be iconic as it was by the mere fact that the Run for the Roses is halfway to its bicentennial, and the fact that Travis Kelce was in attendance with a hat-suit combo that'd make Nathan Detroit proud.\n\nBut was Taylor Swift's significant other the best-dressed man at Churchill Downs? Absolutely the f**k not.\n\nA man whose name I regretfully don't know, nor can I unearth it on the Twittersphere despite my best on-the-fly efforts, stole the show and some of the thunder from Mystik Dan's thrilling victory by a nose over Sierra Leone and Forever Young.\n\nHad to show the proper race before the reveal of this man. You wouldn't be prepared for the drop right away. Even before the race, folks were wondering just who the hell this guy was.\n\nAgain, man is a mystery and I don't mean any disrespect if he's, like, part of the training crew or something. All I know is, he was right next to Mystik Dan trainer Kenny McPeek for his interviews afterwards. Poor Go Long NFL writer Tyler Dunne -- news breaker of the Sean McDermott 9/11 speech -- called his shot that Mystik Dan would emerge victorious by force of sheer proximity to Mr. Stars and Stripes. Just couldn't pull the trigger on the winning bet slip in time.\n\nIt is painfully obvious that Captain America -- is that nickname too on the nose? Will workshop as I go here -- was fiercely dedicated to the Mystik Dan cause. That man's face was straight-up scalded by the sun.\n\nThe main takeaway from the Kentucky Derby and from this article is as follows. You can't tell me Mr. Stars and Stripes -- better moniker, that -- isn't personally responsible for the extra mojo Mystik Dan needed to edge out the competition at the finish line. Nor can you convince me that the strength of his charisma and the wattage of his general aura didn't spark such epic breakthroughs for McPeek and veteran jockey Brian Hernandez.\n\nDon't even need to look at Mystik Dan's pedigree. It's irrelevant. Mr. Stars and Stripes was and is the X-factor. You really want to bet against Mystik Dan at the Preakness with all this as context? Be my guest. I know who I'm tailing at the next Triple Crown race -- and it ain't because I'm hoping for Mystik Dan to achieve horse racing's most coveted trifecta of wins. It's because Mr. Stars and Stripes will not be denied.\n\nPledge your allegiance to Mr. Stars and Stripes. He is an instant legend. {"uri": "8112568602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:29:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:29:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:28:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/276725/mystik-dans-preakness-status-undecided-others-pass", "title": "Mystik Dan's Preakness Status Undecided, Others Pass", "body": "Sierra Leone will target the Belmont (G1); Baffert prepares two for Preakness (G1).\n\nThe day after the first jewel of the Triple Crown came to a thrilling end in the May 4 Kentucky Derby (G1) at Churchill Downs, attention started to turn toward the second jewel. With the Derby completed, the field for the 149th Preakness Stakes (G1) at Pimlico Race Course May 18 is beginning to take shape but will likely be missing much Derby influence.\n\nKentucky Derby-winning trainer Kenny McPeek had not yet completed his morning after Derby interview with the media May 5 before receiving a call from Pimlico officially inviting Mystik Dan to the Preakness. However, whether or not the Kentucky Derby winner participates is still yet to be determined.\n\n\"I'm undecided on Baltimore, we'll see,\" said McPeek.\n\nMcPeek said the Goldencents colt was tired following his gutsy performance in which he held off Blue Grass Stakes (G1) winner Sierra Leone by a nose. McPeek plans to send the Derby winner back to the track May 8, and will determine from there his status on the Preakness.\n\n\"If I don't think he's right and ready, then we'll just wait for the Belmont,\" McPeek said.\n\nSign up for BloodHorse Daily\n\nThe June 8 Belmont Stakes (G1) appears to be the most likely landing spot for many of the Derby contenders. With the race temporarily moving from Belmont Park to Saratoga Race Course due to Belmont Park reconstruction, the typical 1 1/2-mile distance will be reduced to the same 1 1/4 miles of the Derby. Saratoga's main-track track configuration necessitates the change.\n\n\"I think that distance at Saratoga is a great race,\" McPeek said. \"I actually like it better at a mile and a quarter than a mile and a half.\"\n\nMcPeek himself will head to Saratoga this week to begin prepping his barn for the summer.\n\n\"Better-than-average chance we're going to send him and some others straight to Saratoga,\" he added.\n\nOne of the weighing factors for McPeek could be that when Mystik Dan broke his maiden at Churchill Downs Nov. 12, he ran a flat fifth in allowance company just 13 days later. The two-week turn-around could be too quick for Mystik Dan, but McPeek also noted that things could be different this time as a 3-year-old.\n\n\"Horses sometimes pop back quickly, sometimes they don't,\" McPeek said. \"We'll just have to take that as it comes; it's too early to tell.\"\n\nMcPeek trains Mystik Dan for owners Lance Gasaway, 4 G Racing, Daniel Hamby III, and Valley View Farm.\n\nShould Mystik Dan compete in the Preakness, he will likely not see any of the horses who surrounded him at the end of the Derby.\n\nChad Brown, fresh off a heartbreaking defeat as Sierra Leone came up inches short of Derby glory, made it clear Sunday morning that the Belmont will be the son of Gun Runner 's next start.\n\n\"He's not going to the Preakness,\" Brown said. \"I'm going to take him to Saratoga tomorrow and he's going to train up there for the Belmont.\"\n\nSierra Leone will not be the only Derby horse whose connections are opting to skip the Preakness in favor of the Belmont. Connections for both Honor Marie and West Saratoga confirmed that the Belmont is currently their next target.\n\nThird-place finisher Forever Young and fifth-place finisher T O Password will both bypass the remainder of the Triple Crown. They are scheduled to fly back to Japan early this week.\n\nBrad Cox confirmed fourth-place finisher Catching Freedom is not under consideration for the Preakness. Bill Mott said sixth-place finisher Resilience , who made a threatening move on the far turn before flattening out in the stretch, will not go forward with the Triple Crown, alluding to shorter races being in the colt's future.\n\nLast year, Kentucky Derby winner Mage was the lone Derby starter to participate in the Preakness. It appears that 2024 could follow a similar story.\n\nNew Shooters\n\nWith many Derby contenders likely to skip the Preakness, this opens the door for new shooters looking to earn a victory in one of America's classics.\n\nZedan Racing Stable's two-time grade 1 winner Muth is one of the few horses with a confirmed bullseye drawn on the Preakness gate. Trained by Bob Baffert, the Arkansas Derby (G1) winner was not eligible to start in the Kentucky Derby due to Baffert's suspension from Churchill Downs following a failed drug test that disqualified Medina Spirit 's victory in the 2021 Kentucky Derby.\n\nIn the Arkansas Derby, Muth defeated Mystik Dan by 6 1/4 lengths. Even if Mystik Dan returns for the Preakness, it is likely that Muth will be the favorite for the Triple Crown's middle jewel.\n\nBaffert is also preparing San Felipe Stakes (G2) winner and Santa Anita Derby (G1) runner-up Imagination for the Preakness. That colt races for the partnership of SF Racing, Starlight Racing, Madaket Stables, Stonestreet Stables, Dianne Bashor, Bob Masterson, Waves Edge Capital, Catherine Donovan, and Tom Ryan.\n\nThe Baffert duo worked together at Santa Anita Park May 4, breezing a bullet six furlongs in 1:11 2/5.\n\nBrown-trained Tuscan Gold , third in the Louisiana Derby (G2), is under consideration for the Preakness. However, Brown plans to enter the son of Medaglia d'Oro in the May 11 Peter Pan Stakes (G3) at Aqueduct Racetrack.\n\n\"See how (the Peter Pan) comes up,\" Brown said about his decision between the two races. \"Where he draws -- it's likely to be a big field from what I'm hearing -- weather, keep an eye on (who's going to the) Preakness. Go from there.\"\n\nSeveral horses have earned automatic-berth victories in prep races for the Preakness and could be possibilities for the race in Baltimore, Md.\n\nFour-time stakes winner Copper Tax earned an automatic berth to the Preakness with his victory in the April 20 Federico Tesio Stakes at Laurel Park. Since his victory, the son of Copper Bullet has yet to record a published workout for trainer Gary Capuano.\n\nAlso on April 20, Informed Patriot earned a Preakness berth after victory in the Bathhouse Row Stakes at Oaklawn Park. The Hard Spun colt worked a half-mile in :52 for trainer Steve Asmussen Sunday at Oaklawn Park.\n\nPatriot Spirit earned a $20,000 credit toward Preakness entry fees after winning the April 21 Illinois Derby at Hawthorne Race Course but he is not Triple Crown nominated. {"uri": "8111823656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:45:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:45:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:42:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/sports/ap-sports-summarybrief-at-11-34-p-m-edt/article_9ff3f3ab-abf6-5fd1-8861-9654e2587d71.html", "title": "AP Sports SummaryBrief at 11:34 p.m. EDT", "body": "Mystik Dan wins 150th Kentucky Derby by a nose in the closest 3-horse photo finish since 1947\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Mystik Dan won the 150th Kentucky Derby in a dramatic three-horse photo finish, edging out Sierra Leone and Forever Young for the upset victory. It was the 10th Derby to be decided by a nose, the closest margin in horse racing. Sent off at 18-1 odds, Mystik Dan and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode the rail down the stretch with a short lead. Sierra Leone and Forever Young from Japan gave chase and pressured the leader to the wire in front of 156,710 at Churchill Downs on Saturday. Hernandez and trainer Kenny McPeek had teamed to win the Kentucky Oaks for fillies a day earlier with Thorpedo Anna. Mystik Dan ran 1 1/4 miles in 2:03.34 and paid $39.22 to win.\n\nKentucky Derby victory aboard Mystik Dan provides signature win for jockey Brian Hernandez Jr.\n\nLOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) -- Jockey Brian Hernandez Jr. rode Mystik Dan to victory in the 150th Kentucky Derby to complete the most rewarding weekend of his career. The Eclipse Award winner and Breeders' Cup champion won the milestone derby a day after guiding filly Thorpedo Anna to a wire-to-wire victory by 4 3/4 lengths in the Kentucky Oaks. He became the first jockey to complete the Derby/Oaks double since Hall of Famer Calvin Borel in 2009, fitting considering Hernandez studied Borel's derby wins and spent time with him in his Kentucky racing career. And, he's no longer under the radar as a jockey.\n\nEdwards scores 43 points, Reid erupts in 4th to help Timberwolves beat Nuggets 106-99 in Game 1\n\nDENVER (AP) -- Anthony Edwards scored a playoff career-high 43 points, Naz Reid had 14 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter and the Minnesota Timberwolves beat the defending NBA champion Denver Nuggets 106-99 in Game 1 of the second-round series Saturday night. Edwards was unstoppable in the first half, scoring 25 points, and Reid took over in the fourth quarter. Game 2 is Monday night in Denver. Three days after undergoing knee surgery, Timberwolves coach Chris Finch was on the bench in the second row, next to the scorer's table and behind assistant coach Micah Nori, who did the instructing, roaming and switching. Two-time NBA MVP Nikola Jokic had 32 points, eight rebounds and nine assists for Denver.\n\nDavid Pastrnak scores in overtime to lift Bruins to Game 7 win over rival Maple Leafs\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- David Pastrnak scored on a feed from Hampus Lindholm 1:54 into overtime and the Boston Bruins beat the Toronto Maple Leafs 2-1 in Game 7 to clinch their first-round series and advance in the NHL playoffs. Jeremy Swayman finished with 30 saves and Lindholm had the tying goal in regulation to help the Bruins avoid losing their second straight first-round series after holding a 3-1 lead. They have now defeated the rival Maple Leafs in Game 7 of the first round of the playoffs three times in the last seven years. Boston will meet the Florida Panthers, who upset the Bruins in seven games in the first round last year.\n\nMessi has a record-setting game with a goal and 5 assists in Inter Miami's 6-2 win over Red Bulls\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- Lionel Messi set three MLS records with a goal and five assists as Inter Miami trounced the New York Red Bulls 6-2. His six goal contributions, five assists and five assists in a half were all league records. Fresh after earning MLS Player of the Month Award for April, Messi has scored and assisted in six consecutive league matches. Luis Su\u00e1rez had three goals and Matias Rojas scored twice as Inter Miami scored six unanswered goals to come back from a 1-0 halftime deficit. Inter Miami remains atop the Eastern Conference with 24 points. Dante Vanzeir gave New York the first-half lead. The Red Bulls dropped to 4-2-5.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nTaylor Pendrith leads Byron Nelson as one of several seeking first PGA Tour victory\n\nMcKINNEY, Texas (AP) -- Taylor Pendrith has a one-shot lead going into the final round of the CJ Cup Byron Nelson. The Canadian is among several leaders seeking his first PGA Tour victory. Pendrith chipped in twice for consecutive eagles to kick-start his round of 8-under 63. It's the third time for back-to-back eagles on tour this season. Pendrith is at 19 under, one shot ahead of second-round leader Jake Knapp. First-round leader Matt Wallace is another shot back in a tie with Ben Kohles.\n\nYankees slugger Aaron Judge ejected for first time in his career\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- New York Yankees slugger Aaron Judge was ejected for the first time in his career when he argued a called third strike by plate umpire Ryan Blakney in the seventh inning of Saturday's game against the Detroit Tigers. With one out, Judge took a full count fastball from Tyler Holton that he thought was slightly outside. Blakney rang him up, Judge glanced back and was ejected. After starting to walk back to the dugout, Judge returned to argue the call and manager Aaron Boone continued the argument.\n\nHaaland scores 4 in another win for Man City. Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though\n\nErling Haaland scored four goals in another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown. Yet Arsenal isn't going away in this title race. Haaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton. It was a response to Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth a few hours earlier. Arsenal retained its one-point lead over City but the defending champions have three games left. That's one more than Arsenal. Burnley slipped closer to relegation with a 4-1 loss to Newcastle.\n\nReal Madrid wins its record-extending 36th Spanish league title after Barcelona loses at Girona\n\nBARCELONA, Spain (AP) -- Real Madrid has won its record-extending 36th Spanish league title after securing an insurmountable 13-point lead over second-place Girona with four games remaining. Madrid reclaimed the domestic crown after beating Cadiz 3-0 earlier Saturday and Barcelona then lost 4-2 at Girona. Only a victory by Barcelona would have stopped Madrid from celebrating. Girona leapfrogged Barcelona and pushed its Catalan rival into third place at 14 points behind Madrid. Madrid hosts Bayern Munich in the Champions League on Wednesday with their semifinal evenly balanced after a 2-2 first-leg draw in Germany.\n\nCavaliers and Magic to settle playoff series standoff with Game 7 -- the 'best two words in sports'\n\nCLEVELAND (AP) -- The Cavs and Magic are going to the limit. Unable to find a way to win on the road, Cleveland and Orlando will settle their series on Sunday with a Game 7, a fitting conclusion between two teams that have put their strengths and weaknesses on public display for six games. Only one advances to face the Boston Celtics, who will be well-rested for whichever team escapes this stalemate. ESPN's Marty Smith shared just how rare it is:\n\nNBC Sports also provided the overhead footage of the race which gave another angle of just how close the the run to the finish was.\n\nIt proved to be a great weekend for trainer Kenny McPeek. He became the first trainer since 1952 and the fourth ever to win both the Kentucky Derby and Kentucky Oaks in the same year. Thorpeda Anna won the 150th Oaks on Friday night in a much more dominant showing.\n\nGoing into the weekend McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez hadn't won either of the major Churchill Downs races despite 33 combined entries. With Hernandez aboard both winners, they made history together.\n\nIt's going to be hard for the rest of the major races left on the calendar to top what we saw in Louisville, but the fun is just getting started.\n\nMcPeek was non-committal about whether his horse would enter the Preakness and contend for the second jewel of the Crown, per Andrew DeWitt of The Athletic.\n\nIf he does it will certainly bring more attention to the historic race on May 18th at Pimlico race track in Baltimore, Maryland.\n\nNot only will a few of the contenders from the Derby be waiting for him but a few "body": "After Saturday's photo finish in the 150th Kentucky Derby, Mystik Dan will have the chance to become the fourteenth horse to ever win a Triple Crown.\n\nMystik Dan, led by trainer Kenny McPeek and jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., could now compete for the second leg of the crown later this month at the 2024 Preakness Stakes.\n\nThe surprise Derby winner is likely to once again face steep odds at Pimlico with some top competitors likely to run.\n\nLast year, only 2023 Derby winner Mage ran both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, but other top finishers Sierra Leone and Forever Young could consider seeking redemption in the Preakness after coming within a nose of a Derby win.\n\nSierra Leone, Derby runner-up and winner of the Grade 1 Blue Grass, is ridden by jockey Tyler Gaffalione, who won the Preakness with War of Will in 2019.\n\nThe Japan-bred Forever Young finished in a close third in the Derby after winning the Group 2 UAE Derby in March.\n\nTwo horses trained by Bob Baffert are likely to take on the Preakness after sitting out the Kentucky Derby following Baffert's Churchill Downs' suspension.\n\nMuth, winner of the Grade 1 Arkansas Derby, and Imagination, second in the Grade 1 Santa Anita Derby, worked six furlongs together at Santa Anita Saturday in preparation for the race, per Victor Ryan of the Paulick Report.\n\nMuth covered the distance in 1:12 2/5 and is expected to be a favorite at Pimlico, per Byron King of Blood Horse.\n\nThorpedo Anna could travel to Pimlico after winning Friday's Kentucky Oaks, but trainer Ken McPeek told the Daily Racing Form's Nicole Russo that the chances were \"less than 50 percent.\" Her availability will depend on how she recovers over the next few days.\n\nCooper Tax, winner of a Preakness berth after finishing first in the Federico Tesio Stake in April, could decide to run after recovering from an early stumble and rallying to win at Laurel Park, Frank Vespe reported for Racing Biz. Trainer Gary Capuano says the decision will depend on the horse's training and weight heading into the Preakness, per Pimlico.com.\n\nInformed Patriot could arrive at the Preakness after winning the Bath House Row Stakes at Oaklawn in April in what his trainer Steve Asmussen called the horse's \"best race to date,\" per Mary Rampellini of Daily Racing Form.\n\nThe 2024 Preakness Stakes will take place Saturday, May 18 at the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, Maryland. {"uri": "8111676455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:40:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:40:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:40:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/horse-racing/kentucky-derby-mystik-dan-photo-finish-nose/632582", "title": "Mystik Dan wins Kentucky Derby by a literal nose", "body": "Saturday's Kentucky Derby was one of the closest finishes in recent memory, and perhaps of any Triple Crown race ever.\n\n18-1 underdog Mystik Dan managed to hold off Sierra Leone by a literal nose, with Forever Young in third. Remarkably, the top three horses could barely be separated, and the official announcement of a winner was delayed by over ten minutes as officials looked at every angle in a literal photo finish.\n\nThe actual teletimer finish showed just how close the race was. Mystik Dan eked it out by a literal nose, and Sierra Leone was just as close to Forever Young to seize second.\n\nThe finish was unquestionably one of the closest in Kentucky Derby history. It is also the most memorable since 2019, which saw the initial winner disqualified after the race. That appears unlikely this time, thankfully, since the nose-to-nose finish was exhilarating to watch.", "source": {"uri": "larrybrownsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Larry Brown Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "grey_papke@larrybrownsports.com", "name": "Grey Papke", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Thoroughbred_Racing_(United_States)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky_Derby", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kentucky Derby"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Sierra Leone"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_racing", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Horse racing"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Auto_Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Auto Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Snowmobile_Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Snowmobile Racing", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Personal_Watercraft_Racing", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Motorsports/Personal Watercraft Racing", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://larrybrownsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/kentucky-derby-photo-finish.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539947", "eventUri": "eng-9539947", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.192156862745098, "wgt": 135, "relevance": 1}

{"uri": "8111676441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:40:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:40:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:40:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/05/04/1249206141/kentucky-derby-winner-mystik-dan", "title": "Mystik Dan wins the Kentucky Derby by a nose", "body": "Sierra Leone, with jockey Tyler Gaffalione, (2), Forever Young, with jockey Ryusei Sakai, and Mystik Dan, with jockey Brian Hernandez Jr., cross the finish line at Churchill Downs during the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby horse race Saturday, in Louisville, Ky.\n\nIn a close finish, Mystik Dan won the Kentucky Derby by a mere horse's nostril over Sierra Leone.\n\nContenders waited with bated breath in the seconds before the official decision was made. The thoroughbred had entered the race with 18-1 odds -- a longshot compared to favorite Fierceness at 3-1 odds.\n\nBehind Sierra Leone, Forever Young placed third.\n\nThe weather behaved on Saturday at the 150th running of the race. The longest running sporting event in the U.S. was held following changes to aiming to clean up the sport.\n\nMultiple scandals have plagued the horse racing industry in recent years, including a sudden uptick in horse deaths and doping allegations. In 2020, more than two dozen people were indicted in a racehorse doping scheme. Last year, Churchill Downs drew increased scrutiny after 12 horses died at the track within a month.\n\nAbout a year later, multiple investigations have found no pattern connecting those deaths, reported member station Louisville Public Media.\n\nThe sport in general is dangerous for horses. Last year, 336 horses died from racing-related injuries, according to the Jockey Club.\n\nIn response to doping and abuse allegations, Congress in 2021 approved the creation of the Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority, which aims to set national standards to regulate the sport.\n\nThe federal body put new anti-doping rules into effect at Churchill Downs this year. HISA CEO Lisa Lazarus told LPM this week that the horses have been repeatedly tested.\n\n\"If they're running in the Derby, it means they have not had an issue with our program,\" she said.", {"uri": "8112913754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "23:43:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T23:43:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T23:42:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/horse-racing/mystik-dan-kentucky-derby-triple-crown-preakness/632638", "title": "Kentucky Derby winner Mystik Dan may not make Triple Crown attempt", "body": "Mystik Dan has already claimed the first race in the chase for the Triple Crown, but the colt might not even try for the second.\n\nCiting the short two-week turnaround between the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, trainer Kenny McPeek refused to commit to running Mystik Dan in the second leg of the Triple Crown. McPeek said they would ultimately let the horse indicate how he was feeling.\n\n\"We're not committed to the Preakness, not yet,\" McPeek said Sunday, via Gary B. Graves of the Associated Press. \"I ran him back once in two weeks and it completely backfired on me. ... So, we'll just watch him over the next week. It'll be one of those (situations) where we'll probably take it up to the last minute.\n\n\"We'll let him tell us.\"\n\nThat would be disappointing, but not unprecedented. A number of Kentucky Derby winners have skipped the Preakness, most recently 2022 winner Rich Strike, a longshot Derby winner that had not planned in running in the Preakness to begin with.\n\nJustify is the most recent horse to win the Triple Crown, having done so in 2018.
